revision.comment: Added free to read link in citations with [[WP:OABOT|OAbot]] #oabot
revision.text:
{{technical|date=October 2013}} A '''charge density wave''' (CDW) is an ordered [[quantum fluid]] of electrons in a linear chain compound or layered crystal. The electrons within a CDW form a standing wave pattern and sometimes collectively carry an electric current. The electrons in such a CDW, like those in a [[superconductor]], can flow through a linear chain compound en masse, in a highly correlated fashion. Unlike a superconductor, however, the electric CDW current often flows in a jerky fashion, much like water dripping from a faucet due to its electrostatic properties. In a CDW, the combined effects of pinning (due to impurities) and electrostatic interactions (due to the net electric charges of any CDW kinks) likely play critical roles in the CDW current's jerky behavior, as discussed in sections 4 & 5 below.
Most CDW's in metallic crystals form due to the wave-like nature of electrons – a manifestation of quantum mechanical [[wave-particle duality]] – causing the electronic charge density to become spatially modulated, i.e., to form periodic "bumps" in charge. This [[standing wave]] affects each electronic [[wave function]], and is created by combining electron states, or wavefunctions, of opposite momenta. The effect is somewhat analogous to the standing wave in a guitar string, which can be viewed as the combination of two interfering, traveling waves moving in opposite directions (see [[interference (wave propagation)]]).
The CDW in electronic charge is accompanied by a periodic distortion – essentially a superlattice – of the [[crystal structure|atomic lattice]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=G. Grüner|title=The dynamics of charge density waves|journal=Reviews of Modern Physics|year=1988|volume=60|issue=4|pages=1129–1181 |doi= 10.1103/RevModPhys.60.1129|bibcode = 1988RvMP...60.1129G }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=P. Monceau|title=Electronic crystals: an experimental overview|journal=Advances in Physics|year=2012|volume=61|issue=4|pages=325–581 |doi=10.1080/00018732.2012.719674|arxiv = 1307.0929 |bibcode = 2012AdPhy..61..325M }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=B. Savitsky|title=Bending and breaking of stripes in a charge ordered manganite|journal=Nature Communications|year=2017|volume=8|pages=1883 |doi=10.1038/s41467-017-02156-1|arxiv = 1707.00221 |bibcode=2017NatCo...8.1883S}}</ref> The metallic crystals look like thin shiny ribbons (e.g., quasi-1-D NbSe<sub>3</sub> crystals) or shiny flat sheets (e.g., quasi-2-D, 1T-TaS<sub>2</sub> crystals). The CDW's existence was first predicted in the 1930s by [[Rudolf Peierls]]. He argued that a 1-D metal would be unstable to the formation of energy gaps at the Fermi [[wavevector]]s ±''k<sub>F</sub>'', which reduce the energies of the filled electronic states at ±''k<sub>F</sub>'' as compared to their original [[Fermi energy]] ''E<sub>F</sub>''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Thorne|title=Charge‐Density‐Wave Conductors|first=Robert E.|date=May 1996|journal=[[Physics Today]]|volume=49|issue=5|pages=42–47|doi=10.1063/1.881498|bibcode=1996PhT....49e..42T}}</ref> The temperature below which such gaps form is known as the [[Peierls transition]] temperature, ''T<sub>P</sub>''.
The electron spins are spatially modulated to form a standing spin wave in a [[spin density wave]] (SDW). A SDW can be viewed as two CDWs for the spin-up and spin-down subbands, whose charge modulations are 180° out-of-phase.
== Fröhlich model of superconductivity == In 1954, [[Herbert Fröhlich]] proposed a microscopic theory,<ref>{{cite journal|author=H. Fröhlich|title=On the Theory of Superconductivity: The One-Dimensional Case|journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society A]]|year=1954|volume=223|issue=1154|pages=296–305 |doi= 10.1098/rspa.1954.0116|bibcode = 1954RSPSA.223..296F }}</ref> in which energy gaps at ±''k<sub>F</sub>'' would form below a transition temperature as a result of the interaction between the [[electrons]] and [[phonon]]s of wavevector ''Q''=2''k<sub>F</sub>''. Conduction at high temperatures is metallic in a quasi-1-D conductor, whose [[Fermi surface]] consists of fairly flat sheets perpendicular to the chain direction at ±''k<sub>F</sub>''. The electrons near the Fermi surface couple strongly with the phonons of 'nesting' wave number ''Q'' = 2''k<sub>F</sub>''. The 2''k<sub>F</sub>'' mode thus becomes softened as a result of the electron-phonon interaction.<ref>{{cite journal|author=John Bardeen|title=Superconductivity and other macroscopic quantum phenomena|journal=Physics Today|year=1990|volume=43|issue=12|pages=25–31|doi= 10.1063/1.881218|bibcode = 1990PhT....43l..25B}}</ref> The 2''k<sub>F</sub>'' phonon mode frequency decreases with decreasing temperature, and finally goes to zero at the [[Peierls transition]] temperature. Since phonons are [[boson]]s, this mode becomes macroscopically occupied at lower temperatures, and is manifested by a static periodic lattice distortion. At the same time, an electronic CDW forms, and the Peierls gap opens up at ±''k<sub>F</sub>''. Below the Peierls transition temperature, a complete Peierls gap leads to thermally activated behavior in the conductivity due to normal uncondensed electrons.
However, a CDW whose wavelength is incommensurate with the underlying atomic lattice, i.e., where the CDW wavelength is not an integer multiple of the lattice constant, would have no preferred position, or phase ''φ'', in its charge modulation ''ρ<sub>0</sub>'' + ''ρ<sub>1</sub>''cos[2''k<sub>F</sub>x – φ'']. Fröhlich thus proposed that the CDW could move and, moreover, that the Peierls gaps would be displaced in [[momentum space]] along with the entire [[Fermi sea]], leading to an electric current proportional to ''dφ/dt''. However, as discussed in subsequent sections, even an incommensurate CDW cannot move freely, but is pinned by impurities. Moreover, interaction with normal carriers leads to dissipative transport, unlike a superconductor.
== CDWs in quasi-2-D layered materials == Several quasi-2-D systems, including layered transition metal [[dichalcogenide]]s,<ref>{{cite journal|author=W. L. McMillan|title=Landau theory of charge-density waves in transition-metal dichalcogenides|journal=Physical Review B|year=1975|volume=12|issue=4|pages=1187–1196 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.12.1187|url= http://x-ray.ucsd.edu/mediawiki/images/b/bc/McMillan_Landau_theory_PRB_75.pdf|bibcode = 1975PhRvB..12.1187M }}</ref> undergo Peierls transitions to form quasi-2-D CDWs. These result from multiple nesting wavevectors coupling different flat regions of the Fermi surface.<ref>{{cite journal|author=A. A. Kordyuk |title=Pseudogap from ARPES experiment: Three gaps in cuprates and topological superconductivity (Review Article)|journal=Low Temperature Physics|volume=41|issue=5|pages=319|year=2015|arxiv=1501.04154 |doi=10.1063/1.4919371|bibcode=2015LTP....41..319K}}</ref> The charge modulation can either form a honeycomb lattice with hexagonal symmetry or a checkerboard pattern. A concomitant periodic lattice displacement accompanies the CDW and has been directly observed in 1T-TaS<sub>2</sub> using cryogenic electron microscopy.<ref>{{cite journal|author=R. Hovden, et al.|title=Atomic Lattice Disorder in Charge Density Wave Phases of Exfoliated Dichalcogenides (1T-TaS<sub>2</sub>)|journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |year=2016|volume=113|issue=41|pages=11420–11424|doi=10.1073/pnas.1606044113|pmid=27681627|pmc=5068312|arxiv = 1609.09486 |bibcode = 2016PNAS..11311420H }}</ref> In 2012, evidence for competing, incipient CDW phases were reported for layered cuprate [[high-temperature superconductors]] such as YBCO.<ref>{{cite journal|author=T. Wu, H. Mayaffre, S. Krämer, M. Horvatić, C. Berthier, W. N. Hardy, R. Liang, D. A. Bonn, M.-H. Julien |year=2011|title=Magnetic-field-induced charge-stripe order in the high-temperature superconductor YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>y</sub>|journal=Nature |volume=477|issue=7363|pages=191–194|doi=10.1038/nature10345|bibcode=2011Natur.477..191W|arxiv=1109.2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=J. Chang |author2=E. Blackburn |author3=A. T. Holmes |author4=N. B. Christensen |author5=J. Larsen |author6=J. Mesot |author7=R. Liang |author8=D. A. Bonn |author9=W. N. Hardy |author10=A. Watenphul |author11=M. v. Zimmermann |author12=E. M. Forgan |author13=S. M. Hayden |title=Direct observation of competition between superconductivity and charge density wave order in YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>6.67</sub>|journal=Nature Physics|year=2012|volume=8|issue=12|pages=871–876|doi= 10.1038/nphys2456|arxiv = 1206.4333 |bibcode = 2012NatPh...8..871C }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=G. Ghiringhelli |author2=M. Le Tacon |author3=M. Minola |author4=S. Blanco-Canosa |author5=C. Mazzoli |author6=N. B. Brookes |author7=G. M. De Luca |author8=A. Frano |author9=D. G. Hawthorn |author10=F. He |author11=T. Loew |author12=M. M. Sala |author13=D. C. Peets |author14=M. Salluzzo |author15=E. Schierle |author16=R. Sutarto |author17=G. A. Sawatzky |author18=E. Weschke |author19=B. Keimer |author20=L. Braicovich |title=Long-Range Incommensurate Charge Fluctuations in (Y,Nd)Ba<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>6+x</sub>|journal=Science|year=2012|volume=337|issue=6096|pages=821–825 |doi=10.1126/science.1223532|pmid=22798406 |arxiv = 1207.0915 |bibcode = 2012Sci...337..821G }}</ref>
== CDW transport in linear chain compounds == Early studies of quasi-1-D conductors were motivated by a proposal, in 1964, that certain types of polymer chain compounds could exhibit superconductivity with a high critical temperature ''T<sub>c</sub>''.<ref>{{cite journal | author = W. A. Little | journal = [[Physical Review]] | volume = 134 | year = 1964 | pages = A1416–A1424 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRev.134.A1416 | title = Possibility of Synthesizing an Organic Superconductor | issue = 6A|bibcode = 1964PhRv..134.1416L }}</ref> The theory was based on the idea that pairing of electrons in the [[BCS theory]] of [[superconductivity]] could be mediated by interactions of conducting electrons in one chain with nonconducting electrons in some side chains. (By contrast, electron pairing is mediated by [[phonon]]s, or vibrating ions, in the [[BCS theory]] of conventional superconductors.) Since light electrons, instead of heavy ions, would lead to the formation of Cooper pairs, their characteristic frequency and, hence, energy scale and ''T<sub>c</sub>'' would be enhanced. Organic materials, such as [[Charge-transfer complex#Electrical conductivity|TTF-TCNQ]] were measured and studied theoretically in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=P. W. Anderson |author2=P. A. Lee |author3=M. Saitoh | journal = [[Solid State Communications]] | volume = 13 | year = 1973 | pages = 595–598 | doi = 10.1016/S0038-1098(73)80020-1 | title = Remarks on giant conductivity in TTF-TCNQ | bibcode=1973SSCom..13..595A | issue = 5}}</ref> These materials were found to undergo a metal-insulator, rather than superconducting, transition. It was eventually established that such experiments represented the first observations of the [[Peierls transition]].
The first evidence for CDW transport in inorganic linear chain compounds, such as transition metal trichalcogenides, was reported in 1976 by Monceau et al.,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=P. Monceau |author2=N. P. Ong |author3=A. M. Portis |author4=A. Meerschaut |author5=J. Rouxel |title=Electric Field Breakdown of Charge-Density-Wave—Induced Anomalies in NbSe<sub>3</sub> |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=1976 |volume=37 |issue=10 |pages=602–606 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.37.602 |bibcode=1976PhRvL..37..602M }}</ref> who observed enhanced electrical conduction at increased electric fields in [[niobium triselenide|NbSe<sub>3</sub>]]. The nonlinear contribution to the electrical conductivity ''σ'' vs. field ''E'' was fit to a Landau-Zener tunneling characteristic ~ exp[-''E''<sub>0</sub>/''E''] (see [[Landau–Zener formula]]), but it was soon realized that the characteristic Zener field ''E''<sub>0</sub> was far too small to represent Zener tunneling of normal electrons across the Peierls gap. Subsequent experiments<ref>{{cite journal |author1=R. M. Fleming |author2=C. C. Grimes |title=Sliding-Mode Conductivity in NbSe<sub>3</sub>: Observation of a Threshold Electric Field and Conduction Noise |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=1979 |volume=42 |issue=21 |pages=1423–1426 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.42.1423 |bibcode=1979PhRvL..42.1423F }}</ref> showed a sharp threshold electric field, as well as peaks in the noise spectrum (narrow band noise) whose fundamental frequency scales with the CDW current. These and other experiments (e.g.,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=P. Monceau |author2=J. Richard |author3=M. Renard |title=Interference Effects of the Charge-Density-Wave Motion in NbSe<sub>3</sub> |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=1980 |volume=45 |issue=1 |pages=43–46 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.45.43 |bibcode=1980PhRvL..45...43M }}</ref>) confirm that the CDW collectively carries an electric current in a jerky fashion above the threshold field.
== Classical models of CDW depinning == Linear chain compounds exhibiting CDW transport have CDW wavelengths ''λ<sub>cdw</sub>'' = ''π/k<sub>F</sub>'' incommensurate with (i.e., not an integer multiple of) the lattice constant. In such materials, pinning is due to impurities that break the translational symmetry of the CDW with respect to ''φ''.<ref>{{cite book|author=George Gruner|title=Density Waves in Solids|publisher=Addison-Wesley|year=1994|isbn=0-201-62654-3}}</ref> The simplest model treats the pinning as a sine-Gordon potential of the form ''u''(''φ'') = ''u''<sub>0</sub>[1 – cos''φ''], while the [[electric field]] tilts the periodic pinning potential until the phase can slide over the barrier above the classical depinning field. Known as the [[overdamped]] oscillator model, since it also models the damped CDW response to oscillatory (ac) electric fields, this picture accounts for the scaling of the narrow-band noise with CDW current above threshold.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=G. Grüner |author2=A. Zawadowski |author3=P. M. Chaikin |title=Nonlinear conductivity and noise due to charge-density-wave depinning in NbSe<sub>3</sub> |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=1981 |volume=46 |issue=7 |pages=511–515 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.46.511 |bibcode=1981PhRvL..46..511G }}</ref>
However, since impurities are randomly distributed throughout the crystal, a more realistic picture must allow for variations in optimum CDW phase ''φ'' with position - essentially a modified sine-Gordon picture with a disordered washboard potential. This is done in the Fukuyama-Lee-Rice (FLR) model,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=H. Fukuyama |author2=P. A. Lee |title=Dynamics of the charge-density wave. I. Impurity pinning in a single chain |journal=Physical Review B |year=1978 |volume=17 |issue=2 |pages=535–541 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.17.535 |bibcode=1978PhRvB..17..535F }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=P. A. Lee |author2=T. M. Rice |title=Electric field depinning of charge density waves |journal=Physical Review B |year=1979 |volume=19 |issue=8 |pages=3970–3980 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.19.3970 |bibcode=1979PhRvB..19.3970L }}</ref> in which the CDW minimizes its total energy by optimizing both the elastic strain energy due to spatial gradients in ''φ'' and the pinning energy. Two limits that emerge from FLR include weak pinning, typically from isoelectronic impurities, where the optimum phase is spread over many impurities and the depinning field scales as ''n<sub>i</sub>''<sup>2</sup> (''n<sub>i</sub>'' being the impurity concentration) and strong pinning, where each impurity is strong enough to pin the CDW phase and the depinning field scales linearly with ''n<sub>i</sub>''. Variations of this theme include numerical simulations that incorporate random distributions of impurities (random pinning model).<ref>{{cite journal |author=P. B. Littlewood |title=Sliding charge-density waves: A numerical study |journal=Physical Review B |year=1986 |volume=33 |issue=10 |pages=6694–6708 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.33.6694 |bibcode=1986PhRvB..33.6694L }}</ref>
== Quantum models of CDW transport == Early quantum models included a soliton pair creation model by Maki<ref>{{cite journal|author=Kazumi Maki |title=Creation of soliton pairs by electric fields in charge-density—wave condensates |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=1977 |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=46–48 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.39.46 |bibcode=1977PhRvL..39...46M }}</ref> and a proposal by [[John Bardeen]] that condensed CDW electrons tunnel coherently through a tiny pinning gap,<ref>{{cite journal|author=John Bardeen |title=Theory of non-ohmic conduction from charge-density waves in NbSe<sub>3</sub> |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=1979 |volume=42 |issue=22 |pages=1498–1500 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.42.1498 |bibcode=1979PhRvL..42.1498B }}</ref> fixed at ±''k<sub>F</sub>'' unlike the Peierls gap. Maki's theory lacked a sharp threshold field and Bardeen only gave a phenomenological interpretation of the threshold field.<ref>{{cite journal|author=John Bardeen |title=Tunneling theory of charge-density-wave depinning |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=1980 |volume=45 |issue=24 |pages=1978–1980 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.45.1978|bibcode=1980PhRvL..45.1978B }}</ref> However, a 1985 paper by Krive and Rozhavsky<ref>{{cite journal|author1=I. V. Krive |author2=A. S. Rozhavsky |title= On the nature of threshold electric field in quasi-one-dimensional commensurate charge-density-waves |journal= Solid State Communications |year=1985|volume=55|issue=8|pages=691–694 |doi= 10.1016/0038-1098(85)90235-2|bibcode = 1985SSCom..55..691K }}</ref> pointed out that nucleated solitons and antisolitons of charge ±''q'' generate an internal [[electric field]] ''E*'' proportional to ''q/ε''. The electrostatic energy (1/2)''ε''[''E'' ± ''E*'']<sup>2</sup> prevents soliton tunneling for applied fields ''E'' less than a threshold ''E<sub>T</sub>'' = ''E*''/2 without violating energy conservation. Although this [[Coulomb blockade]] threshold can be much smaller than the classical depinning field, it shows the same scaling with impurity concentration since the CDW's polarizability and dielectric response ''ε'' vary inversely with pinning strength.<ref>{{cite journal|author=G. Grüner|title=The dynamics of charge density waves|journal=Reviews of Modern Physics|year=1988|volume=60|issue=4|pages=1129–1181 |doi= 10.1103/RevModPhys.60.1129|bibcode = 1988RvMP...60.1129G }}</ref>
Building on this picture, as well as a 2000 article on time-correlated soliton tunneling,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=J. H. Miller |author2=C. Ordóñez |author3=E. Prodan |title=Time-correlated soliton tunneling in charge and spin density waves |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=2000 |volume=84 |issue=7 |pages=1555–1558 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.84.1555 |pmid=11017566 |bibcode=2000PhRvL..84.1555M }}</ref> a more recent quantum model<ref>{{cite journal|author1=J.H. Miller, Jr. |author2=A.I. Wijesinghe |author3=Z. Tang |author4=A.M. Guloy |title= Correlated quantum transport of density wave electrons|journal=Physical Review Letters|year=2012|volume=108|issue=3|pages=036404|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.036404|pmid=22400766 |bibcode = 2012PhRvL108L36404M|arxiv=1109.4619}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|author1=J.H. Miller, Jr. |author2=A.I. Wijesinghe |author3=Z. Tang |author4=A.M. Guloy |title= Coherent quantum transport of charge density waves|journal=Physical Review B |volume=87 |issue=11 |pages=115127 |arxiv=1212.3020|year=2012 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.87.115127 |bibcode = 2013PhRvB..87k5127M }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=J.H. Miller, Jr. |author2=A.I. Wijesinghe |author3=Z. Tang |author4=A.M. Guloy |title=Coherent quantum transport of charge density waves |journal=Physical Review B |year=2013 |volume=87 |issue=11 |pages=115127 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.87.115127 |arxiv=1212.3020 |bibcode=2013PhRvB..87k5127M }}</ref> proposes Josephson-like coupling (see [[Josephson effect]]) between complex order parameters associated with nucleated droplets of charged soliton dislocations on many parallel chains. Following [[Richard Feynman]] in [[The Feynman Lectures on Physics]], Vol. III, Ch. 21, their time-evolution is described using the [[Schrödinger equation]] as an emergent classical equation. The narrow-band noise and related phenomena result from the periodic buildup of electrostatic charging energy and thus do not depend on the detailed shape of the washboard pinning potential. Both a soliton pair-creation threshold and a higher classical depinning field emerge from the model, which views the CDW as a sticky quantum fluid or deformable quantum solid with dislocations, a concept discussed by [[Philip Warren Anderson]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Philip W. Anderson|title=Basic Notions in Condensed Matter Physics|publisher=Benjamin/Cummings|year=1984|isbn=0-8053-0220-4}}</ref>
== Aharonov–Bohm quantum interference effects == The first evidence for phenomena related to the [[Aharonov–Bohm effect]] in CDWs was reported in a 1997 paper,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Y. I. Latyshev |author2=O. Laborde |author3=P. Monceau |author4=S. Klaumünzer |title=Aharonov-Bohm effect on charge density wave (CDW) moving through columnar defects in NbSe<sub>3</sub> |journal=Physical Review Letters |year=1997 |volume=78 |issue=5 |pages=919–922 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.78.919 |bibcode=1997PhRvL..78..919L }}</ref> which described experiments showing oscillations of period ''h''/2''e'' in CDW (not normal electron) conductance versus magnetic flux through columnar defects in NbSe<sub>3</sub>. Later experiments, including some reported in 2012,<ref>{{cite journal|author1=M. Tsubota |author2=K. Inagaki |author3=T. Matsuura |author4=S. Tanda |title= Aharonov-Bohm effect in charge-density wave loops with inherent temporal current switching|journal=Europhysics Letters|year=2012|volume=97|issue=5|pages=57011|doi= 10.1209/0295-5075/97/57011|arxiv = 0906.5206 |bibcode = 2012EL.....9757011T |url=http://eprints.lib.hokudai.ac.jp/dspace/bitstream/2115/49114/2/EPL97%285%29_57011.pdf}}</ref> show oscillations in CDW current versus magnetic flux, of dominant period ''h''/2''e'', through TaS<sub>3</sub> rings up to 85 [[µm]] in circumference above 77 K. This behavior is similar to that of the superconducting quantum interference device (see [[SQUID]]), lending credence to the idea that CDW electron transport is fundamentally quantum in nature (see [[quantum mechanics]]).
==References==
===Cited references=== {{Reflist|30em}}
===General references=== * Grüner, George. ''Density Waves in Solids''. Addison-Wesley, 1994. {{ISBN|0-201-62654-3}} * Review of experiments as of 2013 by Pierre Monceau. [https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0929 ''Electronic crystals: an experimental overview''].
== See also == * [[Spin density wave]] * [[High-temperature superconductivity]]
[[Category:Superconductivity]] [[Category:Phases of matter]] [[Category:Condensed matter physics]]

{{context|date=March 2010}} A '''Domestic Energy Assessor (DEA)''' is an accredited position in the UK that is approved by the Ministry for Housing, Communities and Local Government (MHCLG). Under the UK's Energy Performance of Buildings Regulations, an [[Energy_Performance_Certificate_(United_Kingdom)|Energy Performance Certificate]] is required for the sale or rent of a domestic dwelling. DEAs are qualified and accredited for the production of RdSAP EPCs - these are specifically for use on existing buildings, which would include an dwelling built after 2008 which had already received an on-construction SAP EPC. As of November 2018, DEAs had produced 16,849,375 RdSAP EPCs since the inception of the industry.<ref>https://www.epcregister.com/lodgementStats.html</ref>
==Qualifications== "If you’re a DEA you must: * carry out energy efficiency assessments on existing dwellings only * collect data on the dimensions, construction, heating and hot water provision of the property and enter it into an approved software programme - Reduced Data Standard Assessment Procedure (RDSAP) * produce energy performance certificates (EPCs) for homes being marketed for sale, for other homes sold and for homes when rented."<ref>{{cite web|title=Domestic energy assessor for existing buildings accreditation (England and Wales) - GOV.UK|url=https://www.gov.uk/domestic-energy-assessor-existing-buildings|website=www.gov.uk|accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref>
==Importance of the role== Domestic energy assessors will be commissioned by householders or their agents to visit homes, initially those that are about to come onto the market. The owners will be obliged to make EPCs and advisory reports available to buyers, and later to tenants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206125409/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref> In this way, DEAs will be a key part of helping homebuyers, [[homeowner]]s and tenants contribute to the “green agenda”.<ref>{{cite web|title=Agent Green|url=http://www.agentgreen.co.uk/|website=www.agentgreen.co.uk|accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref> Research confirms that householders want to know about the energy efficiency of their homes, and about how they can make improvements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206125409/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref>
==Skills and knowledge== These are defined in the [[National Occupational Standards]] (NOS). The NOS are a specification of both the technical knowledge and the skills required to be a competent DEA They include a requirement to understand the legal background to the role, to possess relevant [[interpersonal skills]] and make accurate judgments consistently, aided by the [[software]], on the recommendations for cost effective improvement measures. They may be downloaded free of charge from the Asset Skills Energy Assessors website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206125409/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref>
==Training to achieve a qualification== DEA qualifications will be provided by three awarding bodies–the Awarding Body for the Built Environment (ABBE), [[City and Guilds of London Institute|City and Guilds]] and the [[National Association of Estate Agents]] (NAEA). Each will include a [[multiple choice]] examination and detailed assessment of not less than five EPCs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206125409/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref> Many providers in both the [[Public sector|public]] (usually [[Further education college|Further Education Colleges]]) and [[private sector]] are offering or planning to offer training to become a DEA. Professional bodies and private providers will also do the same, whilst larger companies will almost certainly provide the learning in-house. Asset Skills, awarding bodies and [[professional association]]s can all give advice about how to locate [[training]] relevant to your needs and where you live.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206125409/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref> The amount of training you require will depend on your current level of skills and knowledge–obviously much less for an experienced practitioner than someone entering the world of Energy Assessment and buildings for the first time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206125409/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref>
Some [[funding]] support may be available in certain circumstances–approach a local or regional [[Learning and Skills Council]] (LSC) or in Wales, the [[Welsh Assembly Government]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206125409/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref>
==After qualification== In order to practise, DEAs need to join an [[accreditation]] body. This will entail a check that the individual is fit and proper and a commitment to maintaining appropriate [[Professional indemnity|Professional Indemnity]], updating your skills and knowledge regularly ([[Continuing professional development|CPD]]), participating in the accrediting body’s [[quality assurance]] scheme, and abiding by their advice and guidance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206125409/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/housing/pdf/domesticenergyassessor.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref>
==Accreditation Schemes for DEAs== Domestic Energy Assessors are able to join any of the following accreditation schemes to be able to practice. Multiple registrations are common within the Industry. * ECMK * Elmhurst * Quidos * Sterling * Stroma * Bacra (Scottish only)
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Energy in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
[[File:Middle Marshyandi Hydro Electricity Dam Udipur.jpg|thumb|Middle Marshyandi Hydroelectricity Dam, [[Udipur]]]] [[Nepal]] had a total primary energy supply ([[TPES]]) of 10.29 [[tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]] in 2012.<ref name=iea2012 /> Electricity consumption was 3.57 [[TWh]]. Most of this primary energy (about 80%) represents solid biofuels used in the residential sector (for heating, cooking etc.).<ref name=iea2012>{{cite web|title=Nepal|url=http://www.iea.org/statistics/statisticssearch/report/?year=2012&country=Nepal&product=Balances|website=www.iea.org|publisher=International Energy Agency (IEA)|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref> About 23% of the electricity is imported, with the rest almost completely supplied by [[hydroelectricity]].
Nepal has no known major oil, [[natural gas|gas]], or [[coal]] reserves,<ref name=usaid /> and its position in the [[Himalayas]] makes it hard to reach remote communities. Consequently, most Nepali citizens have historically met their energy needs with biomass, human labor, imported kerosene, and/or traditional vertical axis water mills. Energy consumption per capita is thus low, at one-third the average for Asia as a whole and less than one-fifth of the world average. The country has considerable hydroelectricity potential. The commercially viable potential is estimated at about 44 GW from 66 hydropower sites.<ref name=usaid>{{cite web|title=Nepal|url=http://www.sari-energy.org/pagefiles/countries/nepal_energy_detail.asp|publisher=USAID South Asia Regional Initiative for Energy Integration (SARI/EI)|accessdate=16 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425173323/http://sari-energy.org/PageFiles/Countries/Nepal_Energy_detail.asp|archivedate=25 April 2012|df=}}</ref> In 2010, the electrification rate was only 53% (leaving 12.5 million people without electricity) and 76% depended on wood for cooking.
With about 1 [[tonne of oil equivalent|toe]] for every $1,000 of [[Gross domestic product|GDP]], Nepal has the poorest energy intensity among all south Asian countries. The country has therefore very large energy efficiency potential.<ref name=iea2012 />
==Oil products== [[Petroleum]] is the second largest energy fuel in Nepal after firewood and accounts for 11% of primary energy consumption in the country.<ref name=iea2012 /> All petroleum products are imported from [[India]]. At the moment, the import of petroleum products is transacted exclusively between the [[Nepal Oil Corporation]] and the [[Indian Oil Corporation]].<ref name=NOC>{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://www.nepaloil.com.np/About-Us/1/|publisher=Nepal Oil Corporation|accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref> 75% of the imports are [[diesel fuel|diesel]], [[kerosene]] and [[gasoline]]. Due to the high energy demand in the country, the dependence on petroleum imports is increasing. More than 62% of the petroleum products are used in the transportation sector. Besides that, petroleum products constitute important energy sources for cooking purposes in households.
==Biomass== [[biomass energy|Biomass]] is by far the most important primary energy source in Nepal. Biomass comprises wood, agricultural residues and dung. About 95% of the biomass is used for cooking and heating purposes in households.
==Biogas== Farming system in Nepal is heavily dependent on livestock, with at least 1.2 million households owning cattle and buffalo. The technical [[biogas]] potential is therefore high and is estimated to be at least one million household-size plants, 57 percent located in the Terai plains, 37 percent in the hills and 6 percent in remote hills.
According to Nepal's ''[[Alternative Energy Promotion Centre]]'', as of July 2011, 241,920 biogas plants were installed in more than 2,800 Village Development Committees and in all 75 Districts under their Biogas Support Program.<ref>{{cite web|title=Installed biogas plants|url=http://www.aepc.gov.np/?option=statistics&page=substatistics&mid=6&sub_id=49&id=4|publisher=Alternative Energy Promotion Centre (AEPC)|accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Energy conservation in Nepal]] *[[Renewable energy in Nepal]] *[[Nepal Electricity Authority]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Asia topic|Energy in}}
[[Category:Energy in Nepal|*]]

{{Infobox rockunit | name = Exmouth Plateau | period = | age = | image = Northern_Carnarvon_Basin.png | imagesize = 300px | caption = Image of the Northern Carnarvon Basin and other outlying structure on the coast of the Northwest Australian Margin | type = Extensional Passive Margin | prilithology = | otherlithology = | unitof = | subunits = | underlies = | overlies = | thickness = | area = | map = | map_caption = | location | coordinates = 19° 00'00" S, 114° 00'00" E | region = Northwestern Australia | country = Australia | extent = | namedfor = | namedby = | year_ts = | location_ts = | coordinates_ts = | paleocoordinates_ts = | region_ts = | country_ts = | thickness_ts = }} The '''Exmouth Plateau''' is an elongate northeast striking extensional passive margin located in the [[Indian Ocean]] roughly 3,000 meters offshore from western and [[North West Australia|northwestern]] [[Western Australia]]. The plateau makes up the westernmost structural unit of the [[Carnarvon Basin|Northern Carnarvon Basin]], which comprises the Exmouth, Barrow, Dampier, and Beagle Sub-basins, and the Rankin Platform.{{cite web|title=Regional Geology of the Northern Carnarvon Basin|website=Geoscience Australia|url=http://www.petroleum-acreage.gov.au/files/files/2013/documents/regional-geology/Regional_Geology-Northern_Carnarvon.pdf|accessdate=18 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150309082718/http://petroleum-acreage.gov.au/files/files/2013/documents/regional-geology/Regional_Geology-Northern_Carnarvon.pdf|archivedate=9 March 2015|df=}} The Exmouth Plateau was once a part of the northern shore of eastern of [[Gondwanaland]] until it broke away during Late [[Jurassic]] to Early [[Cretaceous]], leaving behind the [[oceanic crust]] of the Argo, Cuvier, and Gascoyne abyssal plains that now surround the distal margins of Exmouth Plateau.{{cite journal|last1=Exon|first1=N.F.|last2=Haq|first2=B.U.|last3=Rad|first3=U. von|title=Exmouth Plateau revisited: scientific drilling and geological framework|journal=Proceedings of the Ocean Drilling Program|date=1992|volume=122|pages=3–20|url=http://www-odp.tamu.edu/Publications/122_SR/VOLUME/CHAPTERS/sr122_01.pdf}} ==Tectonic history== [[File:Gondwana Distribution with Onycophora Distribution Superimposed.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Gondwana during the early Cretaceous]] In the Late [[Jurassic]], [[Gondwanaland]] begins to break apart creating Western Gondwana, which was composed of the South American and African continental land masses, and Eastern Gondwana. The Eastern Gondwanian continent was made Madagascar, Greater India, Antarctica, and Australia. During this period of time Australia shared its southern margin with Antarctica and the western margin (now the Exmouth Plateau) with Greater India.{{cite journal|last1=Görür|first1=N.|last2=Sengör|first2=A.M.C.|title=Paleogeography and tectonic evolution of the eastern Tethysides: implications for the northwest Australian margin breakup history|journal=Proceedings of Ocean Drilling Program, Scientific Results|date=1992|volume=122|pages=83–106}} The formation of the Exmouth's northern margin, the Argo Abyssal Plain, was not initiated until 155 million years ago when Australia broke apart from a continental fragment of the [[Burma plate]] that's present location is argued to be subsumed under Asia.{{cite journal|last1=Dewey|first1=J.F.|title=Lithospheric stress, deformation and tectonic cycles: the disruption of Pangea and the closure of Tethys|journal=geology society of london special publications|date=1988|volume=37|pages=23–40|doi=10.1144/GSL.SP.1988.037.01.03}} It wasn't until 20 million years later that the Greater Indian land mass broke from western Australia, forming the central and southern margins of the Exmouth Plateau now known as the Gascoyne and Cuvier Abyssal Plains.{{cite journal|last1=Fullerton|first1=Lawrence G.|last2=Sager|first2=William W.|last3=Handschumacher|first3=David W.|title=Late Jurassic-Early Cretaceous evolution of the eastern Indian Ocean adjacent to northwest Australia|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|date=1989|volume=94|issue=B3|pages=2937–2953|doi=10.1029/JB094iB03p02937}} As Australia continued to diverge away from the Antarctic land mass, it migrated in a northeastern direction and rotated counterclockwise to it present location, leaving the Exmouth Plateau along the continent's western margin. ===Late Triassic=== In the begin of the late [[Triassic]], high volumes of sediments accumulate off of the shoreline of western Australia to the northern extend of the Exmouth Plateau by the Mungaroo Deltas. The [[Carnian]] (237-228 Ma) to [[Norian]] (228-209 Ma) aged fluviodeltaic sediments deposited were siliciclastic claystones and sandstones, and detritus which would late make up the coals found in Mungaroo Formation. As extensional rifting between Greater Indian and the Australian continued, magmatic intrusion along the westernmost section of the Exmouth Plateau caused further rifting to the outer margins.{{cite journal|last1=Lorenzo|first1=Juan M.|last2=Mutter|first2=John C.|last3=Larson|first3=Roger L.|title=Development of the continent-ocean transform boundary of the southern Exmouth Plateau|journal=Geology|date=1991|volume=19|pages=843–846|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(1991)019<0843:DOTCOT>2.3.CO;2}} By the end of the Late Triassic (209-201 Ma) tectonic activity had relatively slowed down and less deltaic sediments were deposited compared to the [[Carnian]] and [[Norian]]. More marine sedimentary deposit such as carbonates are found during this time period.{{cite book|last1=Stagg|first1=H.M.J.|last2=Alcock|first2=M.B.|last3=Bernardel|first3=G.|last4=Moore|first4=A.M.G.|last5=Symonds|first5=P.A.|last6=Exon|first6=N.F.|title=Geological framework of the Outer Exmouth Plateau and adjacent ocean basins|publisher=Geoscience Australia Record|date=2013|orig-year=2004|isbn=192087108X}} ===Early Jurassic=== [[File:Exmouth Plateau tectonic model (mid-late Jurassic).png|thumb|500px|right|Diagram modeled after Mutter et al. (1989) depiction of the Middle to Late Jurassic extension]] During the early Jurassic, extension at the west Australian margin initiated simple shear mechanics creating a system of listric normal faults near the eastern region of the Exmouth Plateau.{{cite journal|last1=Mutter|first1=John C|last2=Larson|first2=Roger L.|title=Extension of the Exmouth Plateau, offshore northwestern Australia: Deep seismic reflection/refraction evidence for simple and pure shear mechanisms|journal=Geology|date=1989|volume=17|issue=1|pages=15–18|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(1989)017<0015:EOTEPO>2.3.CO;2}} These listric faults were a product from the development of a major low angle detachment fault between a sedimentary base of Permian-Triassic upper crust and the mid-crustal horizon.{{cite journal|last1=Wernicke|first1=B.|title=Low-angle normal faults in the Basin and Range province|journal=Nature|date=1981|volume=291|pages=645–648|doi=10.1038/291645a0}} As a result, brittle deformation and crustal thinning in the upper crust of the eastern Exmouth Plateau occurred, while in the west, the lower crystalline crust and lithosphere experienced shear stress and thinning. The formation of the fault system closer to the coast caused the initial development of the Exmouth, Barrow, and Dampier sub-basins of the Northern Carnarvon Basin. Carbonate marine sediment, primarily marls, continued to be deposited at this time on the central and western portions of the plateau. Closer to the shoreline siliciclastic mud and silt were deposited from marine and deltaic environments. ===Middle to late Jurassic=== [[File:Seismic cross section of Exmouth and Barrow sub-basins.png|thumb|right|400px|Seismic cross section northwest to southeast of the Barrow and Exmouth sub-basins]] As extension continued in the mid to late Jurassic, multiple [[pull-apart basin]]s and oblique right-lateral strike-slip faulting in the eastern margin of the Exmouth Plateau continued to dominate. The simple shear stress of the Exmouth detachment fault between the base of the upper crust, and the lower crust had been reduced in the east plateau. This reduction in simple shear was in part caused by the deformation that developed series negative flower structures and half-graben systems in the west plateau. By this time, the lithospheric thinning that had been initiated in during the early Jurassic was now considerably thinner. At this period, a magmatic intrusion between the lower crystalline crest and the lithosphere been introduce, underplating this region. ===Early Cretaceous=== In Early [[Cretaceous]], pure shear deformation at the ocean-continental boundary completed the final continental breakup and sea-floor spreading. By this time the overall structural morphology of the Exmouth Plateau had taken shape, aside from the post-breakup subsidence that occurred afterward from the Late Cretaceous to present day. Activity at the eastern Exmouth Plateau's detachment system had likely ceased which is reason for the completion of the plateau's morphology. == Sequence stratigraphy == === Locker Shale and Mungaroo Formation === {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="width:35%; text-align:center; font-size:100%; border:1.5px solid black" |- ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | [[Geological time scale|Period]] ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | [[Epoch (geology)|Epoch]] ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | Age ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | Formation |- | style="background:#9400D3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" align="center" rowspan="7" | [[Triassic]] | style="background:#9932CC; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" align="center" rowspan="3"| Late | style="background:#BAA3BF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Rhaetian]]
(209-201 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | Brigadier
Formation |- | style="background:#BAA3BF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Norian]]
(228-209 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" rowspan="3"| Mungaroo
Formation |- | style="background:#BAA3BF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Carnian]]
(237-228 Ma) |- | style="background:#BA55D3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" align="center" rowspan="2"| Middle | style="background:#ECCEF2; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" columnspan="2" | [[Ladinian]]
(241-237 Ma) |- | style="background:#ECCEF2; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Anisian]]
(247-241 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" rowspan="3" | Locker
Shale |- | style="background:#9370DB; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" align="center" rowspan="2"| Early | style="background:#FBE6FF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Olenekian]]
(250-247 Ma) |- | style="background:#FBE6FF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Induan]]
(252-250 Ma) |} The Locker Shale and Mungaroo formation are associated with the syn-rift and post-rift sequences of the Permian extension that occurred just prior to the late Triassic extension event across the northwestern margin of Australia. Lying atop unconformable unit of Paleozoic sediments, the Locker Shale is composed of marine sediments deposited in a transgressional environment during the Late Permian extension.{{cite journal|last1=Kopsen|first1=E.|last2=McGann|first2=G.|title=A review of the hydrocarbon habitat of the eastern and central Barrow-Dampier sub-basin, Western Australia|journal=APEA J.|date=1985|volume=25|pages=154–176}} These marine sediments were deposited at the base of the Late [[Triassic]] and continued up until the end of [[Anisian]] age when it transitioned in the Mungaroo Formation. The Mungaroo Formation is an intricate [[fluvial]] environment of meandering and braided stream deposits laid down in the [[Ladinian]] (~241 Mya) to [[Norian]] ages (~209 Mya) during the pre-rift active margin of the Northwestern Australian Shelf.{{cite journal|last1=Vos|first1=R.G.|last2=McHattie|first2=C.M.|title=Upper Triassic depositional environments, Central Exmouth Plateau (permit WA-84-P) Northwestern Australia|journal=Paper presented at 5th Australian Geological Convention|date=August 17–20, 1981}} It is one of the thickest formations in the region and becomes progressively thicker (approximately 3,000 m thick) in the distal portions of the Northern Carnarvon Basin furthest offshore.{{cite journal|last1=Cockbain|first1=A.E.|title=The North West Shelf|journal=APEA J.|date=1983|volume=29|pages=529–545}} One of the primary gas source for the Exmouth Plateau and Northern Carnarvon Basin, the Mungaroo Formation contains thick successions of [[siltstone]], [[sandstone]], and [[coal]].{{cite journal|last1=Barber|first1=P.|title=The Exmouth Plateau deepwater frontier: a case study|date=1988|issue=The North West Shelf, Australia: Proceedings of the Petroleum Exploration Society of Australia Symposium, Perth|pages=173–187}} === Brigadier Formation === The Mungaroo Formation is capped by thin transgressive sequence of shallow marine claystone and limestone called the Brigadier Formation. This is a much thinner formation than the Mungaroo laid down only for a short period of time between the beginning of the [[Rhaetian]] to the Early [[Hettangian]]. Do to the thickness of fluvial deltaic deposits from the Mungaroo Formation, the transgressional sequence of the Brigadier Formation is correlated with the [[subsidence]] of sub-basins across region during the Middle and Late [[Triassic]].{{cite journal|last1=Driscoll|first1=Neal W.|last2=Karner|first2=Garry d.|title=Lower crustal extension across the Northern Carnarvon basin, Australia: Evidence for an eastward dipping detachment|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|date=March 10, 1998|volume=103|pages=4975–4991|doi=10.1029/97jb03295}} === Dingo Claystones === {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="width:40%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; border:1.5px solid black" |- ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | [[Geological time scale|Period]] ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | [[Epoch (geology)|Epoch]] ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | Age ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | Lithologies |- | style="background:#4169E1; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="11" | [[Jurassic]] | style="background:#6495ED; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="4" | Late | style="background:#A3ACBF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Tithonian]] (145-152 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" | |- | style="background:#A3ACBF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Kimmeridgian]] (157-152 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="3"| Upper Dingo
Claystone |- | style="background:#A3ACBF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Oxfordian (stage)|Oxfordian]] (164-157 Ma) |- | style="background:#A3ACBF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Callovian]] (166-164 Ma) |- | style="background:#87CEEB; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="3"| Middle | style="background:#CEDAF2; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Bathonian]] (168-166 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="7"| Lower Dingo
Claystone |- | style="background:#CEDAF2; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Bajocian]] (170-168 Ma) |- | style="background:#CEDAF2; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Aalenian]] (174-170 Ma) |- | style="background:#B0E0E6; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="4"| Early | style="background:#E6EEFF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Toarcian]] (183-174 Ma) |- | style="background:#E6EEFF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Pliensbachian]] (191-183 Ma) |- | style="background:#E6EEFF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Sinemurian]] (199-191 Ma) |- | style="background:#E6EEFF; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Hettangian]] (201-199 Ma) |- |} The distribution of sediment packages throughout the Northern Carnarvon Basin and Exmouth Plateau varies with location during the Jurassic. By the [[Pliensbachian]], the general beginning structure of the Northern Carnarvon Basin was formed, creating the Exmouth, Barrow, and Dampier sub-basins along the proximal end of the northwestern Australian margin. Rapid subsidence of the Northern Carnarvon sub-basins ensued the deposition of the Dingo Claystones. These Claystones are thick marine shale deposits separated into two sequence, the Upper and Lower Dingo Claystones. The Lower Dingo sequence cannot be found in the Exmouth Plateau, because deposition During the Early to Middle [[Jurassic]] was restricted to sediments filling in the empty troughs of the Northern Carnarvon sub-basins.{{cite journal|last1=Colwell|first1=J.B.|last2=Röhl|first2=U.|last3=von Rad|first3=U.|last4=Kristan-Tollmann|first4=E.|title=Mesozoic sedimentary and volcaniclastic rocks dredged from the northern Exmouth Plateau and Rowley Terrace, offshore northwest Australia|journal=Journal of Australian Geology and Geophysics|date=1994|volume=15|issue=1|pages=11–42}} As deposition continued through the Middle and Late [[Jurassic]], the troughs of sub-basins filled allowing more of the Dingo sediment overflow into the distal margins of the region. This depositional sequence characterizes the Upper Dingo Claystones, which are found as thick proximal sequences in the Northern Carnarvon sub-basins and thinner distal sequences in the Exmouth Plateau. {{clear}} === Barrow Group === {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="width:40%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; border:1.5px solid black" |- ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | [[Geological time scale|Period]] ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | [[Epoch (geology)|Epoch]] ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | Age ! style="border:1.5px solid black" align="center" | Formation |- | style="background:#6B8E23; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="13" | [[Cretaceous]] | style="background:#008000; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="7" | Late | style="background:#3C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="2" | [[Maastrichtian]] (72.1-66.0 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" | Miria
Formation |- | style="border:1.5px solid black" | |- | style="background:#3C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Campanian]] (83.6-72.1 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="2" | Toolonga Calcilutite |- | style="background:#3C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Santonian]] (86.3-83.6 Ma) |- | style="background:#3C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Coniacian]] (89.8-86.3 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="2" | |- | style="background:#3C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Turonian]] (93.9-89.8 Ma) |- | style="background:#3C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Cenomanian]] (100-93.9 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="5" | Winning
Group |- | style="background:#228B22; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="6"| Early | style="background:#6C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Albian]] (100-113 Ma) |- | style="background:#6C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Aptian]] (126-113 Ma) |- | style="background:#6C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Barremian]] (131-126 Ma) |- | style="background:#6C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Hauterivian]] (134-131 Ma) |- | style="background:#6C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Valanginian]] (139-134 Ma) | style="border:1.5px solid black" rowspan="2" | Barrow
Group |- | style="background:#6C3; color:black; border:1.5px solid black" | [[Berriasian]] (145-139 Ma) |- |} During the late [[Tithonian]] to early [[Valanginian]] there were major changes in depositional patterns, specifically associated with the Barrow Group. At this period of time there was large uplift of the Cape Range Fracture Zone that provided sediments from the Barrow Delta prograde northward past Barrow Island and across the Exmouth Plateau. The sediments of the Barrow Group are composed of interbedded shale and fluvial-deltiac sands that were extensively deposited into Exmouth and Barrow sub-basins.{{cite journal|last1=Boyd|first1=R.|last2=Williamson|first2=P.|last3=Haq|first3=B.|title=Seismic stratigraphy and passive margin evolution of the Southern Exmouth Plateau|journal=Proceedings of the Ocean Drilling Program, Scientific Results|date=1992|volume=122|pages=39–59}} === Winning Group === Eventually, deposition of the Barrow Delta's sediment ceased during the early or middle [[Valanginian]] with due the continental break up at the southern margin of the Exmouth Plateau.{{cite journal|last1=Hocking|first1=R.M.|title=Carnarvon Basin: Geology and Mineral Resources of Western Australia|journal=Western Australia Geological Survey|date=1990|pages=457–495}} This was followed seafloor spreading at the Gascoyne and Cuvier Abyssal Plains and erosion at the surface of the Exmouth, Dampier and Barrow sub-basins and an unconformity to be position at the top of the early to middle [[Valanginian]]. By the middle to late [[Valanginian]] and through the [[Cretaceous]] major transgression occurred with deposit the Winning Group atop the [[Valanginian]] unconformity. The Winning Group consists of Muderong Shale, Windalia Radiolarite, and Gearle Siltsone. The Muderong Shale actually considered a siltstone and was deposited in a low energy, offshore-marine environment. The deposition of these sediments makes good seal for gas buildups in the Exmouth Plateau and the surrounding sub-basins of the Northern Carnvon Basin.{{cite journal|last1=Hocking|first1=R.M.|last2=Moors|first2=H.T.|last3=van de Graaff|first3=W.J.E.|title=Geology of the Carnarvon Basin Western Australia|journal=Geological Survey of Western Australia|date=1987}} The Windalia Radiolarite are primarily carbonate marine deposits commonly containing poorly preserved radiolarians and forminiferas. The Gearle Siltstone is a low-energy, offshore-marine deposit in a period of that input of the terrigenous sediments to the offshore was low minimal.{{cite journal|last1=Apthorpe|first1=M.C.|title=Depositional history of the upper Cretaceous of the Northwest Shelf, based on Foraminera|journal=Australian Petrolium Exploration Association Journal|date=1979|volume=19|issue=1|pages=74–89}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Indian Ocean]] [[Category:Geology of Western Australia]] [[Category:North West Shelf]]

[[File:Meteorology_thermodynamic_en.svg|thumb|Diagram showing an air parcel path when raised along B-C-E compared to the surrounding air mass Temperature (T) and humidity (Tw)]] In [[atmospheric sciences]], the '''free convective layer''' ('''FCL''') is the layer of conditional or [[potential instability]] in the [[troposphere]]. It is a layer of positive [[buoyancy]] (PBE) and is the layer where deep, moist convection (DMC) can occur. On an [[atmospheric sounding]], it is the layer between the [[level of free convection]] (LFC) and the [[equilibrium level]] (EL). The FCL is important to a variety of convective processes and to severe thunderstorm forecasting.
It is the layer of instability, the "positive area" on [[thermodynamic diagrams]] where an ascending [[air parcel]] is warmer than its environment. [[Integral|Integrating]] buoyant energy from the LFC to the EL gives the [[convective available potential energy]] (CAPE), an estimate of the maximum energy available to [[Atmospheric convection|convection]]. The depth of the FCL is expressed by the formula:
: FCL = Z<sub>EL</sub> - Z<sub>LFC</sub> or : FCL = P<sub>EL</sub> - P<sub>LFC</sub>
Deep, moist convection is essentially a [[thunderstorm]], it is [[cumulus congestus cloud]]s or [[cumulonimbus cloud]]s. An air parcel ascending from the near surface layer ([[mixed layer]] or [[planetary boundary layer|boundary layer]]) must [[work (thermodynamics)|work]] through the stable layer of [[convective inhibition]] (CIN) when present. This work comes from increasing instability in the low levels by raising the [[temperature]] or [[dew point]], or by mechanical lift. Without the aid of mechanical forcing, a parcel must reach its [[convective temperature]] (T<sub>c</sub>) before moist convection ([[cloud]]) begins near the [[convective condensation level]] (CCL}, whereas with dynamic lift, [[cloud base]] begins near the [[lifted condensation level]] (LCL). This will remain as shallow, moist convection (small [[cumulus cloud]]s) until breaking through the convective inhibition layer, after which DMC ensues as a parcel hits the LFC and enters the FCL, if thermal or mechanical forcing continues. At the level of neutral buoyancy (the EL), a parcel is cooler than the environment and is stable, so it slow down, eventually ceasing at the [[maximum parcel level]] (MPL).
== References == * Blanchard, David O. (Sep 1998). Assessing the Vertical Distribution of Convective Available Potential Energy. ''[[Weather and Forecasting]]'', 13 (3): 870–877.
== See also == * [[Atmospheric thermodynamics]] * [[Mixed layer]]
== External links == * [http://www.crh.noaa.gov/lsx/science/pdfppt/convective_indices.pdf Atmospheric indices] ([[National Weather Service]] St. Louis)

{{Distinguish|Harmankaya Nature Park}} {{Infobox protected area | name = Harmankaya Canyon Nature Park | alt_name = Harmankaya Kanyonu Tabiat Parkı | iucn_category = | photo = | photo_alt = | photo_caption = | photo_width = | map = Turkey | map_alt = | map_caption = Location of the nature park in Turkey. | map_width = | relief = yes | label_position = right | label= Harmankaya Canyon NP | location = [[Karahasanlar, Yenipazar]] and [[Harmanköy, İnhisar]] villages, [[Bilecik Province]], Turkey | nearest_city = | coordinates = {{coord|40|08|55|N|30|26|27|E|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = | area = {{cvt|260|ha}} | established = {{start date and age|2012|12|26}} | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = Directorate-General of Nature Protection and National Parks
[[Ministry of Environment and Forest (Turkey)|Ministry of Environment and Forest]] | world_heritage_site = | url = }} '''Harmankaya Canyon Nature Park''' ({{lang-tr|Harmankaya Kanyonu Tabiat Parkı}}) is a [[canyon]] in [[Bilecik Province]], western Turkey, which was declared a [[List of nature parks of Turkey|nature park]]. The canyon is located between [[Karahasanlar, Yenipazar|Karahasanlar]] village in [[Yenipazar, Bilecik|Yenipazar]] district and [[Harmanköy, İnhisar|Harmanköy]] village in [[İnhisar]] of Bilecik. Its distance to Karahasanlar village is {{cvt|7|km}} and to Harmanköy about {{cvt|4|km}}. The canyon's northern entrance is at an elevation of {{cvt|520|m}}, the southern entrance is at {{cvt|611|m}} while the elevation in the canyon mid measures about {{cvt|400|m}}. It is about {{cvt|3.9|km}} long, and its entrance is around {{cvt|5|m}} wide. The canyon cliffs are {{cvt|300|-| 600|m}} high. There are two waterfalls of about {{cvt|22|m}} height, and many others of {{cvt|1.5|-|2|m}} height. The area covering {{cvt|260|ha}} was declared as the country's 184th [[nature park]] by the [[Ministry of Environment and Forest (Turkey)|Ministry of Environment and Forest]] on December 26, 2012. The vegetation of the nature park consists of low trees and shrubs like [[oak]] (''Quercus''), [[juniper]] (''Juniperus''), [[rowan]] (''Sorbus''), terebinth (''[[Pistacia terebinthus]]''), [[willow]] (''Salix,'') and blackthorn (''[[Prunus spinosa]]''). == References == {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |url=http://bilecik.com.tr/?link=mekan_detay&mekan_id=122 |publisher=Bilecik |title=Harmankaya Kanyonu |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-07-28 }} {{cite news |url=http://www.sozcu.com.tr/2016/yazarlar/nasuh-mahruki/bilecikin-doga-harikasi-harmankoy-kanyonu-1359410/ |newspaper=[[Sözcü]] |title=Bilecik'in doğa harikası Harmanköy kanyonu |author=Mahruki, Nasuh |date=2016-08-21 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-07-28 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.bilecik.gov.tr/selalelerimiz |publisher=Bilecik Valiliği |title=Kanyon ve Şelalelerimiz |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-07-28 }} {{cite news |url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/hayat/harmankaya-kanyonu-tabiat-parki-ilan-edildi-1116630/ |newspaper=[[Radikal]] |title=Harmankaya Kanyonu, "Tabiat Parkı" ilan edildi |date=2013-01-13 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-07-28 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.milliparklar.gov.tr/anasayfa/resimlihaber/13-01-17/HARMANKAYA_KANYONU_184_TAB%C4%B0AT_PARKIMIZ_OLARAK_%C4%B0LAN_ED%C4%B0LD%C4%B0%E2%80%A6.aspx?sflang=tr |publisher=Doğa Koruma ve Milli Parklar Genel Müdürlüğü |title=Harmankaya Kanyonu 184.Tabiat Parkımız olarak İlan Edildi... |date=2013-01-17 |language=turkish |accessdate=2017-07-28 }} }} {{Canyons and gorges of Turkey}} {{Nature parks of Turkey}} [[Category:Canyons and gorges of Turkey]] [[Category:Landforms of Bilecik Province]] [[Category:Nature parks in Turkey]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Turkey]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Bilecik Province]] [[Category:Yenipazar District, Bilecik Province]] [[Category:İnhisar District]] {{Bilecik-geo-stub}}

revision.comment: The minor radius is not the entire width of the vacuum vessel, but half of it. Taken a vertical cross section of a tokamak, the minor radius is the distance (at midplane) between the center and the vessel wall.
