{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Fusion devices |name = JET |image = JointEuropeanTorus external.jpg |imagetitle = JET in 1991 |type = [[Tokamak]] |operation = 1984 – present |major radius = 2.96 m |minor radius = 1.25 m |volume = 100 m3 |field = 3.45 [[tesla (unit)|T]] (toroidal) |heating = 38 [[megawatt|MW]] |current = 3.2 MA (circular),
4.8 MA (D-shape) |location = [[Oxfordshire]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] }} '''JET''', the '''Joint European Torus''', is the world's largest operational [[Magnetic confinement fusion|magnetically confined]] [[Plasma (physics)|plasma physics]] experiment, located at [[Culham Centre for Fusion Energy]] in [[Oxfordshire]], [[United Kingdom|UK]]. Based on a [[tokamak]] design, the fusion research facility is a joint European project with a main purpose of opening the way to future [[nuclear fusion]] grid energy. JET was one of a number of tokamak reactors built in the early 1980s that tested new design concepts. It was one of only two designed to work with a real [[deuterium]]-[[tritium]] fuel mix, the other being the US-built [[Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor|TFTR]]. Both were built with the ultimate goal of reaching [[fusion energy gain factor|''scientific breakeven'']],{{sfn|Wesson|1999|p=25}} the point where the energy created by the fusion reactions is greater than the energy being fed into it to keep it hot. JET began operation in 1983 and spent most of the next decade increasing its performance in a lengthy series of experiments and upgrades. In 1991 the first experiments including [[tritium]] were made, making JET the first reactor in the world to run on the production fuel of a 50-50 mix of tritium and [[deuterium]]. In 1997, using this fuel, JET set the current world record for fusion output at 16 MW from an input of 24 MW of heating and a total input of 700-800 MW of electrical power. {{cite web |url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/faq/top-twenty-faq/how-much-power-is-needed-to-start-the-reactor-and-to-keep-it-working/ |title=How much power is needed to start the reactor and to keep it working? |website=EUROfusion}} This is also the world record for ''Q'', at 0.67. A ''Q'' of 1 is scientific breakeven, a point JET was not ultimately able to reach. JET was built by an international consortium, which formed the nucleus for the [[European Union]]'s contribution to the [[ITER|International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor]]. JET has been described as a "little ITER" as the designs are very similar in many ways.{{cite web |url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/jet/ |title=JET – A European joint venture |website=ITER}} In recent years, JET has been used to test a number of features from the ITER design. ==History== ===Background=== By the early 1960s, the fusion research community was in the "doldrums". Many initially promising experimental paths had all failed to produce useful results, and the latest experiments suggested performance was stalled out at the [[Bohm diffusion]] limit, far below what would be needed for a practical fusion generator.{{sfn|Bromberg| 1982|pp=130-131}} In 1968 the Soviets held the periodic meeting of fusion researchers in [[Novosibirsk]], where they introduced data from their [[T-3 tokamak]]. This represented a dramatic leap in fusion performance, at least 10 times what the best machines in the world had produced to that point. The results were so good that some dismissed them as faulty measurements. To counter this, the Soviets invited a team from the UK to independently test their machine. Their 1969 report confirmed the Soviet results, resulting in a "veritable stampede" of tokamak construction around the world.{{sfn|Bromberg|1982|pp=151}}{{sfn|Kenward|1979|p=627}} A key issue in tokamak designs was that they did not generate enough of an electrical current in their [[plasma (physics)|plasma]] to provide enough heating to bring the fuel to fusion conditions. Some sort of external heating would be required. There was no shortage of ideas for this, and in the mid-1970s a series of machines were built around the world to explore these concepts. One of these, the [[Princeton Large Torus]] (PLT) demonstrated that [[neutral beam injection]] was a workable concept, using it to reach record temperatures well over the 50 million K that is the minimum needed for a practical reactor.{{sfn|Kenward|1979|p=628}} With the PLTs success, the path to [[breakeven]] finally appeared possible after decades of effort. Breakeven is the point where the energy being given off by the fusion reactions is equal to the amount of energy used to run the reactor. Once breakeven is achieved, even small improvements from that point begin to rapidly increase the amount of net energy being released. Teams around the world began planning for a new generation of machines combining PLTs injectors with [[superconducting]] magnets and vacuum vessels that could hold [[deuterium]]-[[tritium]] fuel instead of the test fuels containing pure deuterium or [[hydrogen]] that had been used up to that point.{{sfn|Kenward|1979|p=630}} ===European design=== In 1971, the [[European Union|Council of the European Community]] decided in favour of a robust fusion programme and provided the necessary legal framework for a European fusion device to be developed.{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/world-leading-nuclear-fusion-project-threatened-by-brexit/ |title= Brexit brings nuclear (con)fusion |first=Sara |last=Stefanini |date=7 April 2017}} In 1975, the first proposals for the JET machine were completed. Detailed design took three years.{{cite web |url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/jet/history/jet’s-first-plasma/ |title=JET's first plasma |first= Paul-Henri |last=Rebut}} At the end of 1977, after a long debate, Culham was chosen as the host site for the new design. Funding was approved on 1 April 1978 as the "JET Joint Undertaking" legal entity.{{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/jet/history/about-jet%E2%80%99s-startup/|title=About JET's startup|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=9 December 2015}} The reactor was built at a new site next to the [[Culham Centre for Fusion Energy]], the UK's fusion research laboratory which opened in 1965. The construction of the buildings was undertaken by [[Tarmac Group|Tarmac Construction]],Berry Ritchie, ''The Story of Tarmac'' Page 100, Published by James & James (Publishers) Ltd, 1999 starting in 1978 with the Torus Hall. The Hall was completed in January 1982 and construction of the JET machine itself began immediately after the completion of the Torus Hall.{{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/jet/history/about-jet%E2%80%99s-startup/|title=About JET's startup|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=9 December 2015}} The cost was 198.8 Million European Units of Account (predecessor to the Euro){{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/?s=cost|title=You searched for cost – EUROfusion|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=9 December 2015}} or 438 million in 2014 US dollars.{{cite web |url=http://www.measuringworth.com/uscompare/relativevalue.php |title=Measuring Worth - Results |publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2015}} JET achieved its first plasma on 25 June 1983.{{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/jet/history/about-jet%E2%80%99s-startup/|title=About JET's startup|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=9 December 2015}} It was officially opened on 9 April 1984 by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]].{{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/2014/04/the-opening-of-jet-1984/|title=The Opening of JET 1984|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=26 June 2016 }} On 9 November 1991, JET performed the world's first deuterium-tritium experiment.{{Cite journal|title=The JET preliminary tritium experiment|journal=Plasma Physics and Controlled Fusion|volume=34|issue=13|pages=1749–1758|doi = 10.1088/0741-3335/34/13/002|year = 1992|last1 = Rebut|first1 = P-H}} This beat the US's machine, TFTR, by a full two years.{{cite web |url=http://www.pppl.gov/news/2013/12/celebrating-20th-anniversary-tritium-shot-heard-around-world-2 |title=Celebrating the 20th anniversary of the tritium shot heard around the world |date=9 December 2013 |website=PPPL }} ===Upgrades=== Although very successful, JET and its counterpart TFTR failed to reach breakeven. This was due to a variety of effects that had not been seen in previous machines operating at lower densities and pressures. Based on these results, and a number of advances in plasma shaping and diverter design, a new tokamak layout emerged, sometimes known as an "advanced tokamak". An advanced tokamak capable of reaching breakeven would have to be very large and very expensive, which led to the international effort [[ITER]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20060824071609/http://www.efda.org/the_iter_project/index.htm The ITER project]. EFDA, European Fusion Development Agreement (2006). In the early 1990s, it was decided to add such a diverter design to JET, which occurred between 1991 and 1993. Performance was significantly improved, allowing JET to set many records in terms of confinement time, temperature and [[fusion triple product]]. It set the record for the closest approach to breakeven, reaching ''Q'' = 0.67 in 1997, producing 16 MW of fusion energy while consuming 24 MW to heat the fuel.{{cite web |url=https://www.iter.org/sci/BeyondITER |title=Milestones around the world |website=ITER}} This is also the record for greatest fusion power produced.{{cite web |url=http://www.ccfe.ac.uk/JET.aspx |title=JET |website=Culham Centre for Fusion Energy}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ccfe.ac.uk/jet.aspx|title=JET|publisher=Culham Centre Fusion Energy|accessdate=26 June 2016}} In 1998 JET's engineers developed a remote handling system with which, for the first time, it was possible to exchange certain components using artificial hands only. A "Remote Handling" system is, in general, an essential tool for any subsequent fusion power plant and especially for the [[International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor]] (ITER). This Remote Handling system was later to lead on to become [[RACE (Remote Applications in Challenging Environments)]].{{cite web |url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/fusion/jet-remote-handling/how-we-do-remote-handling-at-jet/|title=How we do Remote Handling at JET?|website=EUROfusion |accessdate=26 June 2016}} In 1999, the [[European Fusion Development Agreement]] (EFDA) was established with responsibility for the future collective use of JET.{{cite web|url=http://www-sen.upc.es/becasyofertas/EFDA_English.pdf|title=What is EFDA|publisher=Seccio D'Enginyeria Nuclear|accessdate=26 June 2016}} JET operated throughout 2003, with the year culminating in experiments using small amounts of [[tritium]].{{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/newsletter/jet-returns-to-operation-with-tritium/|title=JET returns to operation with Tritium|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=26 June 2016}} ===ITER design work=== In October 2009, a 15-month shutdown period was started to rebuild many parts of the JET to test concepts from the ITER design. This including replacing [[carbon]] components in the vacuum vessel with [[tungsten]] and [[beryllium]] ones.{{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/newsletter/the-iter-like-wall-project-at-jet/|title=The ITER-like Wall Project at JET|website=EUROfusion |accessdate=26 June 2016}} Heating power was also increased by 50%, bringing the neutral beam power available to the plasma up to 34MW, and diagnostic and control capabilities were improved. In total, over 86,000 components were changed in the torus during the shutdown. In mid-May 2011, the shutdown reached its end.{{cite web |url=http://www.efda.org/2011/05/week-81-shutdown-finished/ |title=JET Shutdown Weekly: Week 81: Shutdown finished! |website=EUROfusion|date=13 May 2011 |accessdate=11 December 2011}} The first experimental campaign after the installation of the “ITER-Like Wall” started on 2 September 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.efda.org/2011/09/world%E2%80%99s-largest-fusion-experiment-back-in-operation/ |title=World's largest fusion experiment back in operation|website=EUROfusion |date=2 September 2011 |accessdate=11 December 2011}} On 14 July 2014, the European Commission signed a contract worth €283m for another 5-year extension so more advanced higher energy research can be performed at JET.{{cite web |url=http://horizon2020projects.com/policy-research/contract-for-joint-european-torus-signed/ |title=Contract for Joint European Torus signed|publisher=Horizon 2000 projects |accessdate=14 July 2014}} Under this plan, a new run of deuterium-tritium experiments, a “dress rehearsal” for ITER, would be carried out in 2019.{{cite web |url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/jet/research/ |website=EUROfusion|title=Funded and used in partnership|accessdate=26 November 2017}} ===Future=== [[Brexit]] has thrown the plans for JET in doubt. As part of their plan to leave the EU, the UK will also leave Euratom, which provides the funding for JET.{{cite web|title=EUROfusion and UK after Brexit|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/2016/06/eurofusion-and-uk-after-brexit/|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=26 June 2016}} Talks on the funding after 2018, when the current 5-year plan expires, were underway and a new agreement to extend JET's operation until 2019 or 2020 appeared to be largely complete. These talks were put on hold after the Brexit announcement, and are currently stalled pending the Brexit outcome. == Description == [[File:JointEuropeanTorus internal.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Internal view of the JET tokamak superimposed with an image of a plasma taken with a [[visible spectrum]] video camera.]] JET has a major radius of 3 meters, and the D-shaped vacuum chamber is 2.5 meters wide and 4.2 meters high.{{sfn|Wesson|1999|p=26}} The total plasma volume within it is 100 cubic meters, about 100 times larger than the largest machine in production when the JET design began.{{sfn|Wesson|1999|p=21}} JET was one of the first tokamaks to be designed to use a D-shaped vacuum chamber. This was initially considered as a way to improve the safety factor, but during the design, it was also noticed that this would make it much easier to build the system mechanically, as it reduced the net forces across the chamber that are trying to force the torus towards the center of the major axis. Ideally, the magnets surrounding the chamber should be more curved at the top and bottom and less on the inside and outsides in order to support these forces, which leads to something like an oval shape that the D closely approximated. The flatter shape on the inside edge was also easier to support due to the larger, flatter surface.{{sfn|Wesson|1999|p=22}} While exploring the stability of various plasma shapes on a computer, the team noticed that non-circular plasmas did not exactly cancel out the vertical drift that the twisted fields have originally been introduced to solve. If the plasma was displaced up or down, it would continue travelling in that direction. However, the simulations demonstrated that the drift rate was slow enough that it could be counteracted using additional magnets and an electronic feedback system.{{sfn|Wesson|1999|p=26}} The primary magnetic field in a tokamak is supplied by a series of magnets ringing the vacuum chamber. In JET, these are a series of 32 copper-wound magnets, each one weighing 12 tonnes. In total, they carry a current of 51 MA, and as they had to do so for periods of tens of seconds, they are water cooled. When operating, the coil is attempting to expand with a force of 6 [[Newton (unit)|MN]], there is a net field towards the center of the major axis of 20 MN, and a further twisting force because the poloidal field inside the plasma is in different directions on the top and bottom. All of these forces are borne on the external structure.{{sfn|Wesson|1999|p=31}} Surrounding the entire assembly is the 2,600 tonne eight-limbed transformer which is used to [[magnetic induction|induce]] a current into the plasma. The primary purpose of this current is to generate a poloidal field that mixes with the one supplied by the toroidal magnets to produce the twisted field inside the plasma. The current also serves the secondary purpose of ionizing the fuel and providing some of the heating while the plasma before other systems take over.{{sfn|Wesson|1999|p=32}} The main source of heating in JET is provided by two systems, neutral beam injection and ion cyclotron resonance heating. The former uses small [[particle accelerator]]s to shoot fuel atoms into the plasma, where collisions cause the atoms to ionize and become trapped with the rest of the fuel. These collisions deposit the kinetic energy of the accelerators into the plasma. Ion cyclotron resonance heating is essentially the plasma equivalent of a [[microwave oven]], using [[radio wave]]s to pump energy into the ions directly by matching their [[cyclotron frequency]]. JET was designed so it would initially be built with a few megawatts of both sources, and then later be expanded to as much of 25 MW of neutral beams and 15 MW of cyclotron heating.{{sfn|Wesson|1999|pp=32-33}} JET's power requirements during the plasma pulse are around 500 MW{{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/2011/10/775-tons-of-steel/|title=775 tons of steel|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=9 December 2015}} with peak in excess of 1000 MW. Because power draw from the main grid is limited to 575 MW, two large [[Flywheel energy storage|flywheel generator]]s were constructed to provide this necessary power. Each 775-ton flywheel can spin up to 225 rpm and store 3.75 GJ.{{cite web |url=http://www.efda.org/2010/03/week-20-jet-experiments-sensitive-to-tv-schedules/ |title=Week 20: JET Experiments: sensitive to TV schedules|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=26 June 2016 }} Each flywheel uses 8.8 MW to spin up and can generate 400 MW (briefly).{{cite web|url=https://www.euro-fusion.org/fusion/jet-tech/jets-flywheels/|title=Power supply|website=EUROfusion|accessdate=9 December 2015}} ==See also== {{Portal box|Nuclear technology|Energy}} * [[Fusion power]] * [[ITER]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite book |first=Joan Lisa |last=Bromberg |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ECOvgg7b3MQC |title=Fusion: Science, Politics, and the Invention of a New Energy Source |publisher=MIT Press |date=1982 |isbn=978-0-262-02180-7 |ref=harv}} * {{cite magazine |magazine=New Scientist |title=Fusion research - the temperature rises |first=Michael |last=Kenward |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=tbhTdnZsqMUC&pg=PA626 |date=24 May 1979|ref=harv}} * {{cite book |url=http://www.euro-fusionscipub.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/JETR99013.pdf |title=The Science of JET |page=20 |first=John |last=Wesson |date=November 1999 |publisher=JET Joint Undertaking |ref=harv}} ==External links== * [http://www.efda.org/JET JET pages on the EURO''fusion'' web site] ** [https://www.euro-fusion.org/glossary/poloidal-field-coils/ Poloidal field coils] diagram ** [https://www.euro-fusion.org/2005/10/jet-demonstrates-alpha-particle-heating/ JET demonstrates alpha particle heating. Oct 2005] good graph * [http://www.ccfe.ac.uk Culham Centre for Fusion Energy] * [http://www.uk-atomic-energy.org.uk The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071121222134/http://www.iaea.or.at/inis/ws/d1/r133.html IAEA's information about JET] * [http://skippy.org.uk/jet-torus-hall/ Photos from JET Torus Hall] ===Sources=== * [http://science.howstuffworks.com/fusion-reactor.htm Fusion reactors explained by HowStuffWorks] * [http://www.iop.org/EJ/toc/0029-5515/39/11Y T. Fujita, et al., "High performance experiments in JT-60U reversed shear discharges", ''Nuclear Fusion'', Vol 39, Page 1627 (1999)] {{Coord|51|39|33|N|1|13|35|W|region:GB_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=title}} {{fusion experiments}} {{Major Scientific Research Facilities based in the United Kingdom}} [[Category:Energy in the European Union]] [[Category:Fusion power]] [[Category:Fusion reactors]] [[Category:Plasma physics]] [[Category:Tokamaks]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox astronomical survey}} [[File:Neo-chart.png|thumb|260px|Number of [[near-Earth object|NEO]]s detected by various projects: {| style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: 8px;" |- | valign=top width=50% | {{legend2|#0000FF|border=1px solid #0000B3|'''LINEAR'''}}
{{legend2|#FFA500|border=1px solid #B37400|[[Near Earth Asteroid Tracking|NEAT]]}}
{{legend2|#FF0000|border=1px solid #800000|[[Spacewatch]]}}
{{legend2|#FFFF00|border=1px solid #B3B300|[[LONEOS]]}} | valign=top | {{legend2|#008B00|border=1px solid #003D00|[[Catalina Sky Survey|CSS]]}}
{{legend2|#9400D3|border=1px solid #390052|[[Pan-STARRS]]}}
{{legend2|#00CCCC|border=1px solid #333|[[NEOWISE]]}}
{{legend2|#993300|border=1px solid #333|[[List of near-Earth object observation projects|All others]]}} |} ]] The '''Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research''' ('''LINEAR''') project is a collaboration of the [[United States Air Force]], [[NASA]], and the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]]'s [[Lincoln Laboratory]] for the systematic detection and tracking of [[near-Earth object]]s. LINEAR was responsible for the majority of [[asteroid]] discoveries from 1998 until it was overtaken by the [[Catalina Sky Survey]] in 2005. {{As of|2011|9|15|url=http://www.ll.mit.edu/mission/space/linear/}}, LINEAR had detected 231,082 new [[small Solar System bodies]], of which at least 2,423 were [[near-Earth asteroid]]s and 279 were [[comet]]s. The instruments used by the LINEAR program are located at [[Lincoln Laboratory's Experimental Test Site]] (ETS) on the [[White Sands Missile Range]] (WSMR) near [[Socorro, New Mexico]]. == History == In the late 1970s, the new ''Lincoln Laboratory's Experimental Test Site'' facility ([[Lincoln Laboratory's Experimental Test Site|Lincoln Lab ETS]], observatory code [[IAU code#700–799|704]]) was built at White Sands Missile Range. The project's prototype used low-light video cameras. In 1994 a new proposal was made for automated detection of asteroids, this time using newer digital detector technology. The LINEAR project began operating a [[near-Earth object]] discovery facility in 1996 using a {{Convert|1.0|m|in|abbr=on}} [[aperture]] [[telescope]] designed for the [[Air Force Space Command]]'s [[Ground-based Electro-Optical Deep Space Surveillance]] (GEODSS). The wide-field Air Force telescopes were designed for optical observation of Earth-orbiting spacecraft. Initial field tests used a 1024 × 1024 [[pixel]] [[charge-coupled device]] (CCD) detector. While this CCD detector filled only about one fifth of the telescope's [[field of view]], four near-earth objects were discovered. A 1960 × 2560 pixel CCD which covered the telescope's two-[[square degree]] field of view was then installed, and both detectors were used in later tests. The first LINEAR telescope became fully operational in March 1998. Beginning in October 1999, a second 1.0 m telescope was added to the search effort. In 2002, a {{Convert|0.5|m|in|abbr=on}} telescope equipped with the original CCD was brought on-line to provide follow-up observations for the discoveries made by the two search telescopes. This allowed about 20% more of the sky to be searched each night. Data recorded by the telescopes is sent to a Lincoln Laboratory facility at [[Hanscom Air Force Base]] in [[Lexington, Massachusetts]] for processing. Detections are then forwarded to the [[Minor Planet Center]]. == Discoveries == {{See also|Category:Discoveries by LINEAR}} {| class="wikitable floatright" style="font-size: 0.9em; width: 270px;" |+ [[Minor planet]]s discovered: 147,707  |- | ''see {{section link|List of minor planets|Main index}}'' |} In addition to discovering more than 140,000 [[minor planet]]s, LINEAR is also credited with the discovery, or co-discovery, or rediscovery of several periodic comets, including [[11P/Tempel–Swift–LINEAR]], [[158P/Kowal-LINEAR]], [[160P/LINEAR]] (LINEAR 43), [[165P/LINEAR]] (LINEAR 10), and [[176P/LINEAR]] (LINEAR 52, 118401 LINEAR: one of only five objects classified both as comets and [[asteroid]]s). Other objects discovered include {{Mpl|(137108) 1999 AN|10}}, {{Mpl|(179806) 2002 TD|66}}, and [[2004 FH]]. == See also == * [[EURONEAR]] * [[List of comets discovered by the LINEAR project]] * {{section link|List of minor planet discoverers|Discovering dedicated institutions}} * [[Minor Planet Center]] * [[Planetary Data System]] == References == {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |title=NEO Discovery Statistics |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/stats/ |publisher=NASA Near Earth Object Program |accessdate=2012-01-19}} {{cite web |title=MIT Lincoln Laboratory: LINEAR |url=http://www.ll.mit.edu/mission/space/linear/ |publisher=MIT Lincoln Laboratory |accessdate=2012-01-19}} {{cite web |url=http://www.ll.mit.edu/mission/space/linear/ETS.html |title=LINEAR – Experimental Test Site |publisher=Lincoln Laboratory, MIT |accessdate=3 November 2016}} {{cite journal |bibcode=1980STIN...8112143B |title=Artificial satellites, minor planets, and the ETS |author1=Beatty |first1=D. E. |last2=Sorvari |first2=J. M. |last3=Taff |first3=L. G. |volume=81 |date=1980 |pages=12143 |journal=Unknown}} {{cite journal |bibcode=1981PASP...93..658T |title=A new asteroid observation and search technique |author1=Taff |first1=L. G. |volume=93 |date=1981 |pages=658 |journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific |doi=10.1086/130905}} {{cite journal |doi=10.1117/12.176813 |title=Applying electro-optical space surveillance technology to the detection of near-Earth asteroids |journal=Proceedings of SPIE |date=1994 |last1=Tennyson |first1=Peter D. |last2=Rork |first2=Eugene W. |last3=Kostishack |first3=Daniel F. |volume=2198 |pages=1286|series=Instrumentation in Astronomy VIII }} {{cite web |title=Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research (LINEAR) |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/programs/linear.html |publisher=NASA Near Earth Object Program |accessdate=2012-01-19}} {{cite journal |bibcode=1998DPS....30.1607S |title=Results from the Lincoln Near Earth Asteroid Research (LINEAR) Project |author1=Stokes |first1=G. H. |last2=Viggh |first2=H. E. M. |last3=Shelly |first3=F. L. |last4=Blythe |first4=M. S. |last5=Stuart |first5=J. S. |volume=30 |date=1998 |pages=1042 |journal=American Astronomical Society }} {{cite journal |bibcode=1999AAS...19510801E |title=A Progress Report on the Lincoln Near Earth Asteroid Research Project |author1=Elowitz |first1=R. M. |last2=Stokes |first2=G. H. |last3=Bezpalko |first3=M. |last4=Blythe |first4=M. S. |last5=Evans |first5=J. B. |last6=Pearce |first6=E. C. |last7=Sayer |first7=R. W. |last8=Shelly |first8=F. C. |last9=Viggh |first9=H. E. M. |volume=195 |date=1999 |pages=1531 |journal=American Astronomical Society }} {{cite journal |bibcode=2002AAS...20113003S |title=LINEAR Search and Operations Experience |author1=Stokes |first1=G. H. |last2=Evans |first2=J. B. |last3=Shelly |first3=F. C. |volume=201 |date=2002 |pages=1315 |journal=American Astronomical Society }} {{cite web |title = Minor Planet Discoverers (by number) |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/lists/MPDiscsNum.html |date = 12 January 2017 |accessdate = 2 February 2017}} }} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.ll.mit.edu/LINEAR}} * [https://www.ll.mit.edu/publications/journal/pdf/vol11_no1/11_1linear.pdf The Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research (LINEAR) Program] Grant H. Stokes, Frank Shelly, Herbert E.M. Viggh, Matthew S. Blythe, and Joseph S. Stuart * [http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/stats/ Near Earth Object program – discovery statistics], Jet Propulsion Laboratory {{Comets}} {{Planetary defense}} [[Category:1996 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Discoveries by LINEAR|*]] [[Category:Near-Earth object tracking]]

revision.text:
{{about|SSSIs in Suffolk|other counties|List of SSSIs by Area of Search}} [[File:Lackford Lakes, Suffolk, England-25July2010.jpg|300px|thumb|View over a pond from a bird hide at [[Lackford Lakes]]|alt=Lackford Lakes]] Suffolk is a county in [[East Anglia]]. It is bounded by [[Norfolk]] to the north, [[Cambridgeshire]] to the west, [[Essex]] to the south and the [[North Sea]] to the east. With an area of {{convert|1,466 |mi2|km2}}, it is the eighth largest county in England,{{cite web |url=https://www.britishservices.co.uk/suffolk.htm |title=Suffolk |publisher=British Services |accessdate=20 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508161754/http://www.britishservices.co.uk/suffolk.htm |archivedate=8 May 2016 |df=}} and in mid-2016 the population was 745,000.{{cite web |url=https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland |title=Population Estimates for UK, England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland: Mid 2016 |publisher=Office for National Statistics |accessdate=20 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215062115/https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland |archivedate=15 February 2017 |df=}} At the top level of local government is [[Suffolk County Council]], and below it are seven borough and district councils: [[Babergh]], [[Forest Heath]], [[Ipswich]], [[Mid Suffolk]], [[Borough of St Edmundsbury|St Edmundsbury]], [[Suffolk Coastal]] and [[Waveney District|Waveney]].{{cite web |url=https://www.suffolk.gov.uk/council-and-democracy/borough-district-parish-and-town-councils/ |title=Borough, District, Parish and Town Councils |publisher=Suffolk County Council |accessdate=20 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160527160959/http://www.suffolk.gov.uk/council-and-democracy/borough-district-parish-and-town-councils/ |archivedate=27 May 2016 |df=}} Much of the coast consists of the estuaries of the [[River Orwell|Orwell]], [[River Stour, Suffolk|Stour]], [[River Alde|Alde]], [[River Deben|Deben]] and [[River Blyth, Suffolk|Blyth]] rivers, with large areas of wetlands and marshes. Agriculture and shipping play a major role in the county's economy. In England, [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) are designated by [[Natural England]], a [[non-departmental public body]] which is responsible for protecting England's natural environment. Designation as an SSSI gives legal protection to the most important wildlife and geological sites.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation |publisher=Natural England |title=Sites of Special Scientific Interest: Designation |accessdate=19 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306231551/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation |archivedate=6 March 2016 |df=}} As of October 2017 there are 142 SSSIs in Suffolk,{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=40&responsiblePerson= |title=Designated Sites View: Suffolk |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=17 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906131701/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=40&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=6 September 2017 |df=}} of which 109 are biological, 28 geological and 5 are designated under both criteria. One site is in the [[Dedham Vale]], an [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] (AONB), and thirty-six are in another AONB, [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths]]. There are thirty-three [[Geological Conservation Review]] sites, twenty-three [[Nature Conservation Review]] sites, twenty [[Special Areas of Conservation]], thirty [[Special Protection Area]]s under the [[European Union]] [[Birds Directive|Directive on the Conservation of Wild Birds]], eight [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]] internationally important wetland sites, seven [[National Nature Reserve (United Kingdom)|National Nature Reserve]]s and 4 contain [[Scheduled Monument]]s. Six sites are [[Local Nature Reserve]]s, twenty-seven are managed by the [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]], five by the [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] and one by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]. The largest is [[Breckland Forest]] at {{convert|18,126|ha|acre|adj=on}}, which is partly in Norfolk and has several invertebrates on the [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]],{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000443.pdf |title=Breckland Forest citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508223510/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000443.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2014 |df=}} and the smallest is a {{convert|0.1|ha|acre|adj=on}} meadow in [[London Road Industrial Estate, Brandon]], which has the largest known wild population in Britain of the nationally rare [[Asteraceae|sunflower]] ''[[Artemisia campestris]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003798.pdf |title=London Road Industrial Estate, Brandon citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232029/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003798.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} {{geogroup}} ==Key== {{col-begin}} classifications=== *'''DVAONB''' = [[Dedham Vale]], an [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] *'''GCR''' = [[Geological Conservation Review]] *'''LNR''' = [[Local Nature Reserve]] *'''NCR''' = {{gbmappingsmall| TL 930 721}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002285}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002285.pdf Citation] |This is ancient [[coppice with standards]] on clay soil with diverse herb flora. The most common trees are [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]], [[field maple]] and [[Corylus avellana|hazel]], with many [[Quercus robur|oak]] standards. Flora include [[early purple orchid]], [[Anemone nemorosa|wood anemone]] and [[Viola reichenbachiana|pale wood violet]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002285.pdf |title=Bangrove Wood, Ixworth citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219032108/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002285.pdf |archivedate=19 December 2013 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Barking Woods]] | [[File:Barking Woods at Titley Hill - geograph.org.uk - 314714.jpg|100px|alt=Barking Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 98.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002317&SiteName=barking&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Barking Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=17 May 2017}} | align="center"|PP | [[Ipswich]]

Birds found on open heathland include [[stone-curlew]]s, a protected species, and [[wheatear]]s. Six species of lichen and eight of moss have been recorded.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002331.pdf |title=Barnham Heath citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=19 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201436/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002331.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bawdsey Cliff]] | [[File:Martello Tower and an inverted Pillbox by the very eroded cliffs at East Lane, Bawdsey - geograph.org.uk - 65839.jpg|100px|alt=Bawdsey Cliff]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 17.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002355&SiteName=bawdsey&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bawdsey Cliff |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Felixstowe]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TM 149 414}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=599 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Bobbits Hole (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813224938/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=599 |archivedate=13 August 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1002321}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002321.pdf Citation] |This is the [[Type locality (geology)|type locality]] for the warm [[Ipswichian]] [[interglacial]] around 130,000 to 115,000 year ago. It has yielded continuous deposits from the end of the preceding [[Wolstonian]] cold stage to the end of the Ipswichian. It is described by [[Natural England]] as a "nationally important [[Pleistocene]] reference site".{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002321.pdf |title=Bobbitshole, Belstead citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=13 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140318163149/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002321.pdf |archivedate=18 March 2014 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bradfield Woods]] | [[File:Path through Bradfield Woods - geograph.org.uk - 1451867.jpg|100px|alt=Bradfield Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 81.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002447&SiteName=bradfield&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bradfield Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.18|0.82 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bradfield Woods}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 930 576 }} |[[National Nature Reserve|NNR]],{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/suffolks-national-nature-reserves/suffolks-national-nature-reserves |title=Suffolk's National Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425070202/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/suffolks-national-nature-reserves/suffolks-national-nature-reserves |archivedate=25 April 2017 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006020&SiteName=bradfield&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bradfield Woods |series=National Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/bradfieldwoods |title=Bradfield Woods |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170513164332/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/bradfieldwoods |archivedate=13 May 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1002447}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002447.pdf Citation] |These woods have a history of [[coppicing]] dating to before 1252, producing a very high diversity of flora, with over 370 plant species recorded. Uncommon woodland flowers include [[oxlip]], [[herb paris]] and [[ramson]]. There is also a rich variety of fungi, with two species not recorded elsewhere in Britain.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002447.pdf |title=Bradfield Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195841/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002447.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Breckland Farmland]] | [[File:Private farm track at Tuddenham - geograph.org.uk - 207870.jpg|100px|alt=Breckland Farmland]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 13,392.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000442&SiteName=breckland&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breckland Farmland |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.4|0.6 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Breckland Farmland }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 796 852}} |[[special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|2000442}}{{efn|name=norfolk}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000442.pdf Citation] |The site is designated an SSSI for its internationally important population of [[Eurasian stone-curlew|stone-curlews]]. These birds nest in March on bare ground in cultivated land with very short vegetation. Fields with sugar beet and vegetables and no recreational disturbance are preferred.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000442.pdf |title=Breckland Farmland citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508223127/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000442.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2014 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Breckland Forest]] | [[File:Wangford Warren - geograph.org.uk - 514541.jpg|100px|alt=Breckland Forest]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|18,126.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000443&SiteName=breckland&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breckland Forest |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224631/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000443&SiteName=breckland&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=20 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|PP | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord| 52.4|0.7|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Breckland Forest}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 822 872}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2261 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Beeches Pit, Icklingham (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=601 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=High Lodge (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[local nature reserve|LNR]],{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1138 |title=Barton Mills Valley |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=26 March 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051851/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1138 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df=}} [[special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|2000443}}{{efn|name=norfolk}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000443.pdf Citation] |The forest has breeding [[Woodlark]]s and [[nightjar]]s in internationally important numbers, and several nationally rare vascular plants and invertebrates on the [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. There are also geological sites which provide evidence of the environmental and human history of East Anglia during the [[Middle Pleistocene]]. |- ! scope="row"|[[Brent Eleigh Woods]] | [[File:Lane approaching Langley Wood - geograph.org.uk - 724743.jpg|100px|alt=Brent Eleigh Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|31.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003121&SiteName=brent&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Brent Eleigh Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord|52.09|0.83 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Brent Eleigh Woods}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 938 473}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003121}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003121.pdf Citation] |This site consists of three separate areas, Spragg’s, Langley and Camps Woods. They are ancient woodland on [[calcareous]] clay soils. The main trees are [[Quercus robur|oak]] and [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]], and there are ponds and a stream.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003121.pdf |title=Brent Eleigh Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003355/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003121.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Buckanay Farm Pit, Alderton]] | [[File:Buckanay Farm Pit, Alderton 2.jpg|100px|alt=Buckanay Farm Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003206&SiteName=buckanay&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Buckanay Farm Pit, Alderton |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.03|1.433 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Buckanay Farm Pit, Alderton }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 356 424 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=3128 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Buckanay Farm, Alderton (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1003206}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003206.pdf Citation] | This fossiliferous site exposes rocks of the marine [[Red Crag Formation]], with a [[megaripple]] sequence showing the gradual reduction in depth of the sea.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003206.pdf |title=Buckanay Farm Pit, Alderton citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003314/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003206.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} The Red Crag spans the end of the [[Pliocene]] around 2.6{{nbsp}}million years ago and the start of the succeeding [[Pleistocene]].{{cite book |editor1-first=Patrick J. |editor1-last=Brenchley |editor1-link= |editor2-last=Rawson|editor2-first=Peter F. |title=The Geology of England and Wales |edition=2nd |year=2006 |publisher=The Geological Society |isbn=1-86239-200-5 |pages=432–434}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bugg's Hole Fen, Thelnetham]] | [[File:Bugg's Hole Fen 2.jpg|100px|alt=Bugg's Hole Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 3.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003517&SiteName=bugg&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bugg's Hole Fen, Thelnetham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Thelnetham]]
{{coord|52.373|0.944 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bugg's Hole Fen, Thelnetham }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 005 791 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003517}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003517.pdf Citation] |This [[calcareous]] fen in the valley of the [[River Little Ouse]] has a range of habitats. Fen grassland has flora such as [[grass of parnassus]] and [[bog pimpernel]], there are [[southern marsh orchid]] and [[marsh pennywort]] in marsh grassland, and spring-fed tall fen has [[lesser water parsnip]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003517.pdf |title=Bugg's Hole Fen, Thelnetham citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232156/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003517.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Burgate Wood]] | [[File:Burgate Wood - geograph.org.uk - 311597.jpg|100px|alt=Burgate Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 29.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002377&SiteName=burgate&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Burgate Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Burgate]]
{{coord|52.34|1.045 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Burgate Wood}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 075 757}} |[[Scheduled Monument|SM]]{{cite web |url=https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1016699 |title=Medieval Ringwork in Burgate Wood |publisher=Historic England |accessdate=4 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1002377}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002377.pdf Citation] |This is ancient [[coppice with standards]] [[Quercus robur|oak]] and [[Carpinus betulus|hornbeam]] woodland. The flora is diverse, including the rare [[Pulmonaria officinalis|lungwort]] and the uncommon [[herb paris]], [[yellow archangel]] and [[hairy woodrush]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002377.pdf |title=Burgate Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003330/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002377.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|C}}[[Cavendish Woods]] | [[File:Kings wood - geograph.org.uk - 832117.jpg|100px|alt=Cavendish Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|53.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003179&SiteName=cavendish&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Cavendish Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord|52.11|0.61 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Cavendish Woods}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 791 495 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003179}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003179.pdf Citation] |These ancient woods are managed as [[coppice with standards]]. The main standard tree is oak, and the flora is diverse, including the uncommon [[oxlip]]. There are many [[fallow deer]], and breeding birds include [[woodcock]], [[snipe]] and [[treecreeper]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003179.pdf |title=Cavendish Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504194234/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003179.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cavenham–Icklingham Heaths]] | [[File:River Lark at Turf Fen - geograph.org.uk - 641356.jpg|100px|alt=Cavenham – Icklingham Heaths]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 419.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000992&SiteName=cavenham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Cavenham–Icklingham Heaths |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.33|0.57 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Cavenham–Icklingham Heaths }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 751 732 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', pp. 132–133 [[national Nature Reserve|NNR]],{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006032&SiteName=cavenham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Cavenham Heath |series=National Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 May 2017}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1000992}} |[https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232048/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000992.pdf Citation] |This site has habitats of heath and grassland, with smaller areas of woodland and fen, in the flood-plain of the [[River Lark]]. It is described by [[Natural England]] as of national importance for its invertebrate species, including some which are rare and endangered, and it also has nationally rare flora and nationally scarce [[bryophyte]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000992.pdf |title=Cavenham – Icklingham Heaths citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232048/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000992.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cherry Hill and The Gallops, Barton Mills]] | [[File:Cherry Hill and the Gallops 9.jpg|100px|alt=Cherry Hill and The Gallops]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 10.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003217&SiteName=CHERRY&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Cherry Hill and The Gallops, Barton Mills |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=11 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord| 52.318|0.526|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Cherry Hill and The Gallops, Barton Mills }}

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 287 758 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1000958}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000958.pdf Citation] |This unimproved grassland on [[calcareous]] clay soil has grasses including [[meadow foxtail]], [[sweet vernal grass]] and [[red fescue]]. Diverse flowering plants include [[cuckoo flower]]s and a large population of [[green-winged orchid]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000958.pdf |title=Chippenhall Green citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003809/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000958.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Combs Wood]] | [[File:Footpath in Combs Wood.jpg|100px|alt=Combs Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 15.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003286&SiteName=combs&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Combs Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Stowmarket]]
{{coord|52.171|1.004 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Combs Wood}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 055 568 }} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/combs-wood |title=Combs Wood |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024093507/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/combs-wood |archivedate=24 October 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1003286}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003286.pdf Citation] |This is ancient coppice woodland on [[boulder clay]], with variable quantities of sand and [[loess]] resulting in different soil types. Grassy rides and a pond provide additional habitats for invertebrates.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003286.pdf |title=Combs Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003740/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003286.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cornard Mere]] | [[File:Cornard Mere - geograph.org.uk - 859971.jpg|100px|alt=Cornard Mere]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 8.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003307&SiteName=cornard&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Cornard Mere, Little Cornard |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord|52.016|0.75 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Cornard Mere, Little Cornard}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 888 389}} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/cornard-mere |title=Cornard Mere |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403162257/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/cornard-mere |archivedate=3 April 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1003307}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003307.pdf Citation] |This site has diverse habitats, with fen which is seasonally flooded, [[Ruderal species|ruderal]] herb vegetation, woodland, grassland and scrub. Flora include [[water mint]], [[gypsywort]], [[Scutellaria galericulata|skullcap]], [[ragged robin]] and [[southern marsh orchid]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003307.pdf |title=Cornard Mere citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232348/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003307.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Corton Cliffs]] | [[File:Corton Cliffs 3.jpg|100px|alt=Corton Cliffs]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 5.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002283&SiteName=corton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Corton Cliffs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Lowestoft]]
{{coord|52.509|1.75 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Corton Cliffs}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 546 967 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=590 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Corton (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1002283}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002283.pdf Citation] |This is described by [[Natural England]] as a "nationally important" site, as it is the [[Type locality (geology)|type locality]] for the [[Anglian stage|Anglian glaciation]] around 450,000 years ago. The Anglian was the most extreme [[ice age]] of the [[Pleistocene]] epoch. The site displays the complete Anglian sequence and its relation to the preceding [[Cromerian stage]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002283.pdf |title=Corton Cliffs citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225210/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002283.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Crag Farm Pit, Sudbourne]] | [[File:Crag Farm Pit, Sudbourne 1.jpg|100px|alt=Crag Farm Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|4.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003330&SiteName=crag%20farm&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Crag Farm Pit, Sudbourne |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=21 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.116|1.545 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Crag Farm Pit, Sudbourne}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 428 523 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=515 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Crag Farm, Sudbourne (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1003330}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003330.pdf Citation] |This site dates to the early [[Pliocene]], around four million years ago. It is described by [[Natural England]] as an important geological site, which has the best exposure of sandwave [[facies]] of the [[Coralline Crag Formation]]. Fossils of many [[bryozoan]] species are present.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003330.pdf |title=Crag Farm Pit, Sudbourne citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=21 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504200624/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003330.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Crag Pit, Aldeburgh]] | [[File:Crag Pit, Aldeburgh 3.jpg|100px|alt=Crag Pit, Aldeburgh]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001612&SiteName=crag%20pit&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Crag Pit, Aldeburgh |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=29 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829080757/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001612&SiteName=crag%20pit&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=29 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|NO |[[Aldeburgh]]
{{coord|52.165|1.593 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Crag Pit, Aldeburgh}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 458 580}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=510 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Crag Pit Nursery, Aldeburgh (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829080757/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=510 |archivedate=29 August 2017 |df=}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1001612}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001612.pdf Citation] |This is the most northern site which exposes the [[Pliocene]] [[Coralline Crag Formation]], which dates to around five million years ago. It has rich and diverse fossils, including many [[bryozoan]]s, and other fauna include [[serpulid]]s and several boring forms.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001612.pdf |title=Crag Pit, Aldeburgh citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=29 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003633/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001612.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Crag Pit, Sutton]] | [[File:Crag Pit, Sutton 3.jpg|100px|alt=Crag Pit, Sutton]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 0.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003459&SiteName=crag%20pit&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Crag Pit, Sutton |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.06|1.379 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Crag Pit, Sutton}}
