Herbs include the uncommon [[mossy stonecrop]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003459.pdf |title=Crag Pit, Sutton citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232152/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003459.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cransford Meadow]] | [[File:Cransford Meadow 2.jpg|100px|alt=Cransford Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 4.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003356&SiteName=cransford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Cransford Meadow |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.225|1.398 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Cransford Meadow}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 322 640}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003356}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003356.pdf Citation] |This unimproved meadow has a rich variety of flora. There are grasses such as [[Agrostis stolonifera|creeping bent]], [[meadow foxtail]], [[sweet vernal-grass]], [[Cynosurus cristatus|crested dog's tail]], [[perennial rye-grass]] and [[rough-stalked meadow-grass]]. It is one of only two sites in the county for [[ladies mantle]] ''[[Alchemilla filicaulis vestita]]''. |- ! scope="row"|[[Creeting St Mary Pits]] | [[File:Creeting St Mary Pits 5.jpg|100px|alt=Creeting St Mary Pits]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 5.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003154&SiteName=creet&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Creeting St Mary Pits |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730223134/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003154&SiteName=creet&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|PP |[[Ipswich]]
{{coord|52.157|1.063 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Creeting St. Mary Pits}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 096 554 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2049 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Creeting St Mary Pits (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730223643/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2049 |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1003154}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003154.pdf Citation] |These former quarries are the [[type locality (geology)|type site]] for the 'Creeting Sands', which are believed to be intertidal and shallow marine deposits from an early [[Pleistocene]] [[interglacial]]. It is described by [[Natural England]] as a key stratigraphic site.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003154.pdf |title=Creeting St Mary Pits citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231754/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003154.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|D}}[[Deadman's Grave, Icklingham]] | [[File:The Larches - geograph.org.uk - 276058.jpg|100px|alt=Deadman's Grave, Icklingham]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 127.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003389&SiteName=deadman&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Deadman's Grave, Icklingham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017}} | align="center"|PP | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.34|0.61 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Deadman's Grave, Icklingham }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 779 742 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 133 [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1003389}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003389.pdf Citation] |According to [[Natural England]], this site "is largely covered by short, sheep-grazed, species-rich calcareous grassland of the very highest value." It has four nationally rare plants, [[Silene otites|Spanish catchfly]], [[Phleum phleoides|Boehmer's cat's-tail]], [[Thymus serpyllum|Breckland Wild Thyme]] and [[Veronica verna|spring speedwell]]. Nationally rare [[stone-curlew]]s breed there.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003389.pdf |title=Deadman's Grave, Icklingham citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232106/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003389.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Deben Estuary]] | [[File:Footpath by River Deben, Suffolk - geograph.org.uk - 72634.jpg|100px|alt=Deben Estuary]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 981.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006262&SiteName=deben&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Deben Estuary |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.04|1.35 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Deben Estuary}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 296 434 }} |[[Ramsar site|Ramsar]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/RIS/UK11017.pdf |title=Information Sheet on Ramsar Wetlands (RIS): Deben Estuary |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812024554/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/ris/uk11017.pdf |archivedate=12 August 2017 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK11017&SiteName=deben&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Deben Estuary |series=Ramsar Site |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829080756/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK11017&SiteName=deben&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=29 August 2017 |df=}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/SPA/UK9009261.pdf |title=Special Protection Areas under the EC Birds Directive. Deben Estuary. |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315172410/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/SPA/UK9009261.pdf |archivedate=15 March 2016 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK9009261&SiteName=deben&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Deben Estuary |series=Special Protection Area |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829080756/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK9009261&SiteName=deben&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=29 August 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1006262}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006262.pdf Citation] |The site has been designated an SSSI for its overwintering [[wader]]s and [[wildfowl]], and for its diverse saltmarshes. It has internationally important numbers of overwintering [[Common redshank|redshank]]s and nationally important of [[Brant (goose)|dark-bellied brent geese]], [[Tadorna tadorna|shelducks]] and [[black-tailed godwit]]s. The estuary also has three nationally rare plants and a nationally rare mollusc.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006262.pdf |title=Deben Estuary citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232647/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006262.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Dew's Ponds]] | [[File:Dew's Ponds 4.jpg|100px|alt=Dew's Ponds]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 6.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000434&SiteName=dew&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Dew's Ponds |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Halesworth]]
{{coord|52.293|1.502 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Dew's Ponds}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 389 719 }} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0030133 |title=Dew`s Ponds |series=Special Areas of Conservation |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422025149/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/protectedsites/sacselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0030133 |archivedate=22 April 2016 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0030133&SiteName=dew&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Dew's Ponds |series=Special Area of Conservation |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|2000434}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000434.pdf Citation] |This site has a variety of types of grassland, hedges and ditches, on chalk overlain by [[boulder clay]]. However, it has been designated an SSSI primarily because it has twelve ponds with one of the largest breeding populations of [[great crested newt]]s in Britain. There are also [[grass snake]]s, [[smooth newt]]s and [[slowworm]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000434.pdf |title=Dew's Ponds citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304004120/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000434.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|E}}[[Edwardstone Woods]] | [[File:Footpath To Cowper's Wood - geograph.org.uk - 542176.jpg|100px|alt=Edwardstone Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|27.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003467&SiteName=edwardst&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Edwardstone Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord| 52.046|0.819|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Edwardstone Woods }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 934 424 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003467}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003467.pdf Citation] |These are ancient [[coppice with standards]] woods, which are mainly ash, maple and hazel, but there are large stands of [[Carpinus betulus|hornbeam]] and [[Tilia cordata|small-leaved lime]] in some areas. The diverse ground flora is typical of Suffolk [[boulder clay]] soils.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003467.pdf |title=Edwardstone Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504202140/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003467.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Elmsett Park Wood]] | [[File:Elmsett Park Wood 2.jpg|100px|alt=Elmsett Park Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|8.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003481&SiteName=elmse&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Elmsett Park Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731044047/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003481&SiteName=elmse&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=31 July 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|NO | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord|52.077|1.012 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Elmsett Park Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 065 464 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003481}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003481.pdf Citation] |This [[coppice with standards]] site has diverse woodland types and ground flora. Plants indicative of ancient woodland include [[nettle-leaved bellflower]], [[wood spurge]], [[Platanthera chlorantha|butterfly orchid]] and the uncommon [[spurge laurel]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003481.pdf |title=Elmsett Park Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003318/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003481.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Eriswell Low Warren]] | [[File:Eriswell Low Warren.jpg|100px|alt=Eriswell Low Warren]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 7.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001157&SiteName=eriswell&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Eriswell Low Warren |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord| 52.384|0.554|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Eriswell Low Warren}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 739 793 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', pp. 133–134 [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001157}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001157.pdf Citation] |The site is mainly unimproved acidic grassland on sandy soils, which has a variety of typical [[Breckland]] flora, and there are also areas of [[lichen]]s and [[bryophyte]]s. Rare plants include [[purple-stem cat's-tail]], [[spring speedwell]], [[Spanish catchfly]] and [[perennial knawel]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001157.pdf |title=Eriswell Low Warren citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232543/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001157.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|F}}[[Fakenham Wood and Sapiston Great Grove]] | [[File:Fakenham Wood - geograph.org.uk - 219909.jpg|100px|alt=Fakenham Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 200.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003499&SiteName=FAKENHAM&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Fakenham Wood and Sapiston Great Grove |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.36|0.83 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Fakenham Wood and Sapiston Great Grove}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 928 773}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003499}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003499.pdf Citation] |These two [[coppice with standards]] woods comprise one of the largest areas of ancient woodland in the county. The ground flora is dominated by bracken and bramble, but there are also rides which provide habitats for butterflies, including the largest colony of [[Limenitis camilla|white admirals]] in Suffolk.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003499.pdf |title=Fakenham Wood and Sapiston Great Grove citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201231/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003499.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ferry Cliff, Sutton]] | [[File:Ferry Cliff, Sutton 2.jpg|100px|alt=Ferry Cliff]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|2.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002346&SiteName=ferry&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Ferry Cliff, Sutton |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 June 2017}} | align="center"|FP | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.089|1.324 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ferry Cliff, Sutton }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 278 486 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1286 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Ferry Cliff (Tertiary Mammalia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1002346}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002346.pdf Citation] |This site exposes rocks dating to the [[paleocene]], around 60 million years ago. It has the oldest British fossils of [[rodent]]s, and [[ungulate]]s, both [[Even-toed ungulate|even]] and [[Odd-toed ungulate|odd toed]]. It also has early ''[[hyracotherium]]s''.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002346.pdf |title=Ferry Cliff, Sutton citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232132/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002346.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Flixton Quarry]] | [[File:Flixton Quarry 1.jpg|100px|alt=Flixton Quarry]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002306&SiteName=flixton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Flixton Quarry |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Bungay]]
{{coord|52.423|1.367 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Flixton Quarry }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 290 859}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=598 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Flixton Quarry (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1002306}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002306.pdf Citation] |This site has sands and gravels which are thought to be a glacial outwash dating to the most extreme [[ice age]] of the [[Pleistocene]] epoch, the [[Anglian stage|Anglian glaciation]] around 450,000 years ago. It is described by [[Natural England]] as important because of its relationship with deposits of the succeeding [[Hoxnian Stage]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002306.pdf |title=Flixton Quarry citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055930/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002306.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Fox Fritillary Meadow]] | [[File:Fox Fritillary Meadow 3.jpg|100px|alt=Fox Fritillary Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 2.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002429&SiteName=fox+&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Fox Fritillary Meadow, Framsden |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Stowmarket]]
{{coord|52.2|1.202 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Fox Fritillary Meadow, Framsden }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 189 606 }} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/fox-fritillary-meadow |title=Fox Fritillary Meadow |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=2 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428100030/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/fox-fritillary-meadow |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1002429}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002429.pdf Citation] |This unimproved meadow is located on heavy [[alluvial]] soils at the bottom of a valley. It has a rich variety of flora, including the herbs [[Primula veris|cowslip]], [[cuckooflower]] and [[ragged robin]], together with the largest population in [[East Anglia]] of the rare [[Fritillaria meleagris|snake's head fritillary]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002429.pdf |title=Fox Fritillary Meadow citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003233/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002429.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Foxhole Heath]] | [[File:Foxhole Heath - geograph.org.uk - 924932.jpg|100px|Foxhole Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 85.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004145&SiteName=foxhole&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Foxhole Heath, Eriswell |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord| 52.37|0.55|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Foxhole Heath }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 736 781}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 135 [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1004145}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004145.pdf Citation] |The heath is mainly covered by lichens and mosses, with smaller areas of heather and grassland. Much of it is grazed by rabbits. There are three nationally rare plants, and one rare bird, the [[stone-curlew]]: over one percent of this species in Britain breed on the site, and they also use it as a gathering ground for their autumn migration.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004145.pdf |title=Foxhole Heath, Eriswell citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716135441/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004145.pdf |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Freston and Cutler's Woods with Holbrook Park]] | [[File:Cutlers Wood - geograph.org.uk - 384151.jpg|100px|Cutler's Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 142.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004157&SiteName=FRESTON&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Freston and Cutler's Woods with Holbrook Park |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Ipswich]]
{{coord|52.01|1.14 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Freston and Cutler's Woods with Holbrook Park }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 153 388 }} |[[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1004157}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004157.pdf Citation] |These ancient woods have woodland types typical of spring-fed valleys and light sandy soils. Holbrook Park has [[Living stump|coppice stools]] over 3 metres in diameter, among the largest in Britain. [[Sweet chestnut]], which was introduced in the [[Middle Ages]], is found widely, and other trees include the rare [[wild service tree]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004157.pdf |title=Freston and Cutler's Woods with Holbrook Park citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504202117/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004157.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Frithy and Chadacre Woods]] | [[File:Frithy Wood.JPG|100px|alt=Frithy Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 28.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001098&SiteName=frithy&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Frithy and Chadacre Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220070419/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001098 |archivedate=20 December 2016 |df=}} | align="center"|YES |[[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord| 52.15|0.72|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Frithy and Chadacre Woods }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 859 536 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1001098}} |[https://web.archive.org/web/20131016120417/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001098.pdf Citation] |These are ancient semi-natural woods of the wet [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] and [[acer campestre|maple]] type. The diverse ground flora includes [[early purple orchid]], [[Listera ovata|twayblade]], [[Lithospermum officinale|gromwell]] and [[Hyacinthoides non-scripta|bluebell]].{{cite web |url=https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001098.pdf |title=Frithy and Chadacre Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016120417/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001098.pdf |archivedate=16 October 2013 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|G}}{{sortname|The |Gardens, Great Ashfield|The Gardens, Great Ashfield}} | [[File:The Gardens, Great Ashfield 4.jpg|100px|alt=The Gardens, Great Ashfield]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 3.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005772&SiteName=ashfield&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: The Gardens, Great Ashfield |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.274|0.927 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=The Gardens, Great Ashfield }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 998 680 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1005772}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005772.pdf Citation] |These ancient meadows are traditionally managed by grazing and cutting for hay. They have a rich variety of flora, such as [[green-winged orchid]], [[Ophrys apifera|bee orchid]], [[common twayblade]], [[pepper saxifrage]], [[adder's tongue fern]] and [[ox-eye daisy]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005772.pdf |title=The Gardens, Great Ashfield citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003416/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005772.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Gedgrave Hall Pit]] |[[File:Gedgrave Hall Pit 1.jpg|100px|alt= Gedgrave Hall Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|0.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004178&SiteName=gedgrave&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Gedgrave Hall Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=21 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord| 52.083|1.509|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Gedgrave Hall Pit}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 405 485 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=514 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Gedgrave Hall (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1004178}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004178.pdf Citation] |The site consists to two pits dating to the early [[Pliocene]] [[Coralline Crag Formation]]. The smaller pit has many well-preserved mollusc fossils, whereas those in the larger pit are highly abraded and poorly preserved.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004178.pdf |title=Gedgrave Hall Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=21 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504194938/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004178.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Gipping Great Wood]] | [[File:Gipping Great Wood - geograph.org.uk - 388442.jpg|100px|alt=Gipping Great Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 25.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004186&SiteName=gipping&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Gipping Great Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Stowmarket]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TM 075 624}} | |{{Nature on the map|1004186}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004186.pdf Citation] |This is an ancient [[coppice with standards]] wood with a variety of woodland types. There are many hornbeams, and other trees include oak and ash. Wet rides, a pond and a stream provide additional ecological interest.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004186.pdf |title=Gipping Great Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504193928/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004186.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Glemsford Pits]] | [[File:Glemsford Pits 10.JPG|100px|alt=Glemsford Pits]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|33.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003050&SiteName=GLEMSFORD&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Glemsford Pits |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 May 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord| 52.085|0.681|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Glemsford Pits}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 838 463 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003050}}{{efn|name=essex|This site is partly in Essex}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003050.pdf Citation] |Thirteen species of dragonfly and damselfly have been recorded in these former gravel workings, including one which is rare in Britain, the [[ruddy darter]] dragonfly. Aquatic plants include the [[Nuphar lutea|yellow water-lily]] and [[Hippuris vulgaris|mare's tail]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003050.pdf |title=Glemsford Pits citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=17 May 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222611/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003050.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{sortname|The |Glen Chalk Caves, Bury St Edmunds|The Glen Chalk Caves, Bury St Edmunds}} | [[File:The Glen Chalk Caves 2.jpg|100px|alt=The Glen Chalk Caves]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|1.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003555&SiteName=chalk%20caves&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: The Glen Chalk Caves, Bury St Edmunds |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017}} | align="center"|PP | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.248|0.729 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=The Glen Chalk Caves, Bury St Edmunds }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 864 646 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003555}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003555.pdf Citation] |Tunnels totalling 200 metres in length radiate from a chalk pit, which also contains a disused lime kiln. The tunnels and kiln are used by five species of bat for hibernation, and the surrounding vegetation helps to maintain a suitable micro-climate in the caves. The principal species are [[Daubenton's]], [[Natterer's]] and [[brown long-eared bat]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003555.pdf |title=The Glen Chalk Caves, Bury St Edmunds citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201259/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003555.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Gosbeck Wood]] | [[File:Gosbeck Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1333729.jpg|100px|alt=Gosbeck Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 22.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004201&SiteName=GOSBECK&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Gosbeck Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Ipswich]]
{{coord|52.159|1.134 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Gosbeck Wood}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 145 556}} | |{{Nature on the map|1004201}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004201.pdf Citation] |This is an ancient [[coppice with standards]] wood mainly on [[boulder clay]], with some areas of sandy soil. [[Dog's mercury]] is dominant in the ground flora, and other plants include [[spurge laurel]], [[wood spurge]], [[herb paris]] and [[hairy woodrush]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004201.pdf |title=Gosbeck Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504194055/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004201.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Great Blakenham Pit]] | [[File:Great Blakenham Pit 1.jpg|100px|alt=Great Blakenham Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004221&SiteName=blaken&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Great Blakenham Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731044040/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004221&SiteName=blaken&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=31 July 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|NO | [[Great Blakenham]]
{{coord| 52.107|1.087|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Great Blakenham Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 115 499}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=602 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Great Blakenham (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731024810/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=602 |archivedate=31 July 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1004221}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004221.pdf Citation] |This is described by [[Natural England]] as a key site for [[Pleistocene]] studies. It has a sequence of [[Early Pleistocene|early]] and [[middle Pleistocene]] deposits, including from the ancient course of the [[Ancestral Thames|River Thames]] through [[East Anglia]], and from the severe [[Anglian stage|Anglian ice age]] around 450,000 years ago.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004221.pdf |title=Great Blakenham Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504200302/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004221.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Gromford Meadow]] | [[File:Gromford Meadow, Snape cropped.jpg|100px|alt=Gromford Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 1.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004234&SiteName=gromford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Gromford Meadow |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=21 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Saxmundham]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 386 587 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1004234}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004234.pdf Citation] |This unimproved [[base-rich]] meadow is fed by springs. It has diverse flora with [[meadowsweet]] dominant, and other plants include [[yellow rattle]], [[meadow foxtail]], [[ragged robin]], [[marsh thistle]] and [[lesser spearwort]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004234.pdf |title=Gromford Meadow citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=21 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003640/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004234.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Groton Wood]] | [[File:GrotonWood May2010.jpg|100px|alt=Groton Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 20.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004249&SiteName=groton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Groton Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord|52.051|0.882 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Groton Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 977 431 }} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/groton-wood |title=Groton Wood |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428060547/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/groton-wood |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1004249}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004249.pdf Citation] |Fifteen species of butterfly have been recorded in this wood, including [[Gonepteryx rhamni|brimstones]], [[Speckled wood (butterfly)|speckled woods]] and [[purple hairstreak]]s. There are many [[Prunus avium|wild cherry trees]], and twenty-two seasonal ponds, which have scarce and protected [[great crested newt]]s. |- ! scope="row"|[[Gypsy Camp Meadows, Thrandeston]] | [[File:Gypsy Camp Meadows, Thrandeston 1.jpg|100px|alt=Gypsy Camp Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 2.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001862&SiteName=gypsy&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Gypsy Camp Meadows, Thrandeston |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=2 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Diss]]
{{coord|52.353|1.101 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Gypsy Camp Meadows, Thrandeston }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 113 773}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001862}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001862.pdf Citation] |These wet meadows on poorly drained [[boulder clay]] have a rich variety of flora, and drainage ditches, areas of drier grassland and hedges add to the diversity. Plants include [[early purple orchid]], [[ragged robin]], [[zig-zag clover]] and [[water avens]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001862.pdf |title=Gypsy Camp Meadows, Thrandeston citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=2 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201221/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001862.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|H}}[[Hascot Hill Pit]] | [[File:Hascot Hill Pit 2.jpg|100px|alt=Hascot Hill Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004308&SiteName=hascot&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hascot Hill Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731045618/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004308&SiteName=hascot&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=31 July 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|NO |[[Stowmarket]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 060 537 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=3127 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Hascot Hill Pit, Battisford (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731025139/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=3127 |archivedate=31 July 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1004308}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004308.pdf Citation] |This is the only known site to expose beach deposits of the late [[Pliocene]] and early [[Pleistocene]] [[Red Crag Formation]]. It has beach cobbles and fossils from a [[littoral]] fauna, whereas other Red Crag sites have deposits from deeper water [[facies]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004308.pdf |title=Hascot Hill Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232328/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004308.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hay Wood, Whepstead]] | [[File:Hay Wood, Whepstead 5.jpg|100px|alt=Hay Wood, Whepstead]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 10.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002701&SiteName=whepstead&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hay Wood, Whepstead |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Bury St Edmunds]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TL 809 578 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1002701}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002701.pdf Citation] |This ancient wood on poorly drained [[boulder clay]] has [[coppice]] trees of [[small-leaved lime]] and [[field maple]] with an understorey of hazel. {{gbmappingsmall| TM 063 433}} |[[RSPB]],{{cite web |url=https://www.rspb.org.uk/reserves-and-events/find-a-reserve/reserves-a-z/reserves-by-name/w/wolveswood/ |title=Wolves Wood |publisher=Royal Society for the Protection of Birds |accessdate=6 August 2017}} [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]]Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 54 |{{Nature on the map|1004386}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004386.pdf Citation] |These ancient [[coppice with standards]] woods are mainly [[oak]] with some [[Fraxinus|ash]] and [[birch]]. The soils are [[boulder clay]], which is covered in some areas with glacial sands. Ground flora include [[green hellebore]], [[bird's-nest orchid]] and [[wood spurge]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004386.pdf |title=Hintlesham Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232115/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004386.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Holton Pit]] | [[File:Holton Pit 3.jpg|100px|alt=Holton Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002048&SiteName=holton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Holton Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Halesworth]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TM 405 774}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2336 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Holton (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1002048}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002048.pdf Citation] |This is the only site known to show the sequence of the early [[Pleistocene]] Westleton Beds together with the overlying Kesgrave Gravels. The Westleton Beds are a coastal gravel accumulation, and the site is close to their inland boundary and throws light on their spatial limits.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002048.pdf |title=Holton Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304064601/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002048.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hopton Fen]] | [[File:Hopton Fen, Suffolk - geograph.org.uk - 94571.jpg|100px|alt=Hopton Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 15.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004395&SiteName=hopton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hopton Fen |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Diss]]
