{{gbmappingsmall| TL 990 800}} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/hopton-fen |title=Hopton Fen |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704051651/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/hopton-fen |archivedate=4 July 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1004395}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004395.pdf Citation] |This reed-dominated fen has diverse flora, including [[devil's bit scabious]], [[black bog-rush]], [[bogbean]]a and [[early marsh orchid]]. The SWT is improving the site by excavating new pools, and introducing grazing to restore the open landscape.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004395.pdf |title=Hopton Fen citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231452/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004395.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Horringer Court Caves]] | [[File:Horringer Court Caves 2.jpg|100px|alt=Horringer Court Caves]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 3.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004343&SiteName=horring&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Horringer Court Caves |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord| 52.233|0.687|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Horringer Court Caves }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 836 628 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1004343}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004343.pdf Citation] |This site has over {{convert|500| metres|feet|abbr=off}} of chalk mines, with five grilled entrances, which are used by bats for hibernation. They have been the subject of research since 1947. The main bats using the caves are [[Daubenton's]], but other species include the very rare [[barbastelle]], which have been recorded eight times in 36 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004343.pdf |title=Horringer Court Caves citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201511/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004343.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[How Hill Track]] | [[File:How Hill Track 4.jpg|100px|alt=How Hill Track]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 3.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002197&SiteName=track&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: How Hill Track |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=11 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.358|0.573 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= How Hill Track}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 753 764 }} |[[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1002197}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002197.pdf Citation] |This is a grassland site which provides suitable conditions for seven rare plants, including [[perennial knawel]], [[small alison]], [[Phleum phleoides|purple-stem cat's tail]] and [[sickle medick]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002197.pdf |title=How Hill Track citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=11 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201858/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002197.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hoxne Brick Pit]] | [[File:Hoxne Brick Pit 3.jpg|100px|alt=Hoxne Brick Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004410&SiteName=hoxne&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hoxne Brick Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=3 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Eye, Suffolk|Eye]]
{{coord| 52.344|1.192|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Hoxne Brick Pit}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 175 766}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=596 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Hoxne (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1165 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Hoxne (Pleistocene Vertebrata) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1004410}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004410.pdf Citation] |In 1797, [[John Frere]] suggested that flint [[hand axe]]s, which he found on this site in a deposit twelve feet deep, were weapons dating to a remote period, and this is the earliest recognition that hand axes were made by early humans. The world famous site also provides the type deposits of the [[Hoxnian Stage]], an [[interglacial]] between around 424,000 and 374,000 years ago, which is named after the site.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004410.pdf |title=Hoxne Brick Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=3 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003444/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004410.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}}{{cite book |first=Chris |last=Stringer |authorlink=Chris Stringer |title=Homo Britannicus |page=17 |year=2006 |publisher=Allen Lane |location=London, UK |isbn=978-0-713-99795-8}}{{cite web |url=http://culturalinstitute.britishmuseum.org/asset-viewer/hoxne-handaxe/QQHLEInZfSGV2g?hl=en |title=Hoxne handaxe |publisher=British Museum |accessdate=3 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829165319/http://culturalinstitute.britishmuseum.org/asset-viewer/hoxne-handaxe/QQHLEInZfSGV2g?hl=en |archivedate=29 August 2017 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|I}}[[Iken Wood]] | [[File:Iken Wood 5.jpg|100px|alt=Iken Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002409&SiteName=iken&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Iken Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.155|1.498 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Iken Wood}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 394 565 }} |[[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1002409}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002409.pdf Citation] |This is probably the only ancient coppice wood on blown sand in Britain. Massive [[quercus robur|oak]] [[coppicing#History|standards]] are dominant, and there are [[Living stump|stools]] with a diameter of {{convert|3|m|ft|abbr=off|0}}. Other trees include [[silver birch]], [[Ilex aquifolium|holly]] and [[Sorbus aucuparia|rowan]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002409.pdf |title=Iken Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003622/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002409.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ipswich Heaths]] | [[File:Site of Martlesham Heath airfield - geograph.org.uk - 1219418.jpg|100px|alt=Ipswich Heaths]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 39.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002440&SiteName=ipswich&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Ipswich Heaths |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.049|1.246|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ipswich Heaths }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 227 439 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1002440}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002440.pdf Citation] |The site consists of two separate areas in Martlesham Heath and Purdis Heath. They contain [[Calluna vulgaris|heather]] heath and acid grassland, with clumps of [[Pteridium aquilinum|bracken]] and [[Ulex europaeus|gorse]]. This mosaic of habitats is valuable for butterflies. such as the [[silver-studded blue]], [[common blue]] and [[Small heath (butterfly)|small heath]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002440.pdf |title=Ipswich Heaths citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231800/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002440.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|K}}[[Kentwell Woods]] | [[File:Track through the woods... - geograph.org.uk - 296252.jpg|100px|alt=Kentwell Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|77.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004422&SiteName=kentwell&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Kentwell Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord|52.12|0.71 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Kentwell Woods}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 856 496 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1004422}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004422.pdf Citation] |There is a variety of different woodland types in this site, and the most common is the wet [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] and [[Acer campestre|maple]], with [[Corylus avellana|hazel]] also common. They were managed as [[coppice with standards]] in the past, and have ground vegetation which is typical of ancient woods.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004422.pdf |title=Kentwell Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201855/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004422.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Knettishall Heath]] | [[File:Dew Pond on Knettishall Heath - geograph.org.uk - 911519.jpg|100px|alt=Knettishall Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 91.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002559&SiteName=knett&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Knettishall Heath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Thetford]]
{{coord| 52.39|0.87|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Knettishall Heath}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 951 804 }} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/knettishallheath |title=Knettishall Heath |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170303131147/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/knettishallheath |archivedate=3 March 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1002559}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002559.pdf Citation] |The site is heath and grassland, mainly on acidic soils, with areas of secondary woodland and wet hollows. There are heathland plants such as [[Rumex acetosella|sheep's sorrel]], [[Potentilla erecta|tormentil]], [[Campanula rotundifolia|harebell]] and [[heath bedstraw]], while wet areas have fen vegetation including [[water mint]] and [[yellow iris]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002559.pdf |title=Knettishall Heath citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231942/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002559.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|L}}[[Lackford Lakes]] | [[File:Lackford Lakes Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 589203.jpg|100px|alt=Lackford Lakes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|105.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000068&SiteName=lackford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Lackford Lakes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.3|0.64 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Lackford Lakes }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 803 707 }} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/lackfordlakes |title=Lackford Lakes |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706120651/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/lackfordlakes |archivedate=6 July 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|2000068}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000068.pdf Citation] |The lakes are disused sand and gravel pits in the valley of the [[River Lark]]. There are diverse dragonfly species, and many breeding and overwintering birds, including nationally important numbers of [[gadwall]]s and [[Northern shoveler|shoveler]]s. [[Skylark]]s breed on dry grassland, and [[lapwing]]s in marshy meadows.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000068.pdf |title=Lackford Lakes citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232038/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000068.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Lakenheath Poor's Fen]] | [[File:Lakenheath Poor's Fen 3.jpg|100px|alt=Lakenheath Poor's Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004452&SiteName=laken&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Lakenheath Poor's Fen |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.416|0.5 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Lakenheath Poors Fen}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 701 827 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1004452}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004452.pdf Citation] |This is mainly fen with diverse flora, and there are also areas of damp grassland, ditches and dykes. The grassland is grazed by cattle, and it has flowering plants including [[marsh pennywort]] and [[cuckoo flower]]. The site has a nationally rare plant, [[marsh pea]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004452.pdf |title=Lakenheath Poor's Fen citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195314/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004452.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Lakenheath Warren]] | [[File:Lakenheath Warren - geograph.org.uk - 481888.jpg|100px|alt=Lakenheath Warren]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 588.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271004467%27 |title=Designated Sites View: Lakenheath Warren |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170328060519/http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271004467%27 |archivedate=28 March 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|PP |[[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord| 52.39|0.59|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Lakenheath Warren }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 766 804 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1004467}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004467.pdf Citation] |This is the largest remaining area of heath in the [[Breckland]], and it has a history of use for sheep grazing and as a rabbit warren going back to the thirteenth century, and continuing until the [[Second World War]]. There are several rare lichens and plants, and over fifty species of breeding birds.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004467.pdf |title=Lakenheath Warren citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201848/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004467.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Landguard Common]] | [[File:Landguard - geograph.org.uk - 11709.jpg|100px|alt=Landguard Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 30.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004484&SiteName=landguard&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Landguard Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=26 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224632/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004484&SiteName=landguard&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=20 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|YES |[[Felixstowe]]
{{coord|51.938|1.323 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Landguard Common}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 285 318}} |[[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]]{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=landguard&ID=251 |title=Landguard Common |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170801041044/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=landguard&ID=251 |archivedate=1 August 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1004484}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004484.pdf Citation] |This spit on the northern outskirts of Felixstowe has a vegetated shingle beach, which is a fragile and rare habitat. Flora include [[sea kale]], [[yellow horned poppy]], [[sea sandwort]], [[sea campion]] and [[sea pea]]. Areas of saltmarsh provide cover for small birds.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004484.pdf |title=Landguard Common citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232240/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004484.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Laurel Farm Meadow]] | [[File:Laurel Farm Meadow 4.jpg|100px|alt=Laurel Farm Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|1.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1007227&SiteName=laurel&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Laurel Farm Meadow St. James South Elmham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=15 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Halesworth]]
{{coord| 52.381|1.41|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Laurel Farm Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 322 814}} | |{{Nature on the map|1007227}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1007227.pdf Citation] |This [[Mesotrophic soil|mesotrophic]] grassland site has diverse flora, and it is a type of meadow which is rare in Britain and not found in mainland Europe. The soil is chalky clay which is seasonally waterlogged. There are eleven species of grass, herbs such as [[fairy flax]] and [[Primula veris|cowslip]], and many [[green-winged orchid]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1007227.pdf |title=Laurel Farm Meadow St. James South Elmham citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=15 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052045/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1007227.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Leiston - Aldeburgh]] | [[File:The edge of Thorpeness viewed from Aldeburgh - geograph.org.uk - 1345030.jpg|100px|alt=Leiston – Aldeburgh]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 534.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000370&SiteName=leiston&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Leiston – Aldeburgh |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224632/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000370&SiteName=leiston&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=20 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|PP |[[Aldeburgh]]
{{coord| 52.18|1.6|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Leiston - Aldeburgh }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 463 597 }} |[[local nature reserve|LNR]],{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=456 |title=The Haven, Aldeburgh |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=28 March 2013 |accessdate=25 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426060348/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=456 |archivedate=26 April 2017 |df=}} [[RSPB]],{{cite web |url=https://www.rspb.org.uk/reserves-and-events/find-a-reserve/reserves-a-z/reserves-by-name/n/northwarren/ |title=North Warren |publisher=Royal Society for the Protection of Birds |accessdate=23 April 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]], [[Scheduled Monument|SM]],{{cite web |url=https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1011440 |title=Bowl Barrow on Aldringham Common, 300m East of Stone House |publisher=Historic England |accessdate=4 May 2017}} [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|2000370}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000370.pdf Citation] |This diverse site has open water, fen, acid grassland, scrub, woodland, heath and vegetated shingle. There are many breeding and overwintering birds, abundant dragonflies, and nationally scarce plants such as [[mossy stonecrop]] and [[clustered clover]].{{cite web |url=https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000370.pdf |title=Leiston – Aldeburgh citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 May 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Lineage Wood & Railway Track, Long Melford]] | [[File:Railway Cutting - geograph.org.uk - 296267.jpg|100px|alt=Lineage Wood & Railway Track, Long Melford]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 78.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004495&SiteName=lineage&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Lineage Wood & Railway Track, Long Melford |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 May 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord|52.1|0.76 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Lineage Wood & Railway Track, Long Melford}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 889 484}} | |{{Nature on the map|1004495}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004495.pdf Citation] |Lineage Wood has neutral grassland rides with diverse flora, especially orchids such as the [[Platanthera chlorantha|greater butterfly]], [[fly orchid]], [[Dactylorhiza fuchsii|common spotted]] and [[Ophrys apifera|bee orchid]]. 22 species of butterfly have been recorded. The disused railway line also has floristically rich grassland, but the soil is more alkaline.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004495.pdf |title=Lineage Wood & Railway Track, Long Melford citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003422/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004495.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Lingwood Meadows]] | [[File:Lingwood Meadows 3.jpg|100px|alt=Lingwood Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 2.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006578&SiteName=lingwood&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Lingwood Meadows, Earl Stonham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=31 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731160952/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006578&SiteName=lingwood&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=31 July 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|NO |[[Stowmarket]]
{{coord|52.183|1.094 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Lingwood Meadows, Earl Stonham }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 116 584 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1006578}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006578.pdf Citation] |These ancient meadows are one of the few surviving examples of unimproved grassland in the county. They have diverse flora, and 20 grass species have been recorded with [[red fescue]] and [[Yorkshire fog]] dominant. 55 other species include the nationally scarce [[Trifolium ochroleucon|sulphur clover]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006578.pdf |title=Lingwood Meadows, Earl Stonham citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=31 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504200109/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006578.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Little Blakenham Pit]] | [[File:Little Blakenham Pit 3.jpg|100px|alt=Little Blakenham Pit]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 3.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004523&SiteName=BLAKEN&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Little Blakenham Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=31 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170801025022/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004523&SiteName=BLAKEN&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=1 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|NO | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.1|1.076|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Little Blakenham Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 108 491 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1004523}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004523.pdf Citation] |A {{convert|127|m|ft|abbr=off|adj=on}} tunnel from one of these chalk pits is used by hibernating bats, and it is one of the largest underground roosts known in Britain. Around 450 bats use the tunnel, mainly [[Daubenton's bat|Daubenton's]]. Bats also share a lime kiln with a [[badger sett]]. The site also has chalk grassland.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004523.pdf |title=Little Blakenham Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=31 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195439/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004523.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Little Heath, Barnham]] | [[File:Open access land, Little Heath - geograph.org.uk - 206754.jpg|100px|alt=Little Heath, Barnham]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 46.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000636&SiteName=barnham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Little Heath, Barnham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=1 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Thetford]]
{{coord|52.37|0.72 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Little Heath, Barnham }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 850 781 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 136 [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1000636}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000636.pdf Citation] |Grazing by rabbits and sheep helps to keep the sward on parts of this site as open grassland, but some parts have been invaded by self-sown woodland. The diverse flora in areas grazed by sheep includes [[field woodrush]], [[Trifolium arvense|hare’s foot clover]] and [[harebell]]. [[Stone-curlew]]s nest on short and open turf.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000636.pdf |title=Little Heath, Barnham citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=1 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003754/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000636.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[London Road Industrial Estate, Brandon]] | [[File:London Road Industrial Estate SSSI 1.jpg|100px|alt=London Road Industrial Estate SSSI]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 0.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003798&SiteName=london&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: London Road Industrial Estate, Brandon |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=4 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.439|0.607 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=London Road Industrial Estate, Brandon }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 773 855 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1003798}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003798.pdf Citation] |This very small meadow in the middle of an industrial estate has been designated an SSSI because it has the largest known wild population in Britain of the nationally rare [[Asteraceae|sunflower]] ''[[Artemisia campestris]]'', which is thought to have survived due to periodic soil disturbance. |- ! scope="row"|[[Lordswell Field]] | [[File:Lord's Well Field, Eriswell 3.jpg|100px|alt=Lordswell Field]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 3.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000650&SiteName=lordswell&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Lordswell Field |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.392|0.534 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Lordswell Field }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 725 801}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]] |{{Nature on the map|1000650}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000650.pdf Citation] |This area of [[calcareous]] [[Breckland]] heath has a rich variety of flora including two nationally rare plants, [[spanish catchfly]] and [[perennial knawel]], the latter of which is protected under Section 13 of the [[Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981]]. There is also an area of lichen heath.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000650.pdf |title=Lord's Well Field citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003743/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000650.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|M}}[[Maidscross Hill]] | [[File:Gravel pit at Maids Cross Hill - geograph.org.uk - 464006.jpg|100px|alt=Maidscross Hill]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 44.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000672&SiteName=maidscross&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Maidscross Hill |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=1 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224634/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000672&SiteName=maidscross&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=20 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|YES |[[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.41|0.54 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Maidscross Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 728 823}} |[[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]],{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=maidscross&ID=949 |title=Maidscross Hill |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=4 May 2017}} [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]] |{{Nature on the map|1000672}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000672.pdf Citation] |This very dry grassland has four nationally rare plants, [[Thymus serpyllum|Breckland wild thyme]], [[Silene otites|Spanish catchfly]], [[grape hyacinth]] and [[sickle medick]]. The site is not grazed, which has allowed invasion by bracken and scrub, but also increased the nesting sites for birds.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000672.pdf |title=Maidscross Hill citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=1 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003607/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000672.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Major Farm Meadow]] | [[File:Major Farm, Braiseworth 3.jpg|100px|alt=Major Farm Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 1.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002098&SiteName=major&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Major Farm, Braiseworth |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=3 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Eye, Suffolk|Eye]]
{{coord|52.309|1.108 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Major Farm Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 120 724 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1002098}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002098.pdf Citation] |This is one of the few surviving unimproved hay meadows in the county. It is damp grassland on [[boulder clay]], with diverse flora and many [[molehill]]s. Flowering plants include [[Primula veris|cowslip]], [[Neottia ovata|twayblade]] and [[green-winged orchid]], and there is a mature specimen of the rare [[black poplar]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002098.pdf |title=Major Farm, Braiseworth citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=3 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231745/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002098.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Metfield Meadow]] | [[File:Winks Meadow 6.jpg|100px|alt=Metfield Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 1.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000948&SiteName=metfield&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Metfield Meadow |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=15 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Halesworth]]
{{coord|52.368|1.381 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Metfield Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 303 798}} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/winks-meadow |title=Winks Meadow |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403162827/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/winks-meadow |archivedate=3 April 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1000948}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000948.pdf Citation] |This meadow on a disused airfield is unimproved grassland, with a rich variety of flora on chalky [[boulder clay]]. There are many [[green-winged orchid]]s, [[Primula veris|cowslips]] and [[pepper saxifrage]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000948.pdf |title=Metfield Meadow citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=15 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304054641/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000948.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=}} The meadow is grazed by cattle or cut for hay to maintain the diversity of the wild flowers. |- ! scope="row"|[[Mickfield Meadow]] | [[File:Entrance to Mickfield Meadow - geograph.org.uk - 320285.jpg|100px|alt=Mickfield Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|1.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000685&SiteName=mickfield&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Mickfield Meadow |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=2 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Stowmarket]]
{{coord| 52.225|1.136|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Mickfield Meadow}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 143 632 }} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/mickfield-meadow |title=Mickfield Meadow |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403163726/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/mickfield-meadow |archivedate=3 April 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1000685}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000685.pdf Citation] |Fertilisers and herbicides have never been used on this meadow, and as a result it has a rich variety of flora, including [[Fritillaria meleagris|fritillary]]. The dominant grasses are [[meadow foxtail]], [[Dactylis glomerata|cocksfoot]], [[false oat-grass]], [[Phleum pratense|timothy]] and [[Yorkshire fog]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000685.pdf |title=Mickfield Meadow citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=2 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407094933/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000685.pdf |archivedate=7 April 2014 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Middle Wood, Offton]] | [[File:Field rising towards Middle Wood - geograph.org.uk - 968526.jpg|100px|alt=Middle Wood, Offton]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 23.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002367&SiteName=OFFTON&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Middle Wood, Offton |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Ipswich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 059 499 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1002367}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002367.pdf Citation] |This is a medieval [[coppice with standards]] wood on wet boulder clay, and it has bery diverse ground flora, including species typical of ancient woodland. [[quercus robur|Oak]] is the main standard tree, and there are orchids such as [[common twayblade]], [[early purple orchid]] and [[Platanthera chlorantha|butterfly orchid]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002367.pdf |title=Middle Wood, Offton citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232435/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002367.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Milden Thicks]] | [[File:Bulls Cross Wood - geograph.org.uk - 951783.jpg|100px|alt=Milden Thicks]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 42.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000706&SiteName=milden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Milden Thicks |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.06|0.84|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Milden Thicks }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 951 444}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000706}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000706.pdf Citation] |These are diverse mature woods, described by [[Natural England]] as of national importance for the comparisons which can be made between them. {{coord| 52.161|1.246|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Moat Farm Meadows, Otley }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 221 564}} | |{{Nature on the map|1005770}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005770.pdf Citation] |These [[calcareous]] meadows are traditionally cut for hay. Other species include [[ox-eye daisy]] and [[cuckoo flower]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005770.pdf |title=Moat Farm Meadows, Otley citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003827/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005770.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Martins' Meadows|Monewden Meadows]] | [[File:Martin's Meadow - geograph.org.uk - 670951.jpg|100px|alt=Monewden Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 3.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000736&SiteName=monewden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Monewden Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.167|1.255 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Monewden Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 227 571 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]], [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/martins-meadow |title=Martins' Meadows |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403162313/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/martins-meadow |archivedate=3 April 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1000736}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000736.pdf Citation] |This site has rich flora, and it is described by [[Natural England]] as probably the best example in the county of unimproved calcareous clay and neutral grassland. The herb species are especially diverse, including [[meadow saffron]] and [[green-winged orchid]], and there are ancient fruit trees.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000736.pdf |title=Monewden Meadows citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231723/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000736.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|N}}[[Nacton Meadows]] | [[File:Nacton Meadows 8.jpg|100px|alt=Nacton Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 4.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006266&SiteName=nacton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Nacton Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=13 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814020542/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006266&SiteName=nacton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=14 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|YES |[[Ipswich]]

Wetter areas have more diverse flora, including [[Yorkshire-fog]], [[Cynosurus cristatus|crested dog's tail]], [[sharp-flowered rush]], [[greater bird's-foot-trefoil]] and the uncommon [[marsh arrowgrass]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006266.pdf |title=Nacton Meadows citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=13 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504194232/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006266.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Neutral Farm Pit, Butley]] | [[File:Neutral Farm Pit, Butley 2.jpg|100px|alt=Neutral Farm Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|1.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000781&SiteName=neutral&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Neutral Farm Pit, Butley |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord| 52.106|1.461|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Neutral Farm Pit, Butley }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 371 510 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=591 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Butley Neutral Farm Pit (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1000781}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000781.pdf Citation] |This is described by [[Natural England]] as a classic site in the study of the [[Early Pleistocene]] in [[East Anglia]]. It was used by the nineteenth-century geologist [[Frederick W. Harmer]] to define his Butley division of the [[Red Crag Formation]], and it has many fossils of marine molluscs.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000781.pdf |title=Neutral Farm Pit, Butley citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201015/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000781.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Newbourne Springs]] | [[File:Newbourne Springs Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 161623.jpg|100px|Newbourne Springs]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 15.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000791&SiteName=newbour&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Newbourn (sic) Springs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.043|1.307 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Newbourn Springs}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 269 435 }} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/newbourne-springs |title=Newbourne Springs |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002001003/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/newbourne-springs |archivedate=2 October 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1000791}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000791.pdf Citation] |Most of this site is a narrow valley with a fast-flowing stream with [[alder carr]] and fen. Drier and more acidic soils have grassland, woodland, scrub and bracken heath. The site is actively managed, producing diverse flora and many breeding and migratory birds such as [[Certhia familiaris|treecreepers]], [[Sitta europaea|nuthatches]] and [[sedge warbler]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000791.pdf |title=Newbourn (sic) Springs citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003336/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000791.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Newmarket Heath]] | [[File:The Rowley Mile, Newmarket Racecourse - geograph.org.uk - 189818.jpg|100px|alt=Newmarket Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 279.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006650&SiteName=newmarket&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Newmarket Heath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 June 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Newmarket, Suffolk|Newmarket]]
{{coord|52.24|0.37 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Newmarket Heath }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 622 627 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1006650}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006650.pdf Citation] |Most of this site is chalk grassland, and it has areas of chalk heath, a rare habitat in Britain. There is a rich variety of flowering plants, including a nationally rare species listed in the [[British Red Data Book]] of threatened species and five nationally uncommon ones. The dominant grasses are [[upright brome]] and [[sheep's fescue]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006650.pdf |title=Newmarket Heath citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304033404/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006650.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Norton Wood]] | [[File:Norton Wood 6.jpg|100px|alt=Norton Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 24.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000845&SiteName=norton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Norton Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord| 52.243|0.886|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Norton Wood}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 971 645 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1000845}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000845.pdf Citation] |This ancient [[coppice with standards]] wood is on sand and [[loess]] over [[boulder clay]]. There are many [[pedunculate oak]], hazel, ash and birch trees. The ground flora includes a number of uncommon plants such as [[oxlip]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000845.pdf |title=Norton Wood citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=16 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231542/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000845.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|O}}[[Orwell Estuary]] | [[File:Potter's Reach of the Orwell estuary - geograph.org.uk - 1432814.jpg|100px|alt=Orwell Estuary]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 1,335.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002511&SiteName=orwell&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Orwell Estuary |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 June 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Ipswich]]
{{coord|52|1.23 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Orwell Estuary }}

Stour and Orwell Estuaries. |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315182916/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/SPA/UK9009121.pdf |archivedate=15 March 2016 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK9009121&SiteName=stour&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Stour and Orwell Estuaries |series=Special Protection Area |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/trimley-marshes |title=Trimley Marshes |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=2 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803133056/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/trimley-marshes |archivedate=3 August 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1002511}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002511.pdf Citation] |The estuary is described by [[Natural England]] as of national importance for its breeding [[Recurvirostra avosetta|avocets]], its other breeding and wintering birds, its [[vascular plant]]s and its intertidal mud habitats. It also has a rich and diverse asemblage of invertebrates and a nationally important community of algae.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002511.pdf |title=Orwell Estuary citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=6 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003815/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002511.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Over and Lawn Woods]] | [[File:Lawn Wood - geograph.org.uk - 509045.jpg|100px|alt=Over and Lawn Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 45.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000529&SiteName=over%20and&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Over and Lawn Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Haverhill, Suffolk|Haverhill]]
{{coord| 52.11|0.39|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Over and Lawn Woods}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 635 483}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000529}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000529.pdf Citation] |These are ancient [[coppice with standards]] woods on chalky [[boulder clay]], and the dominant trees are [[pedunculate oak]] and [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]]. The fauna and flora is diverse, including the nationally restricted [[oxlip]]. A stream and pond provide additional ecological interest.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000529.pdf |title=Over and Lawn Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510071949/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000529.pdf |archivedate=10 May 2012 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|P}}[[Pakefield to Easton Bavents]] | [[File:Small lake behind beach - geograph.org.uk - 341028.jpg|100px|alt=Pakefield to Easton Bavents]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 735.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000508&SiteName=pakefield&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Pakefield to Easton Bavents |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Beccles]]

Benacre to Easton Bavents. |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315162242/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/SPA/UK9009291.pdf |archivedate=15 March 2016 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK9009291&SiteName=benacre&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Benacre to Easton Bavents |series=Special Protection Area |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|2000508}} |[https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231804/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000508.pdf Citation] |The site is described by [[Natural England]] as nationally important for its exposures of the [[Lower Pleistocene]] [[Norwich Crag Formation]], its vegetated shingle features, saline lagoons, flood-plain fens, its nationally scarce [[vascular plant]]s, and its scarce breeding birds and wintering [[Botaurus stellaris|bitterns]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000508.pdf |title=Pakefield to Easton Bavents citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231804/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000508.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Pakenham Meadows]] | [[File:Pakenham Meadows 2.jpg|100px|alt=Pakenham Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005849&SiteName=pakenham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Pakenham Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 July 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Bury St Edmunds]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TL 934 686 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1005849}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005849.pdf Citation] |This unimproved and poorly drained meadow has a variety of soil types from loam to peat, and the vegetation types are correspondingly diverse. The herb-rich grassland has [[yellow rattle]], [[Ajuga reptans|bugle]], [[fen bedstraw]], [[oxe-eye daisy]], [[ragged robin]] and [[southern marsh orchid]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005849.pdf |title=Pakenham Meadows citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232639/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005849.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Pashford Poor's Fen, Lakenheath]] | [[File:Pashford Poor's Fen, Lakenheath 5.jpg|100px|alt=Pashford Poor's Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 12.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000899&SiteName=pashford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Pashford Poor's Fen, Lakenheath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Lakenheath]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TL 732 836}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000899}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000899.pdf Citation] |This diverse site has species rich meadows, hollows with fen and marshes, birch woodland, scrub and reedbeds. The invertebrate fauna is diverse, and includes the last known British site for a beetle listed on the [[IUCN Red List|Red Data Book of Threatened Species]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000899.pdf |title=Pashford Poor's Fen, Lakenheath citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213074921/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000899.pdf |archivedate=13 February 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Potton Hall Fields, Westleton]] | [[File:Potton Hall Fields 1.jpg|100px|alt=Potton Hall Fields]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 16.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006426&SiteName=potton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Potton Hall Fields, Westleton |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=15 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Saxmundham]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 456 705 }} |[[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1006426}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006426.pdf Citation] |This site comprises two gently sloping fields on sandy, well drained soil. It has been designated an SSSI because it has a population of several thousand plants of the nationally rare [[filago lutescens|red-tipped cudweed]] in large patches. The plant is only found in two other counties in Britain.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006426.pdf |title=Potton Hall Fields, Westleton citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=15 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224354/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006426.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|R}}[[RAF Lakenheath SSSI|RAF Lakenheath]] | [[File:Lakenheath Military airfield - geograph.org.uk - 53241.jpg|100px|RAF Lakenheath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 111.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006393&SiteName=lakenheath&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: RAF Lakenheath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TL 743 822 }} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1006393}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006393.pdf Citation] |This grassland site on well-drained sandy soils has more rare plants than any other site in the county, including [[perennial knawel]], [[Breckland thyme]], [[wild grape hyacinth]], [[sand catchfly]], [[drooping brome]] and [[smooth rupturewort]]. There are also 22 nationally rare and 47 nationally scarce invertebrates.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006393.pdf |title=RAF Lakenheath citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195832/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006393.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ramsholt Cliff]] | [[File:Ramsholt Cliff.jpg|100px|alt=Ramsholt Cliff]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001596&SiteName=ramsholt&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Ramsholt Cliff |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=26 June 2017}} | align="center"|PP | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.035|1.348 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ramsholt Cliff }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 297 427}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=512 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Ramsholt Cliff, Ramsholt (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1001596}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001596.pdf Citation] |This site is very important historically because it was the basis for the distinction of the [[Pliocene]] [[Coralline Crag Formation]] as a new stratigraphical division by the nineteenth-century geologist, [[Edward Charlesworth]]. The well preserved fossils include several unusual species.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001596.pdf |title=Ramsholt Cliff citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=26 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232140/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001596.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Red House Farm Pit]] | [[File:Red House Farm Pit 3.jpg|100px|alt=Red House Farm Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001633&SiteName=red%20house&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Red House Farm Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TM 435 547}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=509 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Red House Farm Pit, Iken (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1001633}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001633.pdf Citation] |This pit exposes a {{convert|3.5|m|ft|abbr=off}} section of the sandwave [[facies]] of the [[Pliocene]] [[Coralline Crag Formation]]. It has many [[bryozoan]] fossils.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001633.pdf |title=Red House Farm Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231916/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001633.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Red Lodge Heath]] | [[File:Red Lodge Heath 3.jpg|100px|alt=Red Lodge Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 20.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000481&SiteName=lodge&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Red Lodge Heath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=11 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Bury St Edmunds]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TL 697 700}} | |{{Nature on the map|2000481}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000481.pdf Citation] |Habitats on this site are chalk grassland, dry acid grassland, lichen heath, wet woodland and ponds. It has nationally important assemblages of rare plants and invertebrates, including a nationally important population of the [[Cerceris quinquefasciata|five-banded tailed digger wasp]]. It has several other invertebrate species on the [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]], and plants include the nationally rare [[smooth rupturewort]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000481.pdf |title=Red Lodge Heath citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=11 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231827/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000481.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Redgrave and Lopham Fens]] | [[File:Redgrave and South Lopham Fen.jpg|100px|alt=Redgrave and Lopham Fens]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 127.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003726&SiteName=redgrave&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Redgrave and Lopham Fens |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Diss]]
