{{gbmappingsmall| TM 049 796}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 214 [[National Nature Reserve|NNR]],{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006122&SiteName=redgrave&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Redgrave and Lopham Fen |series=National Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 May 2017}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/RIS/UK11056.pdf |title=Information Sheet on Ramsar Wetlands (RIS): Redgrave and South Lopham Fens |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170808084356/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/ris/uk11056.pdf |archivedate=8 August 2017 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK11056&SiteName=redgrave&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Redgrave & South Lopham Fens |series=Ramsar Site |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/redgrave |title=Redgrave and Lopham Fens |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170303044947/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/redgrave |archivedate=3 March 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1003726}}{{efn|name=norfolk}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003726.pdf Citation] |This spring-fed valley at the head of the [[River Waveney]] has several different types of fen vegetation. There are aquatic plants such as [[Utricularia vulgaris|bladderwort]], [[fen pondweed]] and [[Charophytes]], all of which are indicators of low levels of pollution. The site has the only known British population of [[fen raft spider]]s.{{cite web |url=https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003726.pdf |title=Redgrave and Lopham Fens citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Rex Graham nature reserve|Rex Graham Reserve]] | [[File:Rex Graham Reserve.jpg|100px|alt=Rex Graham Reserve]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 2.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center"|NO |[[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.342|0.548 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Rex Graham Reserve }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 737 746}} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0019866 |title=Rex Graham Reserve |series=Special Areas of Conservation |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305154902/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACSelection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0019866 |archivedate=5 March 2016 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0019866&SiteName=rex&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Rex Graham Reserve |series=Special Area of Conservation |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017}} [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1002531}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002531.pdf Citation] |This former chalk pit has the largest population of the nationally rare [[military orchid]], and one of only two known in Britain. It also has many bushes of the uncommon [[mezereon]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002531.pdf |title=Rex Graham Reserve citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=11 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195917/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002531.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Richmond Farm Pit, Gedgrave]] | [[File:Richmond Farm Pit, Gedgrave 5.jpg|100px|alt=Richmond Farm Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001569&SiteName=richmond&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Richmond Farm Pit, Gedgrave |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.089|1.519 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Richmond Farm Pit, Gedgrave}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 412 492 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=511 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Richmond Farm, Gedgrave (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1001569}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001569.pdf Citation] |This pit shows the [[Coralline Crag Formation]] of the [[Pliocene]]. It is described by [[Natural England]] as especially notable for its excellent exposure of the sandwave [[facies]] of the Coralline Crag, but it has very few fossils, which have been transported elsewhere by wave action.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001569.pdf |title=Richmond Farm Pit, Gedgrave citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003450/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001569.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Riverside House Meadow]] | [[File:Riverside House Meadow 1.jpg|100px|alt=Riverside House Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|1.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006842&SiteName=hasketon&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Riverside House Meadow, Hasketon |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 July 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.105|1.275 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Riverside House Meadow, Hasketon }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 244 503}} | |{{Nature on the map|1006842}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006842.pdf Citation] |This unimproved grassland is traditionally managed with a hay cut in the summer, and it has diverse grasses and herbs. The number of such meadows has declined considerably due to changes in agriculture. Eleven grass species and 52 other plants have been recorded.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006842.pdf |title=Riverside House Meadow, Hasketon citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=24 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231601/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006842.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Rockhall Wood Pit, Sutton]] | [[File:Rockhall Wood Pit, Sutton 7.jpg|100px|alt=Rockhall Wood Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 5.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000911&SiteName=rockhall&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Rockhall Wood Pit, Sutton |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=26 June 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.046|1.358 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Rockhall Wood Pit, Sutton }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 304 439 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=592 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Rockhall Wood (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=506 |title=Rockhall Wood, Sutton (Neogene) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1000911}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000911.pdf Citation] |This site has excellent exposures of the [[Pliocene]] [[Coralline Crag Formation]], with a vertical sequence of [[diagenetic]] changes and rich fossil fauna. It is described by [[Natural England]] as probably the most important Pliocene site in Britain.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000911.pdf |title=Rockhall Wood Pit, Sutton citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=25 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231709/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000911.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Round Hill Pit, Aldeburgh]] | [[File:Round Hill Pit, Aldeburgh 2.jpg|100px|alt=Round Hill Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001513&SiteName=round&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Round Hill Pit, Aldeburgh |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=29 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Aldeburgh]]
{{coord|52.16|1.572 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Round Hill Pit, Aldeburgh}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 444 573 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=507 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Round Hill, Aldeburgh (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1001513}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001513.pdf Citation] |This site has a {{convert|2.5| metre|foot|abbr=off|adj=on}} exposure of rocks dating to the [[Coralline Crag Formation]] of the early [[Pliocene]], around five million years ago. It has many horizontal burrows, and is unusual because it has fossils in [[aragonite]], which rarely survive because this mineral is soluble in water.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001513.pdf |title=Round Hill Pit, Aldeburgh citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=29 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231836/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001513.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|S}}[[Sandlings Forest]] | [[File:Tumulus in Tunstall Forest - geograph.org.uk - 420871.jpg|100px|alt=Sandlings Forest]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 2,483.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000433&SiteName=sandlings&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sandlings Forest |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.11|1.45 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sandlings Forest}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 363 512 }} |[[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|2000433}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000433.pdf Citation] |These commercial coniferous plantations are designated an SSSI for their internationally important bird populations. Surveys in the 1990s found 81 singing [[Caprimulgus europaeus|nightjars]], around 2% of the number in Britain, and 71 [[woodlark]]s, approximately 5% of the British population.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000433.pdf |title=Sandlings Forest citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003412/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000433.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sandy Lane Pit, Barham]] | [[File:Quarry entrance - geograph.org.uk - 933526.jpg|100px|alt=Sandy Lane Pit, Barham]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 11.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002300&SiteName=barham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sandy Lane Pit, Barham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.121|1.117|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Sandy Lane Pit, Barham }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 135 515 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=597 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Barham Sandy Lane Pit (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1002300}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002300.pdf Citation] |This site has deposits which span the period from the [[Beestonian stage|Beestonian Stage]], which ended around 866,000 years ago, through to the severe [[ice age]] of the [[Anglian Stage|Anglian]], which started around 478,000 years ago. It has Beestonian deposits thought to have been laid down by the [[Ancestral Thames|proto-Thames]], and a [[paleosol]], a former land surface dating to the Anglian.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002300.pdf |title=Sandy Lane Pit, Barham citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504200614/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002300.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sinks Valley, Kesgrave]] | [[File:Sinks Valley, Kesgrave 3.jpg|100px|alt=Sinks Valley]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 24.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000029&SiteName=sinks&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sinks Valley, Kesgrave |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=20 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820200831/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000029&SiteName=sinks&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=20 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|NO | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord|52.07|1.247 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sinks Valley, Kesgrave}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 226 463 }} | |{{Nature on the map|2000029}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000029.pdf Citation] |This site has diverse semi-natural habitats, with alder and oak woodland, a brook with fringing swamp, wet and dry grassland, spring fed fen and heath. Areas grazed by rabbits have a short turf rich in lichens, mosses and herbs. The nationally uncommon [[mossy stonecrop]] grows on paths.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000029.pdf |title=Sinks Valley, Kesgrave citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=20 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201203/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000029.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sizewell Belts|Sizewell Marshes]] | [[File:Across the dyke - geograph.org.uk - 616867 cropped.jpg|100px|alt=Sizewell Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 105.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003416&SiteName=sizewell&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sizewell Marshes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Leiston]]
{{coord| 52.22|1.61|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sizewell Marshes}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 465 638 }} |[[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]], [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/sizewell-belts |title=Sizewell Belts |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=2 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403163749/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/sizewell-belts |archivedate=3 April 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1003416}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003416.pdf Citation] |These unimproved wet meadows are described by [[Natural England]] as important for their outstanding assemblages of invertebrates, with many nationally rare and scarce species, and of national significance for its assemblage of breeding birds typical of wet grassland. The aquatic fauna is diverse, including the nationally scarce [[soft hornwort]] and [[fen pondweed]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003416.pdf |title=Sizewell Marshes citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003402/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003416.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Snape Warren]] | [[File:Footpath in Black Heath Forest near Snape - geograph.org.uk - 229422.jpg|100px|alt=Snape Warren]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 48.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000928&SiteName=snape&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Snape Warren |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Saxmundham]]
{{coord|52.17|1.52 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Snape Warren }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 406 578 }} |[[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1000928}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000928.pdf Citation] |This site on sandy soils is an example of the lowland heath of eastern England, which has greatly declined since the 1940s. The heath, which is dominated by [[Calluna|ling]], is interspersed with areas of acid grassland, where the most common grasses are [[common bent]] and [[sheep's fescue]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000928.pdf |title=Snape Warren citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231950/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000928.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sotterley Park]] | [[File:Woodland in Sotterley Park - geograph.org.uk - 971305.jpg|100px|alt=Sotterley Park]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 123.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000961&SiteName=sotter&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sotterley Park |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 June 2017}} | align="center"|FP |[[Beccles]]
{{coord| 52.41|1.62|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sotterley Park}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 460 852 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]]Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 55 |{{Nature on the map|1000961}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000961.pdf Citation] |This park was laid out in the eighteenth century, but it goes back at least to the early medieval period, and may retain areas of primary forest. It has many large and ancient trees, which have the richest [[epiphytic]] lichen flora in [[East Anglia]], with 92 recorded species. There are also 14 species of [[bryophyte]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000961.pdf |title=Sotterley Park citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232455/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000961.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sprat's Water and Marshes, Carlton Colville]] | [[File:Carlton Marshes 5.jpg|100px|alt=Sprat's Water and Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 57.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000972&SiteName=sprat&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sprat's Water and Marshes, Carlton Colville |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170521150339/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=s1000972 |archivedate=21 May 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|PP | [[Lowestoft]]
{{coord|52.47|1.69 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sprat's Water and Marshes, Carlton Colville}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 506 922 }} |[[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]], [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/carltonmarshes |title=Carlton and Oulton Marshes |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428122320/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/carltonmarshes |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1000972}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000972.pdf Citation] |The site has open water, mixed fen, [[alder carr]] and wet grazing marsh on thick peat. The diverse flora include a number of uncommon species, and the site is also important for breeding birds.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000972.pdf |title=Sprat's Water and Marshes, Carlton Colville citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304041311/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000972.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Stallode Wash, Lakenheath]] | [[File:Botany Bay - geograph.org.uk - 617728.jpg|100px|alt=Stallode Wash, Lakenheath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 34.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000993&SiteName=stallode&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Stallode Wash, Lakenheath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 June 2017}} | align="center"|FP | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.44|0.463 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Stallode Wash, Lakenheath }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 675 853 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1000993}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000993.pdf Citation] |This is grassland, fen and reedswamp, which is seasonally flooded by the [[River Little Ouse]], and there are smaller areas of permanent open water. There are two nationally rare plants, [[water germander]] and [[marsh pea]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000993.pdf |title=Stallode Wash, Lakenheath citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=8 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504194538/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000993.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Stanton Woods]] | [[File:Steps in the Grundle - geograph.org.uk - 1019169 cropped.jpg|100px|alt=Stanton Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 66.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001008&SiteName=stanton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Stanton Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=11 June 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.31|0.88 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Stanton Woods }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 962 719 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1001008}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001008.pdf Citation] |The site consists of several ancient [[coppice with standards]] woods, some of which are on [[boulder clay]] and others on drier, acid soil. There are also mown rides, small clearings and a linear wooded gorge called The Grundle.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001008.pdf |title=Stanton Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=11 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231458/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001008.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Staverton Park and The Thicks, Wantisden]] | [[File:Oak Grove in 'The Thicks', part of Staverton Park - geograph.org.uk - 1281424.jpg|100px|alt=Staverton Park and The Thicks]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 80.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001023&SiteName=staverton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Staverton Park and The Thicks, Wantisden |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=12 June 2017}} | align="center"|FP | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.1|1.439 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Staverton Park and The Thicks, Wantisden}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 356 507 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]], [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0012741 |title=Staverton Park and The Thicks, Wantisden |series=Special Areas of Conservation |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=4 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140120003639/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/ProtectedSites/SACselection/sac.asp?EUCode=UK0012741 |archivedate=20 January 2014 |df=}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0012741&SiteName=staverton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Staverton Park & The Thicks, Wantisden |series=Special Area of Conservation |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1001023}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001023.pdf Citation] |This ancient park is woodland on sandy soil, with mature pollarded [[Quercus robur|oaks]], while The Thicks is a dense wood with [[Ilex aquifolium|hollies]], some of them thought to be the largest in Britain. There is a rich lichen flora, and invertebrates include rare species.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001023.pdf |title=Staverton Park and The Thicks, Wantisden citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=12 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195856/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001023.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Stoke Tunnel Cutting, Ipswich]] | [[File:View from mouth of tunnel - geograph.org.uk - 434532.jpg|100px|alt=Stoke Tunnel Cutting, Ipswich]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002329&SiteName=stoke&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Stoke Tunnel Cutting, Ipswich |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=12 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Ipswich]]
{{coord|52.046|1.15 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Stoke Tunnel Cutting, Ipswich}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 161 433}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1195 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Stoke Tunnel (Pleistocene Vertebrata) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=600 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Stoke Tunnel (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1002329}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002329.pdf Citation] |This fossiliferous site dates to the late [[Marine Isotope Stage]] 7, around 190,000 years ago. It is part of a high level terrace of the [[River Orwell]] and it has fossils of [[European pond tortoise]]s, lions, [[mammoth]]s, [[woolly rhinoceros]]es, horses and voles.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002329.pdf |title=Stoke Tunnel Cutting, Ipswich citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=12 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195151/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002329.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}}{{cite book |first1=Paul |last1=Pettitt |first2=Mark |last2=White |title=The British Palaeolithic: Human Societies at the Edge of the Pleistocene World |authorlink= |publisher=Routlege |location=Abingdon, UK |year=2012 |edition= |isbn=978-0-415-67455-3 |pages=211–212, 246}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Stour Estuary]] | [[File:Stour estuary at Holbrook Bay - geograph.org.uk - 1602120.jpg|100px|alt=Stour Estuary]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2,248.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004172&SiteName=stour&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Stour Estuary |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 May 2017}} |align="center"|PP | [[Wrabness]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 332 469 }} |[[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]], [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/sutton-hollesley-commons |title=Sutton & Hollesley Commons |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160601151125/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/sutton-hollesley-commons |archivedate=1 June 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1001701}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001701.pdf Citation] |These remnants of the formerly extensive sandy heaths of the Suffolk coast consist of dry grass and heather heathland, together with areas of bracken, scrub and pine and birch woodland. Breeding birds include [[long-eared owl]]s, and [[hen harrier]]s roost there in the winter.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001701.pdf |title=Sutton and Hollesley Heaths citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=12 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003243/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001701.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|T}}[[Thetford Heaths]] | [[File:Thetford Heath - geograph.org.uk - 182398.jpg|100px|alt=Thetford Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|270.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004102&SiteName=thetford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Thetford Heaths |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=13 June 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Thetford]]
{{coord|52.39|0.72 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Thetford Heaths}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 851 801}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2328 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Thetford Heath (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]], [[National Nature Reserve|NNR]],{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006145&SiteName=thetford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Thetford Heath |series=National Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 May 2017}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1004102}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004102.pdf Citation] |A large part of this dry heathland site is [[calacareous]] grassland, and some areas are grazed by sheep or rabbits. There are several nationally rare plants, an uncommon heathland bird, and many lichens and mosses.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004102.pdf |title=Thetford Heaths citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=13 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195750/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004102.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Thorpe Morieux Woods]] | [[File:Thorpe Wood, Suffolk 12.jpg|100px|alt=Thorpe Morieux Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 45.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001735&SiteName=thorpe&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Thorpe Morieux Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807192340/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001735&SiteName=thorpe&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=7 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|PP | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.16|0.84 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Thorpe Morieux Woods}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 942 549 }} |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/bulls-wood |title=Bull's Wood |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=7 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807153553/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/bulls-wood |archivedate=7 August 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1001735}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001735.pdf Citation] |These ancient semi-natural woods are managed by coppicing. The soil is poorly drained [[boulder clay]], and common trees include [[pedunculate oak]]. [[Bramble]] and [[dog's mercury]] are dominant in the ground flora, with extensive [[oxlip]] in some areas.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001735.pdf |title=Thorpe Morieux Woods citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504232635/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001735.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Titsal Wood, Shadingfield]] | [[File:Titsal Wood - geograph.org.uk - 978986.jpg|100px|alt=Titsal Wood, Shadingfield]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 14.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}.{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001775&SiteName=titsal&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Titsal Wood, Shadingfield |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Beccles]]
{{coord|52.4|1.564 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Titsal Wood, Shadingfield}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 426 836 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1001775}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001775.pdf Citation] |This ancient [[coppice with standards]] wood is mainly [[Carpinus betulus|hornbeam]], but it also has young [[Quercus robur|oak]] and [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] standards. The ground flora is rich and ancient, including [[common spotted orchid]], [[Cardamine flexuosa|wood bitter-cress]] and the rare [[Carex strigosa|thin-spiked wood sedge]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001775.pdf |title=Titsal Wood, Shadingfield citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504195209/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001775.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Trundley and Wadgell's Wood, Great Thurlow]] | [[File:Trundley Wood - geograph.org.uk - 508270.jpg|100px|alt=Trundley Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|79.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001784&SiteName=trundley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Trundley and Wadgell's Wood, Great Thurlow |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO |[[Haverhill, Suffolk|Haverhill]]
{{coord|52.13|0.47 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Trundley and Wadgell's Wood, Great Thurlow }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 695 503 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1001784}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001784.pdf Citation] |These semi-natural woods on [[boulder clay]] soils are mostly ancient [[coppice with standards]], with [[pedunculate oak]] as the main standard trees. They have ground flora typical of ancient woodland such as [[early purple orchid]], [[yellow archangel]] and [[Sanicula europaea|sanicle]]. There are wide grassy rides which are dominated by [[Yorkshire fog]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001784.pdf |title=Trundley and Wadgell's Wood, Great Thurlow citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504194457/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001784.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Tunstall Common]] | [[File:Tunstall Common - geograph.org.uk - 66446 cropped.jpg|100px|alt=Tunstall Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 36.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001812&SiteName=tunstall&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Tunstall Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord| 52.141|1.474|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Tunstall Common}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 378 549}} |[[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001812}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001812.pdf Citation] |Most of this dry lowland heath is dominated by [[Calluna vulgaris|heather]], with diverse lichens and mosses. There are also areas of acid grassland, which are being invaded by gorse and bracken. Pine scrub is encroaching from neighbouring plantations.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001812.pdf |title=Tunstall Common citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504194646/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001812.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|V}}[[Valley Farm Pit, Sudbourne]] | [[File:Valley Farm Pit, Sudbourne 4.jpg|100px|alt=Valley Farm Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001527&SiteName=VALLEY%20FARM&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Valley Farm Pit, Sudbourne |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.122|1.556 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Valley Farm Pit, Sudbourne }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 435 530 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=508 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Valley Farm, Sudbourne (Neogene) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017}} [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths|SCHAONB]] |{{Nature on the map|1001527}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001527.pdf Citation] |A shelly, fossilerous [[Pleistocene]] layer lies [[unconformably]] above a [[Pliocene]] [[Coralline Crag Formation]] layer. It is described by [[Natural England]] as important both for [[sedimentological]] studies and for understanding the local relationship between the Pliocene and the Pleistocene.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001527.pdf |title=Valley Farm Pit, Sudbourne citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=22 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504200346/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001527.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|W}}[[Waldringfield Pit]] | [[File:Waldringfield Pit.jpg|100px|alt=Waldringfield Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002231&SiteName=waldrin&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Waldringfield Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=20 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820202303/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002231&SiteName=waldrin&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=20 August 2017 |df=}} | align="center"|NO |[[Woodbridge, Suffolk|Woodbridge]]
{{coord|52.055|1.295 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Waldringfield Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 260 448 }} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2333 |series=Geological Conservation Review |title=Waldringfield (Quaternary of East Anglia) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820202138/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2333 |archivedate=20 August 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1002231}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002231.pdf Citation] |This site exposes a sequence of [[Pleistocene]] deposits, including the [[Waldringfield Gravels]], the lowest unit of the [[Ancestral Thames#Vestiges|Kesgrave Sands and Gravels]], which were deposits on the bed of the [[River Thames]] before it was diverted south by the [[Anglian Glaciation]] around 450,000 years ago. Waldringfield Pit is the [[Type locality (geology)|type site]] for the Waldringfield Gravels.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002231.pdf |title=Waldringfield Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=20 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231650/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002231.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}}{{cite book |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/V7Chap1.pdf |page=21 |first=D. R. |last=Bridgland |title=The Pleistocene of the Thames |date=1994 |publisher=Chapman and Hall |isbn=0 41248 830 2 |location=London, UK |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160122141116/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/pdf/v7chap1.pdf |archivedate=2016-01-22 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wangford Warren and Carr]] | [[File:Wangford Fen, Wangford, Suffolk - geograph.org.uk - 609373.jpg|100px|alt=Wangford Warren and Carr]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 67.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001871&SiteName=wangford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wangford Warren and Carr |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | align="center"|PP |[[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.42|0.58 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wangford Warren and Carr}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 755 839}} | [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, ''A Nature Conservation Review'', p. 134 [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]], [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/wangford-warren |title=Wangford Warren |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515035541/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/wangford-warren |archivedate=15 May 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1001871}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001871.pdf Citation] |According to [[Natural England]], this site has the best preserved system of active sand dunes in [[Breckland]], together with typical Breckland plants and the rare [[grey hair-grass]]. There are also areas of lichen heath and dry grassland.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001871.pdf |title=Wangford Warren and Carr citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303225759/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001871.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2014 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Weather and Horn Heaths, Eriswell]] | [[File:Heathland with gorse in The Brecks near Elveden - geograph.org.uk - 1288059.jpg|100px|alt=Weather and Horn Heaths]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|133.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001889&SiteName=weather&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Weather and Horn Heaths, Eriswell |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord| 52.37|0.62|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Weather and Horn Heaths }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 783 774 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001889}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001889.pdf Citation] |There are areas of acidic grassland and heather, together with large parts dominated by mosses and lichens. Grazing by rabbits and stock has kept plants short and the habitat open.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001889.pdf |title=Weather and Horn Heaths, Eriswell citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003853/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001889.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[West Stow Heath]] | [[File:West Stow Lake - geograph.org.uk - 639767.jpg|100px|alt=West Stow Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 44.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001970&SiteName=west+stow&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: West Stow Heath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord|52.31|0.63 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= West Stow Heath}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 792 714}} |[[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001970}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001970.pdf Citation] |This site has diverse habitats with grassland, heath, wet woodland, scrub, dry woodland and former gravel workings which are now open water. The grassland has three nationally rare plants, [[Festuca caesia|glaucous fescue]], [[thymus serpyllum|Breckland wild thyme]] and [[Veronica verna|spring speedwell]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001970.pdf |title=West Stow Heath citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003543/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001970.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Westhall Wood and Meadow]] | [[File:Westhall Wood, near Rickinghall - geograph.org.uk - 338184.jpg|100px|alt=Westhall Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 43.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005773&SiteName=westhall&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Westhall Wood and Meadow |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Diss]]
{{coord|52.32|0.98 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Westhall Wood and Meadow}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 030 728 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1005773}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005773.pdf Citation] |The wood is ancient [[coppice with standards]] with mainly [[pedunculate oak]] and [[Carpinus betulus|hornbeams]] dominant in the coppice layer. The unimproved meadow is poorly drained and species rich, with grasses including [[red fescue]] and [[Yorkshire fog]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005773.pdf |title=Westhall Wood and Meadow citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505003304/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005773.pdf |archivedate=5 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Weston Fen]] | [[File:Weston Fen 6.jpg|100px|alt=Weston Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 49.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001985&SiteName=weston&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Weston Fen – 1001985 |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 July 2017}} | align="center"|YES | [[Diss]]
{{coord| 52.37|0.91|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Weston Fen}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 980 786}} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/market-weston-fen |title=Market Weston Fen |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416201015/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/market-weston-fen |archivedate=16 April 2016 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1001985}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001985.pdf Citation] |This spring-fed valley fen has a high and stable water table, and as a result it has a rich and varied flora. The dominant plants in the central fen area are [[saw sedge]], the reed ''[[Phragmites australis]]'' and [[Juncus subnodulosus|blunt-flowered rush]]. Other habitats include tall fen grassland, heath and a stream. There are many dragonflies and damselflies.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001985.pdf |title=Weston Fen citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504201530/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001985.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wilde Street Meadow]] | [[File:Wilde Street Meadow 3.jpg|100px|alt=Wilde Street Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 11.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003809&SiteName=wilde&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wilde Street Meadow |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017}} | align="center"|NO | [[Lakenheath]]
{{coord|52.382|0.511 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wilde Street Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 710 790}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003809}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003809.pdf Citation] |This site has a long history of traditional management, with low intensity summer grazing. It has areas of species-rich [[calcareous]] grassland, damp pasture, scrub and dykes. There is a large population of [[green-winged orchid]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003809.pdf |title=Wilde Street Meadow citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=5 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231900/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003809.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wortham Ling]] | [[File:Rabbit burrows in the Ling - geograph.org.uk - 1770327.jpg|100px|alt=Wortham Ling]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 53.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005979&SiteName=wortham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wortham Ling |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | align="center"|YES |[[Diss]]
{{coord| 52.37|1.07|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wortham Ling }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 092 795 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1005979}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005979.pdf Citation] |This site has acid grassland and dry heath on a sandy soil. Some areas are intensely grazed by rabbits, producing a very short sward which is a suitable habitat for lichens and mosses. Butterflies include many [[Grayling (butterfly)|graylings]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005979.pdf |title=Wortham Ling citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504231535/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005979.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2015 |df=}} |} ==See also== {{commons category|Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Suffolk}} *[[National Nature Reserves in Suffolk]] *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in Suffolk]] *[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]] ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{coord|52|10|N|1|0|E|region:GB_type:adm1st|display=title|name=Suffolk}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|editor-first=Derek |editor-last=Ratcliffe |title=A Nature Conservation Review |volume=2 |authorlink=Derek Ratcliffe |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, UK |year=1977 |isbn=0-521-21403-3}} {{SSSIs Suffolk}} {{SSSI AOS lists}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Suffolk| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Suffolk]] [[Category:Suffolk-related lists|Sites of Special Scientific Interest]]

page.title: List of plants of the Amazon rainforest of Brazil

revision.text:
This is a list of plants found in the wild in [[Amazon Rainforest]] [[vegetation]] of [[Brazil]]. The estimates from useful plants suggested that there are 800 plant species of economic or social value in this forest, according to Giacometti (1990).<ref>{{cite journal| first=D.C.| last=Giacometti| year=1990| title=Estratégias de coleta e conservação de germoplasma hortícola da América tropical| pages=91–110| journal=Proc. Simpósio Latinoamericano sobre recursos genéticos de espécies hortícolas| publisher=Fundação Cargill| url=http://www.cargill.com.br/}}</ref> Additions are currently being made to this list. {{Expand list|date=August 2008}}
Flora definition Flora is the scientific word for plant.

'''Maritime domain awareness''' ('''MDA''') is defined by the [[International Maritime Organization]] as the effective understanding of anything associated with the maritime domain that could impact the security, safety, economy, or environment.<ref>{{cite paper|url=http://www.imo.org/blast/blastDataHelper.asp?data_id=29093&filename=1367.pdf |title=AMENDMENTS TO THE INTERNATIONAL AERONAUTICAL AND MARITIME SEARCH AND RESCUE (IAMSAR) MANUAL |publisher=[[International Maritime Organization]] |pages=1 |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> The maritime domain is defined as all areas and things of, on, under, relating to, adjacent to, or bordering on a sea, ocean, or other navigable waterway, including all maritime-related activities, infrastructure, people, cargo, and vessels and other conveyances.
==United States== In the United States, the [[Secretary of the Navy]] is the DoD Executive Agent for maritime domain awareness.<ref>[http://www.dtic.mil/whs/directives/corres/pdf/200502p.pdf Maritime Domain Awareness in the Department of Defense]</ref>
For private ports, The Mariner Group's CommandBridge platform is the market leader in Maritime Domain Awareness Systems.
==Canada== In Canada, the 2004 National Security Policy resulted in the establishment of Marine Security Operations Centers (MSOCs) responsible for supporting a national response to maritime security threat. The East Coast MSOC is in [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], the West Coast MSOC is in [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]], and the [[Great Lakes]] and [[St. Lawrence Seaway]] MSOC is in [[Niagara-on-the-Lake|Niagara]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tc.gc.ca/eng/marinesecurity/operations-269.htm |title=Marine Security Operation Centres - Transport Canada |publisher=Tc.gc.ca |date=2012-05-14 |accessdate=2012-07-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130106020911/http://www.tc.gc.ca/eng/marinesecurity/operations-269.htm |archivedate=2013-01-06 |df= }}</ref>
==European Union== The European Union took a decision in 2008 to improve the integration and interoperability of member states' maritime safety, security, border control, environmental protection, fisheries and law enforcement systems in order to create a Common Information Sharing Environment for the EU maritime domain.<ref>{{cite paper |url=http://www.en.mi.gov.pl/files/0/1791944/Towardstheintegrationofmaritimesurveillance.pdf |title=Towards the integration of maritime surveillance: A common information sharing environment for the EU maritime domain |publisher=COMMISSION OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES |date=2009-10-15 |accessdate=2012-07-03 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Philippines== In the Philippines, the National Coast Watch System (NCWS) was originally designed to improve maritime domain awareness in the [[Sulu Sea|Sulu]] and [[Celebes Sea]]s, but has been extended over the entire island country's territory.<ref>{{cite paper|url=http://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/occasional_papers/2012/RAND_OP372.pdf |title=Non-Traditional Threats and Maritime Domain Awareness in the Tri-Border Area of Southeast Asia The Coast Watch System of the Philippines |publisher=[[Rand Corporation]] |pages=iii |date= |accessdate=2012-07-03}}</ref>
==South Africa== In March 2012, the [[South African Navy]] announce the establishment of two MDA centers, one in [[Cape Town]] for the west coast and one in [[Durban]] to cover the east coast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=24437:navy-to-establish-maritime-awareness-centres&catid=51:Sea&Itemid=106 |title=Navy to establish Maritime Awareness Centres |publisher=DefenceWeb |date=2012-03-19 |accessdate=2012-07-03}}</ref>
==India== NEW DELHI: The Narendra Modi government will establish a National Maritime Authority (NMA) to ensure cohesive policy-making and effective coordination on coastal security among the multiple authorities dealing with maritime issues in the country.
It was the NMA that caught the eye of many in the defence establishment. The concept of an apex federal maritime body is not new. It was strongly recommended after the 26/11 Mumbai terror attacks in 2008, and even figured on the agenda of the Cabinet Committee on Security in the shape of a maritime security advisory board (MSAB) with a maritime security advisor as its chief.
But the then UPA government had junked it due to turf-wars, among other reasons. Even the 2001 GoM report on reforming the national security system had underlined the need for "an apex body for management of maritime affairs for institutionalised linkages among the Navy, Coast Guard and ministries of central and state governments".
Though a slew of coastal security measures have been taken since 26/11, from a fledgling coastal radar network to state marine police stations, experts feel port and coastal security in India is still far from becoming impregnable.
The 15 or more agencies involved, ranging from Navy, Coast Guard, customs, intelligence agencies and port authorities to the home and shipping ministries, state governments and fisheries departments, often work at cross-purposes. "A full-time federal body like NMA is needed to clear the clutter," said an official.
After 26/11, the UPA regime in August 2009 did constitute the national committee on strengthening maritime and coastal security against threats from the sea (NCSMCS), with the cabinet secretary as its chairman. "While NCSMCS has done some good work in monitoring implementation of coastal security measures as well as coordination with different stakeholders, it has met barely 9-10 times since then... much more needs to be done," said a top official.
The '''national maritime domain awareness (NMDA) project''', basically an integrated intelligence grid to detect and tackle threats emanating from the sea in real-time, for instance, is yet to take concrete shape. Its aim was to generate a "common operational picture'' of activities at sea through an institutionalised mechanism for collecting, fusing and analysing information from technical and other sources like coastal surveillance network radars, space-based automatic identification systems, vessel traffic management systems, fishing vessel registration and fishermen biometric identity databases..<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Apex-maritime-authorioty-for-coastal-security/articleshow/36316877.cms&catid=51:Sea&Itemid=106 |title=Apex maritime Authority for Coastal Security |publisher=TimesOfIndia |date=2014-06-10 |accessdate=2014-06-10}}</ref>
