{{Redirect|Rainy season||Rainy Season (disambiguation)}} {{Weather}} [[File:Cairns climate.svg|right|thumb|Rainfall distribution by month in [[Cairns, Queensland|Cairns]], [[Australia]].]]
The''' monsoon season''' is the time of year when most of a region's average annual [[rainfall]] occurs. Generally the season lasts at least a month.<ref>Glossary of Meteorology (2013). [http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=rainy-season1 Rainy season.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215203023/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=rainy-season1 |date=2009-02-15 }} American Meteorological Society. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> The term "'''green season'''" is also sometimes used as a [[euphemism]] by tourist authorities.<ref>Costa Rica Guide (2005). [http://costa-rica-guide.com/when.htm When to Travel to Costa Rica.] ToucanGuides. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> Areas with wet seasons are dispersed across portions of the [[tropics]] and [[subtropics]].<ref>Michael Pidwirny (2008). [http://www.physicalgeography.net/fundamentals/9k.html CHAPTER 9: Introduction to the Biosphere.] PhysicalGeography.net. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref>
Under the [[Köppen climate classification]], for [[tropical climate]]s, a wet season month is defined as a month where average precipitation is {{convert|60|mm}} or more.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hydrol-earth-syst-sci.net/11/1633/2007/hess-11-1633-2007.pdf | title=Updated world Köppen-Geiger climate classification map}}</ref> In contrast to areas with [[savanna]] climates and [[monsoon]] regimes, [[Mediterranean climate]]s have wet winters and dry summers. Dry and rainy months are characteristic of [[tropical seasonal forest]]s: in contrast to [[tropical rainforest]]s, which do not have dry or wet seasons, since their rainfall is equally distributed throughout the year.<ref name="Hyde">Elisabeth M. Benders-Hyde (2003). [http://www.blueplanetbiomes.org/climate.htm World Climates.] Blue Planet Biomes. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> Some areas with pronounced rainy seasons will see a break in rainfall mid-season, when the [[intertropical convergence zone]] or [[monsoon trough]] moves to higher latitudes in the middle of the warm season.<ref name="JS">J. S. 0guntoyinbo and F. 0. Akintola (1983). [http://www.cig.ensmp.fr/~iahs/redbooks/a140/iahs_140_0063.pdf Rainstorm characteristics affecting water availability for agriculture.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205200119/http://www.cig.ensmp.fr/~iahs/redbooks/a140/iahs_140_0063.pdf |date=2009-02-05 }} IAHS Publication Number 140. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref>
When the wet season occurs during a warm season, or [[summer]], [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] falls mainly during the late afternoon and early evening. In the wet season, [[air quality]] improves, fresh water quality improves, and vegetation grows substantially, leading to crop yields late in the season. Rivers overflow their banks, and some animals retreat to higher ground. [[Soil]] nutrients diminish and erosion increases. The incidence of [[malaria]] increases in areas where the rainy season coincides with high temperatures, particularly in tropical areas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs094/en/|title=Malaria Fact Sheet|date=April 2016|website=The World Health Organization|publisher=|access-date=April 24, 2016}}</ref> Some animals have adaptation and survival strategies for the wet season. Often, the previous dry season leads to food shortages in the wet season, as the crops have yet to mature.
==Character of the rainfall== [[File:Darwin 1824.jpg|thumb|left|Wet season storm at night in [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], Australia.]]
In areas where the heavy rainfall is associated with a wind shift, the wet season is known as the monsoon.<ref>Glossary of Meteorology (2009). [http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=monsoon&submit=Search Monsoon.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080322122025/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=monsoon&submit=Search |date=2008-03-22 }} American Meteorological Society. Retrieved on 2009-01-16.</ref> Rainfall in the wet season is mainly due to daytime heating which leads to diurnal thunderstorm activity within a pre-existing moist airmass, so the rain mainly falls in late afternoon and early evening in savannah and monsoon regions. Further, much of the total rainfall each day occurs in the first minutes of the downpour,<ref name="JS" /> before the storms mature into their stratiform stage.<ref>Robert A. Houze Jr (1997). [http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0477/78/10/pdf/i1520-0477-78-10-2179.pdf Stratiform Precipitation in Regions of Convection: A Meteorological Paradox?] Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society, pp. 2179. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> Most places have only one wet season, but areas of the tropics can have two wet seasons, because the monsoon trough, or [[Intertropical Convergence Zone]], can pass over locations in the tropics twice per year. However, since rain forests have rainfall spread evenly through the year, they do not have a wet season.<ref name="Hyde" />
It is different for places with a [[Mediterranean climate]]. In the western United States, during the cold season from September–May, [[extratropical cyclone]]s from the [[Pacific Ocean]] move inland into the region due to a southward migration of the [[jet stream]] during the cold season. This shift in the jet stream brings much of the annual precipitation to the region,<ref name="JHorel">J. Horel (2006). [http://www.met.utah.edu/jhorel/html/wx/climate/normrain.html Normal Monthly Precipitation, Inches.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061113222938/http://www.met.utah.edu/jhorel/html/wx/climate/normrain.html |date=2006-11-13 }} University of Utah. Retrieved on 2008-03-19.</ref> and sometimes also brings heavy rain and strong low pressure systems.<ref name="WesWest">Norman W. Junker (2008). [http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/mcs_web_test_test_files/Page1539.htm West Coast Cold Season Heavy Rainfall Events.] Hydrometeorological Prediction Center. Retrieved on 2008-03-01.</ref> The [[peninsula]] of [[Italy]] has weather very similar to the western United States in this regard.<ref>[[BBC]] Weather (2009). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/world/country_guides/results.shtml?tt=TT004000 Country Guide: Italy.] British Broadcasting Company. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref>
==Areas affected==
Areas with a [[savanna]] climate in [[Sub-Saharan Africa]], such as [[Ghana]], [[Burkina Faso]],<ref>Patrick Laux et al. (2008): Predicting the regional onset of the rainy season in West Africa. International Journal of Climatology, 28 (3), 329–342.</ref><ref>Patrick Laux et al. (2009): Modelling daily precipitation features in the Volta Basin of West Africa. International Journal of Climatology, 29 (7), 937–954.,</ref> [[Darfur]],<ref>David Vandervort (2009). [http://www.icrc.org/Web/Eng/siteeng0.nsf/html/sudan-feature-060707 Darfur: getting ready for the rainy season.] International Committee of the Red Cross. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> [[Eritrea]],<ref>Mehari Tesfazgi Mebrhatu, M. Tsubo, and Sue Walker (2004). [http://www.cropscience.org.au/icsc2004/poster/2/6/580_mebrhatumt.htm A Statistical Model for Seasonal Rainfall Forecasting over the Highlands of Eritrea.] New directions for a diverse planet: Proceedings of the 4th International Crop Science Congress. Retrieved on 2009-02-08.</ref> [[Ethiopia]],<ref>Alex Wynter (2009). [http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/218536/123391195425.htm Ethiopia: March rainy season "critical" for southern pastoralists.] Thomson Reuters Foundation. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> and [[Botswana]] have a distinct rainy season.<ref>The Voice (2009). [http://allafrica.com/stories/200901270599.html Botswana: Rainy Season Fills Up Dams.] allAfrica.com. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> Also within the savanna climate regime, [[Florida]] and [[South Texas]] have a rainy season.<ref>Randy Lascody (2008). [http://www.srh.noaa.gov/mlb/wetdry/FLrainMachine.htm The Florida Rain Machine.] [[National Weather Service]]. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> Monsoon regions include the [[Indian subcontinent]], [[Southeast Asia]] (including [[Indonesia]] and [[Philippines]]),<ref>OCHA Partnership for Humanity (2008). [http://ochaonline.un.org/OchaLinkClick.aspx?link=ocha&docId=1096564 OCHA Field Situation Report: Indonesia – Rainy Season 1 December 2008.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218070603/http://ochaonline.un.org/OchaLinkClick.aspx?link=ocha&docId=1096564 |date=18 February 2009 }} United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> northern sections of [[Australia]]'s North,<ref>Burarra Gathering (2006). [http://burarra.questacon.edu.au/pages/seasons.html Burarra Gathering.] Burarra Gathering. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> [[Polynesia]],<ref>Tahiti Sun Travel Network (2007). [http://www.boraboraisland.com/about.html About Bora Bora Island.] Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> [[Central America]],<ref>[[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]] (2006). [http://www.nrlmry.navy.mil/forecaster_handbooks/CentralAmerica/Forecasters%20Handbook%20for%20Central%20America%20and%20Adjacent%20Waters.2.4.pdf 2.4 Analysis & Forecasting "Thumb Rules" for the Rainy Season.] [[United States Navy]]. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> western and southern [[Mexico]],<ref>Remote Sensing for Migratory Creatures (2002). [https://web.archive.org/web/20041102070632/http://arsc.arid.arizona.edu/migratory/veg_tdf.html Phenology and Creature Migration: Dry season and wet season in West Mexico.] Arizona Remote Sensing Center. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> the Desert Southwest of the United States,<ref name="JHorel" /> southern [[Guyana]],<ref name="GUY">Horace Burton (2006). [http://www.cimh.edu.bb/The%20outfield%204.pdf The climate of Guyana.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124053438/http://cimh.edu.bb/The%20outfield%204.pdf |date=2009-01-24 }} Caribbean Institute for Meteorology and Hydrology. The Outfield, August 2006, pp. 3. Retrieved on 2009-02-08.</ref> portions of northeast [[Brazil]].<ref name="Brazil">James Brian Elsner (1988). [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1988PhDT........55E Analysis of Wet Season Rainfall Over the Nordeste of Brazil, South America.] University Of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref>
Northern [[Guyana]] has two wet seasons: one in early spring and the other in early winter.<ref name="GUY" /> In western Africa, there are two rainy seasons across southern sections, but only one across the north.<ref>C. H. Mari, G. Cailley, L. Corre, M. Saunois, J. L. Attie, V. Thouret, and A. Stohl (2007). [http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/32/82/48/PDF/acpd-7-17339-2007.pdf Biomass burning plumes during the AMMA wet season experiment.] Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics Discussions, pp. 17342. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> Within the Mediterranean climate regime, the west coast of the United States and the [[Mediterranean]] coastline of Italy, Greece,<ref>Greek Embassy London (2008). [http://greece.embassyhomepage.com/greece_weather_forecast_cheap_flights_corfu_hotels_greece_embassy_of_greece_london_uk_greece_travel_insurance.htm Welcome to Greece.] Government of Greece. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> and Turkey experience a wet season in the winter months.<ref>D. Bozkurt, O.L. Sen and M. Karaca (2008). [http://www.cosis.net/abstracts/EGU2008/04210/EGU2008-A-04210-1.pdf Wet season evaluation of RegCM3 performance for Eastern Mediterranean.] EGU General Assembly. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> Similarly, the wet season in the [[Negev desert]] of [[Israel]] extends from October through May.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://geography.huji.ac.il/personal/Dayan/Publications/Synoptic%20Clim%20Maj%20Floods.pdf|page=869|title=Synoptic Climatology of Major Floods in the Negev Desert, Israel|author1=Ron Kahana|author2=Baruch Ziv|author3=Yehouda Enzel|author4=Uri Dayan|last-author-amp=yes|journal=International Journal of Climatology|year=2002|volume=22|doi=10.1002/joc.766|bibcode=2002IJCli..22..867K|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719162555/http://geography.huji.ac.il/personal/Dayan/Publications/Synoptic%20Clim%20Maj%20Floods.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-19|df=}}</ref> At the boundary between the Mediterranean and monsoon climates lies the [[Sonoran desert]], which receives the two rainy seasons associated with each climate regime.<ref>Michael J. Plagens (2009). [http://www.arizonensis.org/sonoran/ What and Where is the Sonoran Desert?] Arizonensis. Retrieved on 2009-02-07.</ref>
The wet season is known by many different local names throughout the world. For example, in Mexico it is known as "storm season". Different names are given to the various short "seasons" of the year by the Aboriginal tribes of [[Northern Australia]]: the wet season typically experienced there from December to March is called ''Gudjewg''. The precise meaning of the word is disputed, although it is widely accepted to relate to the severe thunderstorms, flooding, and abundant vegetation growth commonly experienced at this time.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/topics/national-parks/kakadu-national-park/natural-environment/six-seasons|title=The Six Seasons|date=|website=Australian Government, Department of the Environment|publisher=|access-date=April 25, 2016}}</ref>
== Effects == [[File:Vindhya.jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|right|Monsoon in the [[Vindhya]] mountain range, central [[India]].]]
In tropical areas, when the monsoon arrives, high daytime high temperatures drop and overnight low temperatures increase, thus reducing [[diurnal temperature variation]].<ref>Official Web Site of District Sirsa, India (2001). [http://sirsa.gov.in/htfiles/location.html District Sirsa.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101228153903/http://sirsa.gov.in/htfiles/location.html |date=2010-12-28 }} National Informatice Center. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> During the wet season, a combination of heavy rainfall and, in some places such as [[Hong Kong]], an onshore wind, improve [[air quality]].<ref>Mei Zheng (2000). [http://digitalcommons.uri.edu/dissertations/AAI9989458/ The sources and characteristics of atmospheric particulates during the wet and dry seasons in Hong Kong.] University of Rhode Island. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> In Brazil, the wet season is correlated with weaker [[trade winds]] off the ocean.<ref name="Brazil" /> The [[pH]] level of water becomes more balanced due to the charging of local [[aquifer]]s during the wet season.<ref>S. I. Efe, F. E. Ogban, M. J. Horsfall, E. E. Akporhonor (2005). [https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/bitstream/1807/6445/1/ja05036.pdf Seasonal Variations of Physico-chemical Characteristics in Water Resources Quality in Western Niger Delta Region, Nigeria.] Journal of Applied Scientific Environmental Management. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> Water also softens, as the concentration of dissolved materials reduces during the rainy season.<ref>C. D. Haynes, M. G. Ridpath, M. A. J. Williams (1991). [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZhvtSmJYuN4C&pg=PA91&lpg=PA91&dq=wet+season+characteristics&source=web&ots=RgIkJ2tZp3&sig=nCLkFclils6CqFgiUoSs7RhBsXU&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result#PPA90,M1 Monsoonal Australia.] Taylor & Francis, pp. 90. {{ISBN|978-90-6191-638-3}}. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> Erosion is also increased during rainy periods.<ref name="JS" /> [[Arroyo (creek)|Arroyos]] that are dry at other times of the year fill with runoff, in some cases with water as deep as {{convert|10|ft|m}}.<ref name="Road Notes, Cuba. 1909">United States War Department (1909). [https://books.google.com/books?id=QIUEnyzrZNIC&pg=PA398&lpg=PA398&dq=arroyos+wet+season&source=web&ots=-JQtnTALFh&sig=ayHCdpWNysDEVWDUkLYZTGB7Avg&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result Road Notes, Cuba. 1909.] United States Department of War. Retrieved on 2009-01-16.</ref> Leaching of soils during periods of heavy rainfall depletes nutrients.<ref name="Road Notes, Cuba. 1909" /> The higher runoff from land masses affects nearby ocean areas, which are more [[Stratification (water)|stratified]], or less mixed, due to stronger surface currents forced by the heavy rainfall runoff.<ref>K.W. Choi and J.H.W. Lee (2000). [http://kfki.baw.de/fileadmin/conferences/ICHE/2000-Seoul/pdf/251/PAP_266.PDF Wet Season Tidal Circulation and flushing in Three Fathoms Cove.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227145244/http://kfki.baw.de/fileadmin/conferences/ICHE/2000-Seoul/pdf/251/PAP_266.PDF |date=2009-02-27 }} 4th International Conference on Hydro-Science and Engineering. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref>
===Floods=== High rainfall can cause widespread flooding,<ref>Overseas Security Advisory Council (2009). [https://www.osac.gov/Reports/report.cfm?contentID=95454 Warden Message: Guyana Rainy Season Flood Hazards.]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Overseas Security Advisory Council. Retrieved on 2009-02-05.</ref> which can lead to landslides and mudflows in mountainous areas.<ref>National Flood Insurance Program (2009). [http://www.floodsmart.gov/floodsmart/pages/media_resources/fact_calirain.jsp California's Rainy Season.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121204184919/http://www.floodsmart.gov/floodsmart/pages/media_resources/fact_calirain.jsp |date=2012-12-04 }} [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]. Retrieved on 2009-02-05.</ref> Such floods cause rivers to burst their banks and submerge homes.<ref>AFP (2009). [http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/01/12/2464296.htm Bali Hit By Wet Season Floods.] [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> The [[Ghaggar-Hakra River]], which only flows during India's monsoon season, can flood and severely damage local crops.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sirsa.gov.in/ddmp_sirsa_2015_16.pdf|title=Sirsa District Disaster Management Plan, 2015-2016|date=2015|website=District Sirsa|publisher=Government of Haryana Department of Revenue and Disaster Management, Haryana Institute of Public Administration|access-date=April 25, 2016}}</ref> Floods can be exacerbated by fires that occurred during the previous dry season, which cause soils which are sandy or composed of [[loam]] to become hydrophobic, or water repellent.<ref>Jack Ainsworth & Troy Alan Doss. [http://www.coastal.ca.gov/fire/ucsbfire.html Natural History of Fire & Flood Cycles.] California Coastal Commission. Retrieved on 2009-02-05.</ref> In various ways governments may help people deal with wet season floods. Flood plain mapping identifies which areas are more prone to flooding.<ref>FESA (2007). [http://www.fesa.wa.gov.au/internet/upload/716567526/docs/flood.pdf Flood.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531073015/http://www.fesa.wa.gov.au/internet/upload/716567526/docs/flood.pdf |date=2009-05-31 }} Government of Western Australia. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> Instructions on controlling erosion through outreach{{clarify|date=August 2015}} are also provided by telephone or the internet.<ref>King County Department of Development and Environmental Services (2009). [http://www.kingcounty.gov/property/permits/info/SpecialInterest/ConstructionIndustry/ErosionControl.aspx Erosion and Sediment Control for Construction Sites.] King County, Washington Government. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref>
== Life adaptations == [[File:East - Guinean Savanna 001.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.15|Equatorial [[savanna]] in the [[East Province, Cameroon|East Province]] of [[Cameroon]].]]
===Humans=== The wet season is the main period of vegetation growth within the Savanna climate regime.<ref>[[Charles Darwin University]] (2009). [http://learnline.cdu.edu.au/units/sbi507/module2/savanna.html Characteristics of tropical savannas.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217001357/http://learnline.cdu.edu.au/units/sbi507/module2/savanna.html |date=2009-02-17 }} Charles Darwin University. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> However, this also means that wet season is a time for food shortages before crops reach their full maturity.<ref>[[A. Roberto Frisancho]] (1993). [https://books.google.com/books?id=-K_SYHBo42MC&pg=PA388&lpg=PA388&dq=wet+season+characteristics&source=web&ots=QSA_t3uuZU&sig=iin9pzOynVHyA7x4wMYEkApeCV8&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=5&ct=result Human Adaptation and Accommodation.] University of Michigan Press, pp. 388. {{ISBN|978-0-472-09511-7}}. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> This causes seasonal weight changes for people in developing countries, with a drop occurring during the wet season until the time of the first harvest, when weights rebound.<ref>Marti J. Van Liere, Eric-Alain D. Ategbo, Jan Hoorweg, Adel P. Den Hartog, and Joseph G. A. J. Hautvast. The significance of socio-economic characteristics for adult seasonal body-weight fluctuations: a study in north-western Benin. British Journal of Nutrition: Cambridge University Press, 1994.</ref> Malaria incidence increases during periods of high temperature and heavy rainfall.<ref>African Centre of Meteorological Application for Development (2008). [http://www.wmo.ch/pages/prog/wcp/wcdmp/csm/documents/Bull_Deka1_April08.pdf Ten Day Climate Bulletin: Dekad of 01 to 10 April, 2008.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227145240/http://www.wmo.ch/pages/prog/wcp/wcdmp/csm/documents/Bull_Deka1_April08.pdf |date=2009-02-27 }} ACMAD. Retrieved on 2009-02-08.</ref>
===Animals=== Cows calve, or give birth, at the beginning of the wet season.<ref>John P. McNamara, J. France, D. E. Beever (2000). [https://books.google.com/books?id=hHyYFscJI3kC&pg=PA272&lpg=PA272&dq=wet+season+france&source=bl&ots=DEKUCI7nd8&sig=qlA9vcQN7aszIeUsCiw7ZO_CMkQ&hl=en&ei=wsuMSfK3IN-BtwfqjfmYCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPA275,M1 Modelling Nutrient Utilization in Farm Animals.] CABI, pp. 275. {{ISBN|978-0-85199-449-9}}. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> The onset of the rainy season signals the departure of the [[monarch butterfly]] from Mexico.<ref>Dr. [[Lincoln Brower]] (2005). [http://www.learner.org/jnorth/images/graphics/mexico/SeasonsWetDryLPB.gif Precipitation at the Monarch Overwintering Sites in Mexico.] Journey North. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref> Tropical species of [[butterfly|butterflies]] show larger dot markings on their wings to fend off possible predators and are more active during the wet season than the [[dry season]].<ref>Paul M. Brakefield and Torben B. Larsen (1983). [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119525964/abstract The evolutionary significance of dry and wet season forms in some tropical butterflies.] ''Biological Journal of the Linnean Society'', pp. 1–12. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> Within the tropics and warmer areas of the subtropics, decreased salinity of near shore wetlands due to the rains causes an increase in crocodile nesting.<ref>Phil Hall (1989). [https://books.google.com/books?id=97oE6gTFW8EC&pg=PA168&lpg=PA168&dq=wet+season+characteristics&source=web&ots=f-YiC1UsuP&sig=R8rihBBTBTpHQwhv6qNRb55V4F4&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=10&ct=result#PPA167,M1 Crocodiles, Their Ecology, Management, and Conservation.] International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources Crocodile Specialist Group, pp. 167. Retrieved on 2008-12-27.</ref> Other species, such as the [[arroyo toad]], spawn within the couple of months after the seasonal rains.<ref>San Diego Natural History Museum (2009). [http://www.sdnhm.org/fieldguide/herps/bufo-cal.html Bufo californicus: Arroyo Toad.] San Diego Natural History Museum. Retrieved on 2009-01-16.</ref> [[Armadillo]]s and [[rattlesnake]]s seek higher ground.<ref>Linda Deuver (1978). [http://www.corkscrew.audubon.org/Information/LDuever.html Dry season, wet season.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090120151900/http://corkscrew.audubon.org/Information/LDuever.html |date=2009-01-20 }} Audubon Magazine, November 1978, pp. 120–130. Retrieved on 2009-02-06.</ref>

{{Other uses|Zamzam (disambiguation){{!}}Zamzam}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox historic site | name = Well of Zamzam | native_name = زمزم | native_language = Arabic | image = File:Zamzamwell2.JPG | caption = Zamzam well entrance | locmapin = Saudi Arabia | map_caption = Location of Zamzam Well in Mecca, Saudi Arabia | coordinates = {{coord|21|25|19.2|N|39|49|33.6|E|type:landmark_scale:5000_region:SA-02|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Masjid al-Haram]], [[Mecca]] | area = about {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} deep and {{convert|1.08|to|2.66|m|abbr=on}} in diameter | built = | elevation = | height = | beginning_label = | beginning_date = | formed = | founded = Traditionally ca. 2400 BC | demolished = | rebuilt = | restored = | restored_by = | governing_body = [[Politics of Saudi Arabia|Government of Saudi Arabia]] | designation1 = | designation1_offname = Zamzam | designation1_date = | designation1_number = }} The '''Well of Zamzam''' ({{lang-ar|زَمْزَم}}) is a [[Water well|well]] located within the [[Masjid al-Haram]] in [[Mecca]], [[Saudi Arabia]], {{convert|20|m|abbr=on}} east of the [[Kaaba|Kabah]], the holiest place in Islam. According to [[Islamic mythology]], it is a miraculously generated source of water from [[God in Islam|God]], which sprang thousands of years ago when [[Abraham in Islam|Ibrahim's]] infant son [[Ishmael in Islam|ʾIsmaʿil]] was left with his mother [[Hagar in Islam|Hajar]] in the desert, where he was thirsty and kept crying. Millions of pilgrims visit the well each year while performing the ''[[Hajj]]'' or ''[[Umrah]]'' pilgrimages in order to drink its water. The safety of Zamzam water for drinking has been the subject of debate.{{cite news |title=Contaminated Zam Zam holy water from Mecca sold in UK |first=Guy|last= Lynn |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-13267205 |newspaper=BBC News |date=May 5, 2011 |accessdate=May 6, 2011}} == Traditional origin == Islamic tradition states that the Zamzam Well was revealed to [[Hagar in Islam|Hajar]], the second wife of [[Abraham in Islam|Ibrahim's]]Bible. {{Bibleverse||Genesis|16:3|HE}} ''A Hebrew – English Bible'', Retrieved July 13, 2011 and mother of [[Ishmael in Islam|ʾIsmaʿil]]. By the instruction of God, Ibrahim left his wife and son at a spot in the desert and walked away. She was desperately seeking water for her infant son, but she could not find any, as Mecca is located in a hot dry valley with few sources of water. Hajar ran seven times back and forth in the scorching heat between the two hills of [[Al-Safa and Al-Marwah|Safa and Marwah]], looking for water. Getting thirstier by the second, the infant Ishmael scraped the land with his feet, where suddenly water sprang out. There are other versions of the story involving God sending his [[angel]], [[Gabriel]] ([[Holy Spirit (Islam)|Jibra'il]]), who kicked the ground with his heel (or wing), and the water rose. A similar story about a well is also mentioned in the Bible.{{cite web|url=http://islamiat101.blogspot.com/2012/10/zamzam-holy-water-mention-in-bible_31.html|title=Seeking The Truth: Zamzam - The Holy Water Mention In Bible|first=Shafay|last=Islam|date=October 31, 2012|publisher=}} The name of the well comes from the phrase ''Zomë Zomë'', meaning "stop flowing", a command repeated by Hagara during her attempt to contain the spring water.{{cite web | title=Zamzam Studies and Research Centre | work=Saudi Geological Survey | url=http://www.sgs.org.sa/english/earth/pages/zamzam.aspx | accessdate=June 2, 2014| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130619152954/http://www.sgs.org.sa/english/earth/pages/zamzam.aspx | archivedate = June 19, 2013 | deadurl = no}} According to Islamic tradition, Abraham rebuilt the ''Bayt Allah'' ("House of God", cognate of the Hebrew-derived place name [[Bethel]]) near the site of the well, a building which had been originally constructed by [[Adam]] ([[Adam in Islam|Adem]]), and today is called the Kaaba, a building toward which Muslims around the world face in prayer, five times each day. The Zamzam Well is located approximately {{convert|20|m|abbr=on}} east of the Kaaba. In other Islamic tradition, [[Muhammad]]'s heart was extracted from his body, washed with the water of Zamzam, and then was restored in its original position, after which it was filled with faith and wisdom.{{cite web|url=http://hadithcollection.com/sahihmuslim/129-Sahih%20Muslim%20Book%2001.%20Faith/8470-sahih-muslim-book-001-hadith-number-0314.html|title=Sahih Muslim Book 001, Hadith Number 0314|publisher=Hadith Collection}} ==History== [[File:Zamzamwill.JPG|thumb|People visiting distribution points supplying Zamzam water]] [[Image:Zamzambottle.jpg|thumb|In Europe, alleged Zamzam water is frequently bottled in plastic containers of this type.]] [[File:Zamzam water in plastic bottle.jpg|thumb|Zamzam water in a [[plastic bottle]] for non-commercial distribution in Pakistan. This is a typical way to distribute the water to friends and family by people returning from Hajj and Umrah in Pakistan.]] [[File:Mecca zamzam.jpg|thumb|The Zamzam Well's old location for men. The location for women was separate.]] The well originally had two cisterns in the first era, one for drinking and one for [[Ritual purification|ablution]].{{cite web | author = Mahmoud Isma'il Shil and 'Abdur-Rahman 'Abdul-Wahid | title = Historic Places: The Well of Zamzam | url = http://www.islamonline.net/English/hajj/2002/01/stories/article4.shtml | accessdate =August 6, 2008 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080223204039/http://www.islamonline.net/English/hajj/2002/01/stories/article4.shtml| archivedate = February 23, 2008}} At that time, it was a simple well surrounded by a fence of stones. Then in the era of the [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]] [[caliph]] [[Al-Mansur]] 771 ADExcept where stated all dates are [[Julian calendar]] (154/155 [[Islamic calendar|AH]]){{cite web|url=https://www.fourmilab.ch/documents/calendar/|title=Calendar Converter|first=John|last=Walker|publisher=}} a dome was built above the well, and it was tiled with marble. In 775 AD (158/159 AH), [[Al-Mahdi]] rebuilt the well during his [[caliphate]], and built a dome of [[teak]] which was covered with [[mosaic]]. One small dome covered the well, and a larger dome covered the room for the pilgrims. In 835 AD (220 AH) there was further restoration, and the dome was covered with marble during the caliphate of [[Al-Mu'tasim]]. In 1417 (819/820 AH), during the time of the [[Mamluk]]s, the mosque was damaged by fire, and required restoration. Further restoration occurred in 1430 (833/834 AH), and again in 1499 (904/95 AH) during the time of [[Sultan]] [[Qaitbay]], when the marble was replaced. In modern times, the most extensive restoration took place to the dome during the era of the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] Sultan [[Abdul Hamid II]] in 1915[[Gregorian calendar]] (1333/1334 AH). To facilitate crowd control, the building housing the Zamzam was moved away from its original location, to get it out of the way of the ''[[Tawaf]]'', when millions of pilgrims would [[Circumambulation|circumambulate]] the Kaaba. The water of the well is now pumped to the eastern part of the mosque, where it was made available in separate locations for men and women. == Technical information == The Zamzam well was excavated by hand, and is about {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} deep and {{convert|1.08|to|2.66|m|abbr=on}} in diameter. It taps groundwater from the [[wadi]] [[alluvium]] and some from the [[bedrock]]. Originally water from the well was drawn via ropes and buckets, but today the well itself is in a basement room where it can be seen behind glass panels (visitors are not allowed to enter). Electric pumps draw the water, which is available throughout the Masjid al-Haram via water fountains and dispensing containers near the Tawaf area. [[Hydrogeology|Hydrogeologically]], the well is in the ''Wadi Ibrahim'' (Valley of Abraham). The upper half of the well is in the sandy alluvium of the valley, lined with stone masonry except for the top metre (3 ft) which has a concrete "collar". The lower half is in the bedrock. Between the alluvium and the bedrock is a {{convert|1/2|m|adj=on}} section of permeable weathered rock, lined with stone, and it is this section that provides the main water entry into the well. Water in the well comes from absorbed rainfall in the Wadi Ibrahim, as well as run-off from the local hills. Since the area has become more and more settled, water from absorbed rainfall on the Wadi Ibrahim has decreased. The [[Saudi Geological Survey]] has a "Zamzam Studies and Research Centre" which analyses the technical properties of the well in detail. Water levels were monitored by [[hydrograph]], which in more recent times has changed to a digital monitoring system that tracks the water level, electric conductivity, [[pH]], [[Reduction potential|Eh]], and temperature. All of this information is made continuously available via the Internet. Other wells throughout the valley have also been established, some with digital recorders, to monitor the response of the local [[aquifer]] system. Zamzam water is colourless and odorless, but has a distinct taste, with a pH of 7.5–7.7, indicating that it is alkaline to some extent.{{cite web |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10934529.2011.609109 |access-date=5 December 2016 |title=Water quality of bottled water in the kingdom of Saudi Arabia: A comparative study with Riyadh municipal and Zamzam water |publisher=Journal of Environmental Science and Health |volume=46 |issue=13 |date=October 12, 2011 |doi=10.1080/10934529.2011.609109}} {|class=wikitable |- !colspan=3|[[Mass concentration (chemistry)|Mineral concentration]]
as reported by researchers at [[King Saud University]]Nour Al Zuhair, et al. [http://faculty.ksu.edu.sa/khounganian/Interns%20Seminar/Zamzam-waterpublicationarticle.pdf A comparative study between the chemical composition of potable water and Zamzam water in Saudi Arabia]. ''KSU Faculty Sites'', Retrieved August 15, 2010 |- !rowspan=2|mineral !colspan=2|concentration |- !mg/L !oz/cu in |- |[[Sodium]] | {{convert|133|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Calcium]] | {{convert|96|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Magnesium]] | {{convert|38.88|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Potassium]] | {{convert|43.3|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Bicarbonate]] | {{convert|195.4|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Chloride]] | {{convert|163.3|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Fluoride]] | {{convert|0.72|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Nitrate]] | {{convert|124.8|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Sulfate]] | {{convert|124.0|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |- |[[Total dissolved solids]] | {{convert|835|mg/L|oz/cuin|disp=table}} |} ==The water and potential health risks== The British [[Food Standards Agency]] has in the past issued warnings about water claiming to be from the Zamzam Well containing dangerous levels of arsenic;{{cite web| url= http://www.food.gov.uk/news/newsarchive/2005/oct/zamzam |title= Zam Zam water warning| publisher= UK Food Standards Agency| archiveurl= http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20141204204354/http://www.food.gov.uk/news-updates/news/2011/4774/zamzam |archivedate= 4 December 2014| accessdate= 10 December 2017}} such sales have also been reported in the [[United Arab Emirates]] (UAE), where it is illegal to sell Zamzam water. The Saudi government has prohibited the commercial export of Zamzam water from the kingdom.{{cite news |title=UAE residents told to avoid buying Zam Zam water |first= Aftab |last= Kazmi |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/uae/general/uae-residents-told-to-avoid-buying-zam-zam-water-1.802850 |newspaper=gulfnews.com |date=May 4, 2011 |accessdate=May 5, 2011}} In May 2011, a [[BBC London]] investigation found that water taken from taps connected to the Zamzam Well contained high levels of [[nitrate]], potentially harmful bacteria, and [[arsenic]] at levels three times the legal limit in the UK, the same levels found in illegal water purchased in the UK.{{cite news |title=Contaminated Zam Zam holy water from Mecca sold in UK |first=Guy|last= Lynn |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-13267205 |newspaper=BBC News |date=May 5, 2011 |accessdate=May 6, 2011}} Arsenic is a [[carcinogen]], raising concerns that any who regularly consume commercial Zamzam water in large quantities may be exposed to higher risks of cancer. Later in that month the Council of British Hajjis stated that drinking Zamzam water was safe and disagreed with the BBC report. They also went on to point out that the [[Politics of Saudi Arabia|Government of Saudi Arabia]] does not allow the export of Zamzam water for resale. Also stating that it was unknown if the water being sold in the UK was genuine, people should not buy it and report the sellers to the [[Trading Standards]].{{cite press release|url= http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/releases/225253.php | website= Medical News Today| title= Zam Zam Water Is Safe, UK| date= 13 May 2011 | accessdate= 13 July 2015 | publisher= Council of British Hajjis (Pilgrims)}}{{reliable source|date=November 2017}}{{better citation needed|date=November 2017}} The BBC's findings have drawn mixed reactions from the Muslim community.H.A.R. (May 9, 2011). [http://www.waleg.com/archives/022874.html Zamzam Water is Safe to Drink]. ''Waleg'' Retrieved June 17, 2011 Environmental health officer Dr Yunes Ramadan Teinaz told the British broadcaster about commercially marketed Zamzam water that, "People see this water as a holy water. They find it difficult to accept that it is contaminated, but the authorities in Saudi Arabia or in the U.K. must take action."{{cite news| first= David |last= Griner |date= 6 May 2011| url= http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/holy-water-mecca-marketed-illegally-uk-131396 |title= Holy Water From Mecca Marketed Illegally in the UK| work= Adweek| accessdate= 24 May 2011}} The Saudi authorities have stated that water from the well was tested by the Group Laboratories of CARSO-LSEHL in [[Lyon]], licensed by the French Ministry of Health for the testing of drinking water. According to reports of these results, the level of arsenic in Zamzam water taken at its source is much lower than the maximum amount permitted by the [[World Health Organization]].Badea Abu Al-Naja (May 7, 2011). [http://www.arabnews.com/node/376786 Kingdom rejects BBC claim of Zamzam water contamination]. ''Arab News'', retrieved June 2, 2014 The Saudi authorities have thus said that the water is fit for human consumption.{{cite news| date= 8 May 2011| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-13326566 |title= 'No arsenic in genuine holy water', Saudis say| work= BBC News| accessdate= 8 May 2011}} Zuhair Nawab, president of the Saudi Geological Survey (SGS), has claimed that the Zamzam Well is tested on a daily basis, in a process involving the taking of three samples from the well. These are said to be examined in the King Abdullah Zamzam Water Distribution Center in Mecca, which is equipped with advanced facilities. An article written in ''Skeptic'' magazine in 2017 states that the methodologies of testing used by Saudi authorities are incomplete, inadequate and biased.{{cite journal|last1=Telias|first1=Michael|title=Miraculous Water is Just Bad Science|journal=Skeptic|date=2017|volume=Vol. 22|issue=No. 1|pages=8-12}} == See also == * [[List of reduplicated place names]] * [[Lourdes water]], a similarly venerated spring water in Catholicism == Notes == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == References == * {{cite journal|title=The Disappearance and Rediscovery of Zamzam and the 'Well of the Ka'ba'|author=Hawting, G. R.|journal=[[SOAS, University of London|Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies]], University of London|volume=43|issue=1|year=1980|pages=44–54|jstor=616125}} == External links == {{Commons category}} * Careem, S. H. A. {{cite web |title=The Miracle of Zamzam |work=Sunday Observer |url=http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2005/01/30/fea36.html |accessdate=June 5, 2005}} Provides a brief history of the well and some information on the alleged health benefits of Zamzam water. {{Hajj topics |expanded}} [[Category:Holy wells]] [[Category:Hajj]] [[Category:Islamic pilgrimages]] [[Category:Mecca]] [[Category:Religious objects]] [[Category:Springs of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Great Mosque of Mecca]]

{{Infobox protected area | name = Zoka Forest | alt_name = East Moyo Wildlife Reserve | iucn_category = | photo = | photo_alt = | photo_caption = | photo_width = | map = Uganda | map_alt = | map_caption = Location in Uganda | map_width = | relief = | location = [[Adjumani District]], [[Northern Region, Uganda|Northern Region]], [[Uganda]] | nearest_city = [[Adjumani]] | coordinates = {{coords|03|01|03|N|31|39|21|E|region:UG|display=inline, title}} | area = {{convert|1259|ha|km2|abbr=on}} (Tropical Forest),{{convert|10000|ha|km2|abbr=on}} (Wildlife Reserve Area) | established = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = National Forestry Authority | url = }} '''Zoka Forest''' is a natural tropical [[rain forest]] in the [[Northern Region, Uganda|Northern Region]] of [[Uganda]]. The forest is a component of the larger East Moyo Wildlife Reserve.<ref name="Deg">{{cite web | url=http://www.chimpreports.com/govt-to-degazette-zoka-forest-for-sugarcane-plantation | title=Govt to Degazette Zoka Forest for Sugarcane Plantation | accessdate=11 November 2016 | date=7 October 2016 | first=Paul | last=Ampurire | publisher=Chimpreports.com | location=Kampala}}</ref>
==Location== The forest is in the southern part of [[Adjumani District]],<ref>{{google maps | accessdate=11 November 2016 | url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/Adjumani,+Uganda/@2.9809984,31.9164786,9.09z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x177203102fe32e19:0x52d797dacb9b5649!8m2!3d3.2548527!4d31.7195459 | title=Map Showing Adjumani District With Zoka Forest in the Extreme South, Close to the Border With Amuru District}}</ref> approximately {{convert|50|km|0}} south of [[Adjumani]], the district capital.<ref>{{cite web | accessdate=11 November 2016 | last=Globefeed.com | url=http://distancecalculator.globefeed.com/Uganda_Distance_Result.asp?fromplace=Adjumani%2C%20Northern%20Region%2C%20Uganda&toplace=Zoka%20Forest%2C%20East%20Moyo%2C%20Northern%20Region%2C%20Uganda%2C&dt1=ChIJtw10EBQOchcRL80yqYowvEM&dt2=ChIJpzI8jMn9cRcRKjrYyXiBFa0 | date=11 November 2016 | publisher=Globefeed.com | title=Distance between Adjumani, Northern Region, Uganda and Zoka Forest, East Moyo, Northern Region, Uganda}}</ref> The coordinates of the forest are 03°01'03.0"N, 31°39'21.0"E (Latitude:3.017500; Longitude:31.655830).<ref>{{google maps | url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/3%C2%B001'03.0%22N+31%C2%B039'21.0%22E/@2.7248088,31.2431519,8.93z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x0!8m2!3d3.0175!4d31.65583 | title=The Geographical Coordinates of Zoka Forest, Adjumani District, Northern Region, Uganda | accessdate=11 November 2016}}</ref>
==Overview== Situated in the Itirikwa and Ukusijoni sub-counties in the southern part of Adjumani District, the Zoka Central Forest Reserve measures about {{convert|1259|ha|mi2}}. It is the only natural tropical rain forest and the only natural forest resource in Adjumani District.<ref name="Probe">{{cite web | url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201610060114.html | title=Uganda: UPDF Forms Committee to Probe Plunder of Zoka Forest | accessdate=11 November 2016 | date=6 October 2016 | location=Kampala | last=Julius Ocungi | first=and James Owich | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] via [[AllAfrica.com]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | date=13 December 2016 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Zoka-forest-loot-worries-Madi-head/688334-3484170-k2uqpo/index.html | title=Zoka forest loot worries Madi head | accessdate=13 December 2016 | last=Owich | first=James | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}}</ref>
==Conflicting interests==
===Prime minister's investigation=== In August 2016, Prime Minister [[Ruhakana Rugunda]] launched an investigation into the plundering of the Zika Forest. The four-person team is led by [[Mary Karooro Okurut]], the Minister for General Duties in the Office of the Prime Minister. Other team members include [[Ministry of Lands, Housing and Urban Development (Uganda)|Lands, Housing and Urban Development]] Minister [[Betty Amongi]], Minister of Water and Environment [[Sam Cheptoris]], and Minister of State for Northern Uganda [[Grace Kwiyucwiny]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://businessguideafrica.com/ruhakana-rugunda-appoints-four-ministers-to-probe-zoka-forest-plunder | title=Ruhakana Rugunda appoints Four Ministers to probe Zoka forest Plunder | date=6 August 2016 | accessdate=11 November 2016 | publisher=Business Guide Africa (BGA) | author=BGA}}</ref>
===UPDF vs NFA=== The [[National Forestry Authority]] (NFA) has in the past accused members of the [[Uganda People's Defence Force]] (UPDF) of illegally felling trees in the forest reserve and using UPDF trucks to transport the logs out of the forest. In October 2016, the resident commissioner of the Ajumani District told a press conference that she had photographs of UPDF trucks doing this. The trucks were followed to the Pabbo Army Detach in Amuru District, which is under the command of the 4th Division of the UPDF, headquartered in [[Gulu]]. The UPDF has mounted an investigation led by the 4th Division Commander, Brigadier [[Kayanja Muhanga]].<ref name="Probe"/>
===Cabinet ministers disagree=== On 4 October 2016, State Minister of Lands [[Persis Namuganza]] called a press conference to announce plans to de-gazette part of the Zoka Forest to allow the [[Madhvani Group]] to grow sugarcane in the area and relieve the contract farmers in the [[Busoga sub-region]]. The contract farmers in Busoga are starving because they neglected to grow food for their own sustenance and instead planted sugarcane.<ref name="Deg"/>
The plan evoked immediate outrage from environmental groups, the NFA, politicians, and concerned citizens. Deputy Prime Minister [[Moses Ali]], a member of parliament from the Adjumani District, called an impromptu meeting in which Minister of Lands, Housing and Urban Development [[Betty Amongi]] disowned the plan announced by Namuganza, her junior minister.<ref>{{cite web | accessdate=11 November 2016 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Ministers-disagree-on-Zoka-central-forest-giveaway/688334-3410814-qck2j0z/index.html | last=Kasozi | title=Ministers disagree on Zoka central forest giveaway | first=Ephraim | date=10 October 2016 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}}</ref>
